Complete Collection of Ancient and Modern Books, Volume 242 – Cough Chapter

The Yellow Emperor's Classic of Internal Medicine

Discussion on Cough

The Yellow Emperor asked: What causes the lungs to induce coughing? Qi Bo replied: All five viscera and six bowels can cause coughing; it is not solely the lungs. The Emperor said: I wish to understand its characteristics. Qi Bo replied: The skin and hair are connected to the lungs. The skin and hair first encounter pathogenic influences, which can enter through this connection. When cold food and drink enter the stomach and ascend to the lungs through the lung meridian, it results in lung cold. When the lungs are cold, both external and internal pathogens can unite and cause symptoms, leading to coughing from the lungs.

The five viscera each suffer from disease at their respective times, and if it is not that time, they transfer influence to the lungs.

Human beings are interrelated with heaven and earth, so the five viscera are treated accordingly. When affected by cold at the right time, it results in disease; if mild, it may cause coughing, and if severe, it may lead to diarrhea or pain.[1p]
The qi of the five organs corresponds with the qi of the four seasons and the five phases. Therefore, if one experiences a slight illness, it first ascends to the lungs, resulting in a cough; if severe, it rises to the upper, causing a downward flow that leads to painful dysentery.

In autumn, the lungs are the first to be affected; in spring, the liver is first; in summer, the heart; during the extreme yin, the spleen; and in winter, the kidneys are first affected.

The term "first affected" refers to how it then transmits to the lungs, causing a cough. The cough is fundamentally a disease of the lungs; this is why the lungs are mentioned first as being affected.

The Emperor asked: "What differentiates them?" Qi Bo replied: "The symptoms of lung cough are characterized by coughing with wheezing and sound, and in severe cases, spitting blood."

The lungs govern respiration; thus, a cough can produce sound from wheezing. The lungs manage qi; in severe cases, the qi may rise inversely, resulting in spitting blood.

For heart cough, the symptoms include coughing with heart pain, and the throat feeling blocked, resembling a lump; in severe cases, there is swelling of the throat and a sensation of obstruction.

The throat is associated with the lungs; the heart fire affects the metal phase, hence the throat feels blocked. The hand shao yin heart meridian originates in the heart, extends to connect with the heart system, and ascends to include the throat, thus resulting in swelling and pain in the throat.

For liver cough, the symptoms include pain below the ribs on both sides; in severe cases, one cannot turn, and turning leads to fullness beneath the ribs.

The liver meridian spreads through the rib area, which connects upward to the lungs; therefore, a cough leads to pain beneath the ribs. The inability to turn indicates an inability to bend or reach; this is because liver pathogenic influence ascends to the lungs, causing the cough, and if severe, it rebelliously obstructs below without allowing movement, leading to fullness beneath the ribs.[2p]
The symptoms of spleen-related cough manifest as pain under the right rib when coughing, with a pulling sensation towards the shoulder and back; in severe cases, movement becomes difficult, and coughing intensifies upon movement.

(Note: The spleen resides on the right side, hence the pain under the right rib when coughing. Spleen energy ascends to the lungs, and the lung's corresponding area is in the shoulder and back, causing the pulling sensation towards the shoulder and back. If the situation is mild, it affects the lungs leading to a cough; if severe, it impacts the primary channel.)

Symptoms of kidney-related cough cause pain that pulls the shoulder and back, and in severe cases produce phlegm when coughing.

(Note: The kidney channel passes through the diaphragm into the lungs, hence the pain when coughing relates to the lung's channel. Both lungs and kidneys may accumulate water, which leads to the production of phlegm in severe cases.)

The Emperor asked: What about the diseases of the six hollow organs? Where does the illness occur? Qi Bo replied: A long-standing cough in the five organs will transfer to the six hollow organs.

(Note: The illnesses of the six hollow organs shift based on the energy from the five organs.)

If the spleen's cough persists, it will affect the stomach. The symptoms of a stomach-related cough include coughing and vomiting; in severe cases, long worms may emerge.

(Note: The spleen and stomach are interconnected; if the spleen is ill, the disease transfers to the stomach, leading to the stomach's energy reversing and causing vomiting. If vomiting is severe, food energy is consumed, allowing worms to enter the stomach, thus leading to their emergence in severe cases.)

If the liver's cough continues, it will affect the gallbladder. Symptoms of a gallbladder-related cough include coughing and vomiting bile.

(Note: If the pathogenic factor is in the gallbladder, it causes reversal in the stomach, leading to bitter vomiting.)

If the lung's cough persists, it will affect the large intestine. Symptoms of a large intestine-related cough manifest as coughing and involuntary defecation.[3p]
The large intestine is a visceral organ of the lungs, serving as the channel for transmission. Thus, if it ascends, there will be coughing; if it descends, there will be incontinence. If the heart's cough persists, the small intestine will be affected. The small intestine coughs in a way that leads to a loss of qi, causing both qi and cough to be lost. If the qi of the extremities ascends, there will be coughing; if it descends, there will be incontinence. When both qi and cough are lost, it indicates that the qi is ascending and dispersing both upward and downward. If the kidney's cough persists, the bladder will be affected. The bladder coughs in a manner that leads to incontinence. The bladder is the organ of bodily fluids, responsible for the water pathway, hence the coughing leads to incontinence. If coughing continues for a long time, the three burners (San Jiao) will be affected. The three burners cough in a way that leads to abdominal fullness and a lack of desire for food and drink. The three burners are the organ of the middle passages, thus causing abdominal fullness. When coughing occurs, the upper burner cannot manage intake, resulting in a lack of desire for food and drink. All these conditions aggregate in the stomach, and relate to the lungs, causing excessive saliva and phlegm, with facial swelling and rebellious qi. When coughing occurs, the lungs elevate and fluids overflow, leading to an increase in saliva. Water and qi rising cause facial swelling and rebellious qi. The Emperor asked: How should this be treated? Qi Bo replied: To treat the organs, address their points; to treat the viscera, address their connections; and for swelling, treat the meridians. Coughing in the five organs should be treated at their points; coughing in the six viscera should be addressed at their connections; and for swelling, treat the meridians related to the lungs and stomach.[4p]

The Great Discussion on the Changes of Qi

In years when fire is excessive, summer heat prevails, leading to the dysfunction of the lungs associated with metal. As a result, the people suffer from fevers and experience symptoms of breathlessness and coughing. 【Note: In years governed by Wu, when fire is overly active, it overcomes metal. Therefore, the lungs are affected by heat, resulting in wheezing and coughing.】

In years when metal is excessive, dry air prevails, harming the liver associated with wood. In severe cases, this leads to breathlessness and coughing with reversed qi, and in extreme cases, there is blood in the cough. 【Note: Wheezing and reversed qi are lung diseases. The liver meridian passes through the lungs, hence the severity of the cough. The liver governs blood storage, which explains the presence of blood.】

In years when water is excessive, cold air prevails, harming the heart fire, leading to severe breathlessness and coughing. 【Note: In years governed by Bing, when water is overly active, it causes water qi to ascend, resulting in wheezing and coughing.】

In years when wood is deficient, dryness becomes prevalent, leading again to summer heat and fire overpowering the lung metal, resulting in coughing and nasal conditions. 【Note: When the annual wood energy is insufficient, the dryness attributed to metal becomes rampant, and fire resurfaces because its mother is suppressed. In years with deficiencies, the opposing energies may run amok, leading to its own weakening. Therefore, the Qi of the lungs can gain supremacy. The lungs open to the nose, hence the coughing and nasal discharge.】[5p]

Essentials of the Ultimate Truth

The Lesser Yin governs Heaven, where excessive heat prevails, causing the people to suffer from cold, heat, cough, and wheezing. In severe cases, the lungs are affected, leading to abdominal distention and difficulty in breathing and coughing. [Note: In the year of the Rat and Horse, the fire of Lesser Yin rises from within, thus the lungs suffer from fire and heat resulting in a lack of bodily fluids.]

The Lesser Yang governs Heaven, where excessive fire prevails, disrupting the balance of metal, causing the people to cough. [Note: The Lesser Yang governs Heaven during the years of the Tiger and Monkey. Due to the excess of fire, the balance of metal is disrupted, resulting in coughing.]

The Yangming governs Heaven, where excessive dryness prevails, causing the people to cough.[6p]
"Annotation: The Yangming is victorious; it is the year of Mao and You. The dry metal dominates above, hence the great coolness transforms the pulse, resulting in cough. Yangming's triumph arises from within, causing throat blockage and cough.

Annotation: The cold and austere metal energy emerges from within; the blockage and cough occur because the Yangming dry metal ascends to the lungs, creating a mutual resonance of energies. The Emperor asked: How does the recovery of the six energies manifest? Qibo replied: The recovery of the Shaoyin involves internal heat production, energy moving to the left, ascending to the right, resulting in cough and skin pain.

Annotation: The energy moving to the left indicates that the fire energy emanates from the water of the left kidney. Ascending to the right means that the lungs and kidneys intersect vertically, with the kidneys being the source and the lungs the endpoint. When the fire overtakes the lung's metal, coughing and skin pain arise. The recovery of the Taiyin involves transformation due to dampness, leading to internal fluid production, resulting in coughing and wheezing sounds.

Annotation: When the energy reaches an extreme, the transformation to cough and wheeze, accompanied by sound, indicates that fluids have invaded the lungs. The recovery of the Shaoyang involves cough with nasal bleeding; in severe cases, blood may be coughed up and discharged."[7p]
Translation:

The fire of Shaoyang reappears in the autumn and winter, which is why heat invades the heart and lungs, causing coughs. In severe cases, it enters the lungs, resulting in coughing up blood, harming both qi and blood.

The revival of Yangming brings forth abundant clear qi, leading to bitter vomiting, coughing, and irritability, with the illness located in the diaphragm. The revival of Yangming occurs during the time dictated by its fundamental position, which is why clear qi blooms. Coughing and irritability indicate that the lung qi is rebellious, with the illness in the diaphragm and the qi of Yangming rising inversely.

The manifestations of Yangming and Taiyang retaliate against the air from six months prior, which causes disturbances in wood, fire, and earth, leading to ailments across all.

When Jueyin is in charge of heaven, excessive victorious influences can result in tinnitus, dizziness, and in severe cases, coughing. The overpowering wind and wood energies can lead to such coughing, as the excessive and indulgent qi penetrates the channels.

When Shaoyin governs heaven, if overwhelming influences arise, it can lead to severe coughing and wheezing.[8p]
【Note: Lesser Yin governs the heavens, and the essence of three corresponds to the fire of Lesser Yin. When coughing and wheezing occur, it indicates the predominance of the sovereign fire. The sovereign fire governs the year, hence its superiority over the fire, and if excessive, it affects Lesser Yin.】 Lesser Yang governs the heavens; when it is predominant, there is fullness in the chest, coughing, and difficulty in breathing, which may escalate to blood in the sputum, and the hands feel hot. 【Note: Lesser Yang governs the heavens and the initial essence of the three energies, representing the fire of the sovereign and the minister. When predominant, the fullness in the chest and difficulty in breathing arise from this fire, desiring to ascend and emerge externally.】 Greater Yang governs the heavens; when the guest is dominant, there is hinderance in the chest, causing bizarre coughing. 【Note: The energy of Greater Yang resides externally; the lungs govern the skin and hair, thus the hinderance in the chest leads to a runny nose and coughing. The phrase "being affected by cold" refers to the distinction between Greater Yang and cold water.】 Greater Intestine governs the heavens; when the internal excess of clarity recurs, it results in coughing, nasal bleeding, and constriction in the throat. When heat resides in the heart and diaphragm, unceasing coughing and spitting blood may lead to death. 【Note: The internal excess of clarity refers to the guest energy of clarity that enters and accumulates within. Coughing, nasal bleeding, and constriction in the throat, along with heat in the heart and diaphragm, indicate lung disease. If white blood emerges from the lungs, it aligns with Greater Intestine governing the heavens—an essence belonging to the heavens where the organs belong to Yin but blood is Yin; thus if blood issues from the lungs, it signifies a predominance of Yang and an exhaustion of Yin.】[9p]
The Great Treatise on the Six Principles

When golden clouds gather, the people suffer from coughs and reversals.
[Note: "Cough and reversal" refers to lung ailments.]
The governance of the Lesser Yang controls the heavens, as the vital energy transforms and operates from the original state. At the beginning, cold departs, and great warmth arrives. In these cases, the pathogenic energy accumulates above, causing blood to overflow and the eyes to turn red, leading to coughs and headaches.
[Note: The initial state involves the Fire of the Lesser Yin; symptoms like blood overflowing, red eyes, and coughs are all manifestations of wind and fire as illnesses.]
In the second state, the heat reverses and accumulates; the illness is characterized by heat accumulating above, resulting in coughs and vomiting.
[Note: The second external pathogenic energy pertains to the Greater Yin's moist earth, leading to symptoms such as heat accumulation and vomiting due to external dampness condensing while internal heat is retained.]
In the third state, with the arrival of scorching summer heat, the people suffer from coughs and vomiting.[10p]
The notes explain that the qi from the heavens influences the three types of qi, contributing to ailments like coughing and vomiting due to exposure to wind and fire. The governance of the Lesser Yin is concerned with the qi transformation that occurs pre-naturally, resulting in people's ailments of cough and wheeze. The notes clarify that coughing and wheezing arise from heat diseases originating in the upper body.

When the qi of the terminal phase becomes dry, it leads to movement, causing residual fire to become concentrated, resulting in swelling and causing cough and wheeze. The notes explain that the terminating qi is governed by the Yangming, which oversees the dry and metallic transformation, thus causing dryness to lead to movement, heat accumulating from the interaction, and consequently leading to cough and wheeze. The governance of Yangming pertains to the post-natal qi transformation, leading to people's ailments of throat obstruction and cough. The notes mention that throat obstruction results from being affected by dry and damp qi, leading to sickness.

In separate discussions on Yin and Yang, it is noted that when the Yang is affected, it leads to a lack of vitality, prone to coughing and diarrhea. The notes explain that this Yang corresponds to the Lesser Yang qi. When in illness, the qi becomes insufficient while the fire becomes strong, leading to metallic burning, thus promoting coughing.

In relation to menstrual regulation, excess qi results in coughing and wheezing movements upward. The notes indicate that the lungs govern qi and breathing, so an excess leads to upward disturbances like coughing and wheezing.

As for syncope discussions, the hand Taiyin experiences reversal, resulting in a feeling of fullness and coughing. The notes clarify that the lungs govern qi, which can cause a feeling of emptiness and fullness due to reverse flow resulting in coughing. Furthermore, Yangming reverse flow leads to wheezing and coughing.[11p]
Notes: When Yangming qi is obstructed, it leads to wheezing; when it is counterflowing, it leads to coughing.
On the Generation of the Five Organs

Coughing and wheezing occur when obstruction is in the chest, involving the hand Yangming and Taiyin. Note: When pathogens harm the skin, hair, and qi layer, it leads to coughing and upward-reversal of qi. The pathway of the hand Taiyin begins in the middle burner, circulating up to the diaphragm, while the pathway of the hand Yangming enters the chest cavity and connects to the lungs below the diaphragm, belonging to the large intestine. When the pathogen overwhelms the meridian, the stomach experiences counterflow.
On the Communication of Vital Energy to Heaven

In autumn, when attacked by dampness, there is upward-reversal and coughing, leading to weakness and counterflow. Note: In cases of Yin disease, the energy descends to extremes and then ascends, hence in autumn, being injured by dampness causes upward-reversal and coughing.
On Pulse Diagnosis

In Lesser Yin, what is termed vomiting, coughing, and wheezing occurs because yin qi is below and yang qi is above. When all yang qi is floating without support, it results in vomiting, coughing, and wheezing. Note: The cold water of Lesser Yin is below, while the fire qi of the monarch is above. When water and fire do not interact, all yang qi rises without support, causing the upward-reversal of yang heat, resulting in the disease of vomiting, coughing, and wheezing. In Lesser Yang, when coughing is accompanied by blood, it indicates damage to the yang vessels. When yang qi has not yet fully flourished above but the pulse is full, fullness leads to coughing, causing blood to appear in the nose. Note: When yang qi is not yet flourishing above, it indicates that by the ninth month, Lesser Yang begins to flourish. Blood flows with qi, and when qi is not yet flourishing but the pulse is already full, the blood accumulates and reverses.[12p]
On the Transmission of Disease Related to Deficiency and Excess

Lung diseases characterized by wheezing and coughing lead to fullness and pain in the sides after three days; a feeling of heaviness and body pain after one day; bloating after five days; and if it does not resolve after ten days, death occurs. In winter, symptoms appear with the onset of cold, and in summer, they manifest as heat.

Note: The onset of symptoms corresponds to the energy of the sun—rising in the morning brings forth vitality, while setting in the evening draws it back. The lungs govern this vital energy, thus reflecting this cycle of inhalation and exhalation.

Heart disease initially presents as heart pain, followed by coughing after one day; pain in the sides after three days; obstruction and accumulation after five days, with body pain and heaviness, and if it persists for three days, death follows. In winter, this occurs during midnight; in summer, during noon.

Note: The heart is associated with fire. Midnight in winter indicates dominance of water, extinguishing the fire. Noon in summer indicates excessive fire, leading to self-immolation.

On the Regulation of the Five Elements

When metal is insufficient, it is said to give rise to transformation. When the conditions for transformation occur, symptoms include coughing and wheezing, affecting the lungs, presenting as sneezing, coughing, nasal discharge, and bleeding.

Note: Coughing and wheezing are manifestations of the lungs being harmed by fire. Sneezing, coughing, nasal discharge, and bleeding are diseases of metal.

When metal is excessive, it is described as solidification and formation. During conditions of solidification and formation, coughing becomes a prevalent symptom.

Note: Coughing in this context signifies damage to the lungs by fire.

When the lesser yang governs the heavens, fire energy descends, while lung energy rises, resulting in coughing, sneezing, nasal discharge, and nasal obstruction.

Note: The upward movement is due to the descending atmospheric energy, feared to be overpowering, thus causing a follow-through response. Coughing, sneezing, nasal discharge, and obstruction all indicate lung disease.[13p]

Discussion on Wind

The autumn's Geng and Xin energies are disrupted by external evils, resulting in "Lung Wind." The symptoms of Lung Wind include excessive sweating and aversion to wind, presenting a pale and ashen complexion. There may be shortness of breath and cough that is intermittent, worse in the evening than during the day. The area above the eyebrows is examined, showing a pale color.

Note: Wind is a Yang evil that opens the pores, which leads to excessive sweating. Wind harms Yang, causing a mismatch between the evil and the proper energies, hence the aversion to wind. The lung is associated with metal and has a white color. The lung governs Qi and can lead to coughing due to movement; when pressured by wind evil, this leads to shortness of breath. During the day, Yang energy is stronger and can overcome the evil, resulting in less severity; in the evening, the energy weakens, thus the illness worsens. The area above the eyebrows is a point for examining lung conditions.

Essential Diagnostics Conclusion

Spring acupuncture during the Autumn Equinox leads to muscle spasms and reverse Qi, which manifests as coughing.

Note: The organs are fundamentally superior to the lungs, governing the regulation and nourishment of Yin and Yang. The nourishing and protecting Qi and blood help to moisten the muscles and bones and benefit the joints. If the liver is diseased and in turn injures the lung, this causes the muscles to spasm and the Qi to move in reverse, hence leading to an upward reversal of Qi that results in coughing.

Discussion on the True Organs of Jade Mechanism

When the autumn pulse is insufficient, it leads to wheezing, shallow breathing, and coughing, with blood seen in the upper airways and pathological sounds noted.

Note: The lungs govern the Qi of the entire body; when Qi is insufficient, it causes breathlessness and wheezing, with shallow breathing leading to cough. If Qi is insufficient and reverses upwards, then blood also moves upwards. If Qi is insufficient and reverses downwards, one hears the pathological sounds of groaning.[14p]
On the Theory of the Five Qi

The lung is associated with coughing.
(Note: The theory of yin and yang suggests that the lung undergoes a transformation into cough.)

On the Discussion of Heat Illnesses

For illnesses of the kidney and wind, if the condition is weak, one should not apply acupuncture. If acupuncture is applied despite the weakness, after five days the patient's qi will surely manifest. When it manifests, there will be a sensation of heat accompanied by shortness of breath, heat rising from the chest and back to the head, sweating with hot hands, dry mouth and bitter thirst, yellowish urine, swelling below the eyes, rumbling in the abdomen, heavy body and difficulty in movement, missed menstruation, irritability, inability to eat, and trouble lying flat. Lying flat induces coughing, which is known as wind-water. The true qi ascends in rebellion, hence the bitter mouth and dry tongue. One cannot lie flat, as it leads to coughing up clear water. Those with water-related illnesses cannot lie down, as it causes fright, and fright exacerbates coughing.
(Note: The term "wind-water" is used here because wind provokes the movement of water. True qi refers to the vital essence from the heart of the organs. The heart belongs to fire and is adverse to water's evils; thus, when water qi rises, it forces the heart's qi to rebel, resulting in a bitter mouth and dry tongue. The kidney is the root, while the lung is the final aspect; both the metal and water organs are filled with moisture. Therefore, when water qi rises in the lung, it leads to coughing out clear water. Water evils invade the stomach, preventing one from lying down. The stomach meridian connects to the heart; when yang qi enters yin, yin and yang become imbalanced, causing fright and anxiety. The heart's qi overreaches into the lung, as metal fears fire and heat, thus exacerbating the cough.)[15p]
Discourse on Bi Syndrome

The syndrome of the spleen causes the limbs to become weak and collapse, resulting in coughing and vomiting of fluids, leading to a major obstruction above.
[Note: The spleen qi cannot circulate in the limbs, hence they become weak and collapse. The spleen meridian runs upward, affecting the throat; when the qi is obstructed, coughing occurs. Fluids entering the stomach rise to the spleen and lungs, but since the spleen qi cannot transform and transport them, there is vomiting of fluids. The lung qi cannot regulate, hence there is major obstruction above.]

Spiritual Pivot Scripture

Treatise on Pathogenic Qi and Organ Diseases

The liver meridian is slight and large, which manifests as coughing that draws down to the lower abdomen.
[Note: The liver meridian reaches the lower abdomen and connects to the lungs; coughing that draws down to the lower abdomen signifies the reversal of meridian qi between upper and lower.] The lung meridian is slight and rapid, indicating coldness and heat in the lungs, lethargy, coughing up blood, and drawing pain in the waist, back, and chest.
[Note: The lungs govern qi; lethargy, coughing up blood, and drawing pain in the waist, back, and chest indicate a deficiency and coldness in lung qi.][16p]
When the lungs are high, one experiences difficulty in breathing, a tightness in the shoulders, and a cough.
【Note: The lung governs qi, thus when it is high, there is difficulty in breathing, tightness in the shoulders, and coughing.】
— Jade Plate Chapter

Coughing with blood in the urine and loss of form, one’s pulse is small and tense, indicating a reverse condition. Coughing, loss of form, body heat, and a small pulse with urgency indicate a reversal. One would not survive more than fifteen days.
【Note: Coughing with blood in the urine and loss of form, the small and tense pulse indicates injury to the lungs. The heart governs blood, and the lungs cover the heart; hence, coughing and loss of form, body heat, and a small pulse indicate injury to the heart.】
Coughing, blood in urine, loss of flesh, pulse that is reversed. Coughing, vomiting, abdominal distension, and diarrhea, with a pulse gone, indicate reversal. One would not survive more than a moment.
【Note: Coughing with blood in the urine, loss of flesh, and a reversed pulse indicate issues with the lung channels. Coughing, vomiting, abdominal distension, and diarrhea with a absent pulse indicate issues with the liver and spleen channels.】
— Meridian Chapter

The lung hand taiyin channel, when disturbed, causes lung swelling, fullness, and asthma with coughing, pain in the epigastrium, and in severe cases, one may become disoriented or suffer from arm convulsions. This is identified as a disease arising from the lungs, characterized by coughing, asthma, thirst, irritability, fullness in the chest, pain in the inner and anterior arm, and heat in the palms.
【Note: This describes diseases arising from the lungs, hence symptoms include coughing, asthma, thirst, and irritability. The lungs govern qi and are the source of water, covering the heart. Fullness in the chest, arm pain, and heat in the palms are all illnesses in the areas governed by the channels.】[17p]
Fever Chapter

Coughing and bleeding from the nose, with no sweat, and the sweat not reaching the feet, leads to death.
[Note: Coughing indicates internal heat rising in the lungs. Bleeding from the nose indicates external heat pressing on the meridians. The lungs govern the skin and hair, connecting to all the meridians; both internal and external heat are resolved through lung qi and sweating. If sweat does not come out, it means qi is cut off above. If it does not reach the feet, it means qi is cut off below.]

Discussion on Distension

Lung distension is characterized by a feeling of fullness and difficulty in breathing.
[Note: Wu states that this is due to the guard qi reversing within the city's walls, resulting in lung distension.]

Discussion on Diagnosing Illness by Pulse

If one observes slight swelling in the eye socket, resembling someone just arising from sleep, and the neck pulse is active, with occasional coughing, while the hands and feet appear swollen and do not rise, it indicates wind-water skin distension.
[Note: Water overflows due to qi, causing slight swelling in the skin. An active neck pulse and skin distension with coughing indicate that water is retained in the skin, affecting lung qi. Wind-water occurs due to exposure to wind, where the wind causes the water to disperse.][18p]
Coughing Gate

Bian Que's Difficult Classic

Cough

If one obtains the lung pulse, the external signs are a pale face, frequent sneezing, deep sadness, being unhappy, and the desire to cry. The internal signs include movement in the area to the right of the navel, pressing here feels firm like pain. If one experiences coughing, wheezing, chills, and fever, it is indeed a lung issue; if not, it is not.

How can it be known that this is caused by a cold? Indeed. When one speaks irrationally, how can this be said? The lungs govern sound; entering the liver produces breathing, entering the heart leads to speech, entering the spleen results in singing, entering the kidneys causes groaning, and when inside oneself, it leads to weeping. Therefore, it is known that lung pathology entering the heart results in irrational speech.

The illness consists of fever with chills, possibly leading to coughing and wheezing, with a pulse that is floating and strong but thin. The accumulation in the lungs is called "Xi Bi," located beneath the right rib, large like a cup. If it persists for a long time, it causes chills and fever, coughing and wheezing, generating lung stagnation, which is obtained on the days of the spring甲乙. How can this be said? Heart illness transfers to the lungs, the lungs should transfer to the liver. The liver is suited to spring; if the sovereign does not receive evil, the lungs wish to return to the heart, but the heart is unwilling to accept, thus leaving a blockage as accumulation. Therefore, it is known that "Xi Bi" is obtained on the days of spring甲乙.[19p]
Essentials of the Golden Coffer (Han, Zhang Ji)

Coughing due to Mixed Symptoms

When heat resides in the upper jiao, coughing leads to lung wasting. If the pulse at the inch is rapid, and the person coughs with turbid phlegm in the mouth, this indicates lung wasting.

A question arises: if the cough is severe, how can we tell if it is a lung abscess? It should involve pus and blood; if summoned up, the person will die. What is the pulse type? The master said: the pulse at the inch is fine and rapid; fine means wind, rapid means heat. A fine pulse indicates sweating, while a rapid one indicates aversion to cold. Wind is associated with the defensive qi; when the breath does not enter, heat overwhelms the nutritive qi; when inhaled, it does not come out. Wind harms the skin and hair, heat injures the blood vessels. If wind resides in the lungs, the person will cough, experience dry mouth, wheezing, swollen throat without thirst, and much turbid phlegm, along with chills at times. The heat causes blood stagnation, accumulating into pus and abscesses that can be vomited like rice porridge—if emerging early, it can be saved; if the pus has formed, it is fatal.

For coughing with dyspnea and a watery chicken-like sound in the throat, use the Decoction of Rhubarb and Ephedra. For cough and dyspnea with continual turbid spitting, but unable to sleep while sitting, use the Soap Tree Pill. For coughing with a floating pulse, use the Decoction of Thick Pericarp and Ephedra.[20p]
Coughing with a feeling of fullness in the chest, a rapid pulse accompanied by chills, dryness in the throat without thirst, and occasionally producing foul-smelling phlegm resembling rice porridge, indicates lung abscess; marshmallow decoction is the main treatment for this.

For lung distension with cough and dyspnea, accompanied by irritability and wheezing, along with a floating pulse, indicating water retention in the chest, the Xiao Qing Long Decoction with gypsum is the main treatment.

In cases of chest obstruction, symptoms include wheezing, coughing up phlegm, pain in the chest and back, shortness of breath, and a pulse that is deep and slow, with tight and rapid pulse at the wrist; the combination of loquat, scallion, and white wine decoction is the main treatment.

Coughing with difficulty lying down and presenting like swelling is referred to as "supporting fluid."

If there is retained fluid, there will be pain under the ribs radiating to the lower abdomen, and coughing may cease suddenly.

In cases where phlegm accumulates above the diaphragm, symptoms of fullness, wheezing, coughing up phlegm are present, with alternating chills and fever, back pain, and tears flowing from the eyes; such a person may shake and tremble, indicating hidden fluid retention.

If the pulse is wiry in cases of cough, this indicates the presence of water; the Ten Jujube Decoction is the main treatment for this condition.[21p]
If someone has a condition characterized by phlegm and coughing, and experiences chest pain, they may not die for up to a hundred days or even a year; for this, Ten Jujube Soup is appropriate. If the cough has lasted for several years and the pulse is weak, treatment is possible; however, if the pulse is strong, the person is likely to die. Those with a weak pulse will surely suffer from discomfort, as they inherently have phlegm in their chest, and treatment should focus on the phlegm condition.

For a cough that worsens with breathing, preventing lying down, Xiao Qing Long Soup is the main remedy. If this soup is taken and leads to excessive salivation and a dry mouth, with a pulse that is deep at the cun and weak at the chi positions, and symptoms like cold extremities, gas rising from the lower abdomen to the chest and throat, numbness in hands and feet, and a flushed face resembling drunkenness, along with recurrent urinary difficulty, and occasional discomfort, then a combination of Fu Ling, Gui Zhi, Wu Wei Zi, and Gan Cao Soup should be used to address the ascending gas.

If the ascending gas subsides but the cough persists, leading to fullness in the chest, then Gui Ling Wu Wei Zi Gan Cao Soup should be used, replacing Gui with dried ginger and Xi Xin to treat the chest fullness. If the fullness of the cough stops but thirst increases and the ascending gas reappears, this indicates that Xi Xin and dried ginger are acting as heat-inducing medicines.[22p]
If one takes a remedy and is still thirsty, but the thirst subsides, this is known as "supportive drink." Supportive drink requires an adventure, and one who has an adventure will certainly vomit. After vomiting, one should take Pinellia to eliminate the residual fluids.

If the pulse at the inch (cun) position is deep and slippery, it indicates the presence of water Qi, and the face is swollen and warm, this is called "wind edema." If one observes the eyes slightly puffy, resembling a silkworm newly awakened, and if the neck pulse beats strongly, with frequent coughing, and if pressing the hands and feet leaves them sunken and non-rebounding, that is wind edema.

In the case of a Taiyang disease, the pulse is floating and tight, with pain in the joints, coughing, and shortness of breath without thirst, this signifies spleen distension, appearing like swelling. Sweating will lead to recovery. However, in all cases where there is thirst and diarrhea, and frequent urination, one must not induce sweating.[23p]
A patient suffers from water retention, with swelling in the face, limbs, and body. Urination is not smooth; when the pulse is examined, water is not mentioned, but chest pain is reported, with qi rising to the throat, resembling the condition of roasted meat. The patient tends to have a slight cough and wheezing. As the teacher said, what type of pulse is this? The teacher responded: The pulse at the inch position is deep and tight. Deep indicates water, tight indicates cold; deep and tight clash, resulting in a blockage at the lower abdomen. Initially, the condition is slight but can go unnoticed in the young and vigorous. After the decline of yang, the defensive and nutritive energies become disturbed, with yang diminished and yin dominant. A slight cold blockage occurs, and kidney qi rises, causing a constriction in the throat and urgent pain below the ribs. The physician thinks that retaining fluid and treating with drastic purging will alleviate the condition, but as the qi doesn't disperse, the illness persists. Afterward, inducing severe vomiting causes stomach emptiness and distress, dryness in the throat craving water, poor urination, and undigested food leading to swelling in the face, hands, and feet. They also administered Ting Li Wan to remove water; at that time, the patient seemed to improve slightly, but overindulgence in food and drink caused the swelling to return as before, accompanied by painful pressure in the chest and ribs that felt like a runaway dolphin. If water rises and spills over, it leads to cough, wheezing, and reverse qi. The first step is to attack the defensive qi to stop the condition, then treat the cough; once the cough resolves, the wheezing will naturally improve. It is essential to treat the new illness first; the other illness will follow.

In the case of coughing up blood, reversed qi, and difficulty breathing, the pulse is rapid with signs of heat, leading to an inability to lie down, which results in death. For those who cough due to excessive drinking, this must lead to coughing up blood, a result of extreme overindulgence.[24p]
Zhong Cang Jing by Hua Tuo

Discussion on the Deficiency and Excess of the Organs Regarding Life and Death

When the heart is ill, it first manifests as heart pain and incessant coughing. If the diaphragm is obstructed, the body feels heavy and this persists for three days, leading to death. The small intestine is the receptacle organ; when one coughs, the qi expels simultaneously. The pulse in the lungs comes weakly; if it does not reach adequately, it causes wheezing and coughing, with blood appearing in sputum and the presence of disease sounds below. If there is deficiency, cold arises, leading to cough, difficulty in breathing, exhaustion, and excessive sadness. Furthermore, if lung illness persists with coughing leading to blood, bodies feel hot and breathing is short, the pulse should be thin. If the pulse is instead floating and large, and the color appears red instead of white, it indicates fire overpowering metal, which is ten times more fatal and untreatable. In lung illnesses with wheezing and coughing, if the body is cold without heat, and the pulse is slow and weak, treatment is possible. If there is deficiency, one cannot breathe properly; the ears feel heavy, throat is dry, and there is wheezing and coughing with difficulty breathing, along with shoulder and back pain. If there is coughing with involuntary urination, it is due to the upper deficiency failing to control the lower. When drinking alcohol in a draft, if it affects the lungs, it leads to coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath. If there is blood, it is untreatable; if no blood is present, treatment is possible.[25p]
If a person's voice is usually clear and strong yet suddenly becomes quiet and strained, making it hard for them to speak and keeping them fixed in place, although they are not yet ill, their time is limited. For lung diseases, high and rapid breathing accompanied by a cough, along with a warm body and strong pulse indicates illness; if it's weak, they feel fatigued with shortness of breath, swelling in the right side, and speak in short gasps.

For kidney issues, symptoms include abdominal swelling, leg edema, coughing, a heavy body, and sweating at night with a dislike for wind. Additionally, a sound in the throat while sitting, accompanied by coughing and spitting of blood, indicates a deficiency in the kidney with cold, leading to a desire for breathlessness.

The bladder is an organ for fluids. If there is persistent coughing from the bladder, it affects the three burners, leading to a full abdomen and a lack of appetite.

If the middle burner is hot and solid, there is an obstruction, causing belly bloating and breathlessness, with gas rising and sinking blocked, resulting in stagnation.

Sudden coughing with a rapid pulse and a thin body indicates death. Sudden coughing with a scattered pulse indicates death. Sudden coughing with an obese frame and a very rapid pulse indicates death. Coughing with nausea and uncontrollable bowels, along with a thin yet almost absent pulse, indicates death. For all illnesses involving coughing and breathlessness, if the pulse is both sinking and floating, it indicates death. A cough with a hard sinking pulse indicates death.[26p]
Pulse Classic (by Wang Shuhe from the Jin dynasty)

Cough Pulse

If the pulse at the right wrist's inch position is strong and full, this indicates a fullness in the Yangming large intestine channel. The patient suffers from abdominal fullness, is prone to wheezing and coughing, has a red face, body heat, and a feeling in the throat as if there is a lump.

In cases of sweating, vomiting, cold in the lungs, coughing due to drinking cold water, and diarrhea with a weak and cold stomach, the pulse will be tight. A floating, short pulse indicates lung injury; the person may not survive for more than a year, and the patient is likely to cough.

If the cough pulse is deep and tight, the prognosis is death; if it is floating and straight, there is hope for survival; if it is floating and soft, there is hope for recovery; if it is slightly hidden and sinking, the prognosis is death.

In cases of a cough coupled with emaciation, a pulse that is firm and large indicates death. If the cough leads to emaciation and heat persists without subsiding, the prognosis is death.[27p]
Pulse Diagnosis
by Wang Shuhe (Jin Dynasty)

Cough Pulse

The Song of Lung Pulse states: "Deep and tight combined with slippery, the sound of cough can still be heard."
The Song of Slippery Pulse states: "Slippery at the inch, phlegm in the diaphragm leads to nausea, sourness when swallowing, strong tongue, or coughing."
The Song of Rapid Pulse states: "Rapid pulse treats fire illnesses, with five causes to consider. Frequent wheezing and coughing indicate phlegm accumulation, or symptoms of madness with toxic sores."

Prescriptions of a Thousand Gold
by Sun Simiao (Tang Dynasty)

Discussion on Cough

The classics state: "All five organs and six bowels can cause coughing." The lungs are externally situated, close to the upper parts, and associated with the skin and hair, which easily receive pathogens; thus, the lungs are particularly prone to cough. When pathogens invade the lungs, symptoms include chills, heat, wheezing, sweating, coughing affecting the shoulders and back, and wheezing noises; in severe cases, it leads to coughing up blood.

If lung cough persists, it transmits to the large intestine; the cough's manifestation will then involve incontinence of feces. Kidney cough manifests as pain in the lower back, and in severe instances, involves coughing up phlegm. If kidney cough persists, it transmits to the bladder; the manifestation will then involve incontinence of urine.

Liver cough presents as pain in the left side of the ribs, and in severe cases, the patient cannot turn over. If liver cough persists, it transmits to the gallbladder; the cough will lead to the discharge of bitter clear fluid.

Heart cough manifests as heart pain, a sensation of obstruction in the throat, and in severe cases, can lead to throat paralysis or swelling. If heart cough persists, it transmits to the small intestine; the manifestation will then involve loss of breath.

Spleen cough manifests as pain in the right side of the ribs, accompanied by a pulling sensation in the shoulders and back, and in severe cases, the patient cannot move; movement leads to severe coughing. If it continues for a long time, it transmits to the stomach; the manifestation will then involve coughing and vomiting; in severe cases, it can lead to expulsion of long worms.[28p]
A persistent cough that does not cease affects the Triple Burner. The symptoms of a cough associated with the Triple Burner include coughing with a sensation of fullness in the abdomen, inability to eat or drink. All of this accumulates in the stomach and relates to the lungs, causing excessive phlegm and facial swelling along with upward-contrary qi. When there is cold wind, and one is exposed to it, it injures the skin, penetrating into the internal organs, resulting in the above cough and shortness of breath. Sudden exposure to inappropriate cold harms the skin; if it combines with the lungs, it leads to coughing and shortness of breath, or pain in the chest and sides. If coughing up blood-streaked phlegm occurs, it indicates that heat has been affected by untimely cold, becoming violently concentrated and unable to disperse gradually, leading to deep-seated stagnation, likely indicating lung abscess. Coughing with warm medications may worsen the cough, and when accompanied by severe heat with purulent blood, sweating and aversion to cold will be present. When there are untimely cold instances, one must observe the four seasons closely.

When asked about the ten kinds of cough, the teacher replied: There is windy cough, cold cough, phlegm cough, liver cough, heart cough, spleen cough, lung cough, kidney cough, gallbladder cough, and Jueyin cough. When asked about the differences in the symptoms of these ten coughs, the teacher said: When one coughs while wanting to speak but cannot complete the thought, it is called windy cough. If one coughs due to drinking cold fluids or eating cold food, it is termed cold cough. A feeling of hardness and fullness below the heart, along with cough-related pain in the sides, with a pulse that is slow, is referred to as phlegm cough.[29p]
Coughing that leads to pain below the ribs is called liver cough. Coughing with blood in the phlegm, referring to the little yin hand, is called heart cough. Coughing that produces saliva continuously and leads to the lower abdomen is called spleen cough. Coughing that pulls at the neck and expels saliva and foam is called lung cough. Coughing that causes the ears to hear nothing and affects the waist and navel is called kidney cough. Coughing that leads to headache and bitter mouth is called gallbladder cough. Coughing that affects the base of the tongue is called jueyin cough. A cough caused by wind should not be treated with purgatives. Coughs due to cold, phlegm, or liver issues should be treated by needling foot Tai Chong. Heart cough should be treated by needling hand Shen Men. Spleen cough involves needling foot Tai Bai. Lung cough is treated by needling hand Tai Quan. Kidney cough requires needling foot Tai Xi. Gallbladder cough is treated by needling foot Yang Ling Quan. Jueyin cough is treated by needling hand Tai Ling.

Prolonged coughing with phlegm can indicate "internal dampness." If coughing intermittently presents with fever and the pulse feels like "string on a bamboo," it is not a deficiency but rather caused by cold-dampness in the chest, which should be expelled.

For those who cough consistently and have a wiry pulse, it is important to consider their strength and weakness before administering expectorants, and it is advisable to do so only when there is no fever.[30p]
Coughing is associated with the pulse indicating water; it can be treated with a decoction of ten dates. If one cannot find rest due to coughing, this is because the yin is unable to resist pathogens. Those who cough and cannot lie down will have pain radiating up along the neck. Their cough resembles that of a child with whooping cough. For those who consume alcohol and cough, they will surely vomit blood; this results from prolonged sitting and excessive drinking. If the pulse is deep, one should not induce sweating. In cases of chronic cough over several years, if the pulse is weak, it can be treated; if it is excessively strong, it leads to death. A weak pulse suggests that the condition may readily worsen; it indicates that there is fluid retained in the chest, thus belonging to someone with fluid issues. Sweating emerges with difficulty breathing, implying fluid issues. A cough accompanied by frequent urination, akin to loss of control, should not be treated with sweating, as sweating could induce cold chills or fainting.

For illnesses characterized by vomiting blood, wheezing, and difficulty breathing, with a rapid pulse indicating heat, those unable to lie down may face death. In cases of coughing and difficulty breathing with a rapid pulse, death follows, as the person's condition has deteriorated. A large, scattered pulse indicates a state of robust qi but deficient blood, referred to as having a superficial condition without a deep one. Difficulty breathing and facial swelling with a floating, large pulse is untreatable and often worsens with dysentery. When one experiences restless breathing and wheezing, this indicates lung swelling and a potential for fluid retention; inducing sweating can lead to healing.

In general, when dealing with breathing issues, many have found relief through the use of emetic herbs or acupuncture, which is important to deeply understand.[31p]
The Book of Living Beings
By Zhu Gong, Song Dynasty

Coughing

Coughing due to cold damage has two patterns: one is the Taiyang pattern with cough, treated with Xiao Qing Long and Xiao Chai Hu. The other is the Shaoyin pattern with cough, treated with Zhen Wu Decoction, Si Ni San, and Zhu Ling Decoction. Generally, if heat is in the upper jiao, the person must drink water. If water accumulates below the heart, the lung becomes floating; the lung governs cough, and the water vapor rides on it, causing a cough with slight wheezing. Zhang Zhongjing states: if the cold damage does not resolve at the surface, and there is water vapor below the heart, leading to dry retching, fever, and cough, Xiao Qing Long Decoction is the primary treatment. If urination is not smooth and there is fullness in the lower abdomen, remove Ma Huang and add Fu Ling. For alternating chills and fever, fullness and pain in the chest and sides, or cough, Xiao Chai Hu Decoction is the primary treatment; remove Ren Shen and Da Zao, adding Wu Wei Zi and Gan Jiang. If it is the Shaoyin pattern with cough, heaviness and pain in the four limbs, poor urination, and diarrhea with cough, Zhen Wu Decoction is the primary treatment; add Wu Wei Zi and Gan Jiang. In general, the water vapor from cold damage arises from excessive water consumption. The ancients treated coughing from water vapor: if the problem is in Yang, then Xiao Qing Long Decoction is used; if in Yin, then Zhen Wu Decoction is used. For cold extremities, abdominal pain, or diarrhea with cough, Si Ni San is the main treatment; add Wu Wei Zi and Gan Jiang. If diarrhea persists for six to seven days, with cough, dry thirst, agitation, and inability to sleep, Zhu Ling Decoction is the prime remedy.[32p]
Coughing Discussion

Coughing refers to the presence of sound without phlegm, indicating that the lung qi is injured and not clear. 'Sough' refers to having phlegm without sound, resulting from dampness in the spleen that produces phlegm. Coughing entails having phlegm and producing sound, which stems from lung qi injury and the movement of spleen dampness, leading to both cough and sough. Spleen dampness occurs when one is injured by humidity in autumn, causing accumulation in the spleen. Therefore, the "Inner Canon" states that if there’s injury from dampness in autumn, one is bound to cough in winter. Generally, the nature of autumn is meant to be clear, but if this is disturbed, the qi will counteract and result in coughing, and if severe, it can excite spleen dampness and produce phlegm. Thus, it is understood that the spleen cannot retain dampness; though the lung qi is injured, it won't produce phlegm. Phlegm has less cold and more heat. Hence, coughing is not solely a disease of the lungs, as the lungs govern the skin and are responsible for external factors, thus wind and cold can first injure them. The "Inner Canon" states that all the five organs and six bowels can lead to coughing; it is not the sole domain of the lungs, as they each govern their respective times and can be affected by illness. The conditions vary; cold, heat, dryness, dampness, wind, and fire—each can cause coughing. Only when dampness leads to phlegm drinks entering the stomach, lingering without movement, and solely entering the lungs does it result in coughing. For instance, dampness in the heart channel is called heat phlegm, in the liver channel it is called wind phlegm, in the lung channel it is named qi phlegm, and in the kidney channel it is known as cold phlegm; treatments differ and should be addressed according to the symptoms.[33p]
If there is coughing without phlegm, use pungent and sweet substances to moisten the lungs. Therefore, when treating coughs, prioritize phlegm treatment; for phlegm treatment, prioritize regulating qi. Thus, Nánxīng and Bànxià are effective against phlegm, leading to spontaneous alleviation of cough; Zhǐkē and Chénpí promote the flow of qi, allowing phlegm to descend. For those with phlegm who can eat, use the Dà Chéngqì Tāng to mildly purge; if phlegm prevents eating, use the Hòubò Tāng for treatment. In summer, if cough accompanied by fever occurs, it is termed "heat phlegm cough" and should be treated with Four Liang of Xiǎo Chái Hú, adding One Liang of Shígāo and Half Liang of Zhīmǔ. In winter, if cough comes with chills and fever, it is termed "cold cough" and should be treated with Xiǎo Qīng Lóng plus apricot kernels. These are general principles; one should adjust based on the specific symptoms and timing, considering the condition's strength or weakness—this is the fundamental approach to treatment.

When one Yang is affected, there may be slight coughing and diarrhea, with the three jiaos (organs) not functioning well, resulting in coughing upwards and diarrhea downwards, with unsteady heart fire, manifesting as a pull; regulate the center and disperse to treat.

Coughing can originate from all five organs, due to inner injuries to the spleen and stomach, or from external wind-evil. The skin and hair are related to the lungs; wind and cold follow the source and enter, opening the pores for interior and exterior to connect, first transmitting to the lungs and resulting in cough, indicating lung heat. Cold transforms into heat, leading to phlegm production, hence wheezing fullness. The classics state: the throat feels obstructed like a knot; in severe cases, it leads to coughing blood. Chest fullness, wheezing, and thick, sticky phlegm indicate lung qi heat.[34p]
Cough Syndrome

Cough refers to the presence of sound without phlegm, indicating injury to the lung qi and lack of clarity. Sputum refers to the presence of phlegm without sound, caused by dampness in the spleen leading to phlegm. A cough with phlegm and sound occurs due to lung qi injury, which activates spleen dampness, resulting in sputum.

For treating cough, addressing phlegm is the priority, and for treating phlegm, boosting qi takes precedence. Therefore, Naxing and Banxia resolve phlegm, while Zhike and Chenpi help disperse qi. For those with phlegm who can eat, Datchengqi Decoction gently purges. For those with phlegm who cannot eat, Houpo Decoction is prescribed.

In summer, cough with fever is called heat phlegm cough; Xiao Chai Hu Decoction with an additional 2 taels of gypsum and half a tael of Zhimu should be used. In winter, cough accompanied by cold and heat is referred to as cold cough; Xiao Qinglong Decoction plus apricot kernel should be taken. Honey-boiled ginger soup, honey-boiled orange peel soup, and burnt ginger with walnuts all treat non-phlegm cough. This is a general guideline, but adjustments should be made according to the time and specific symptoms.[35p]
On the Duties of Filial Piety in Confucianism (Yuan, Zhang Congzheng)

Coughing and wheezing are essentially the same condition. Later scholars may distinguish cough as yang and wheeze as yin, but there is no substantial evidence for this. The "Inner Canon" discusses coughing exclusively in one section, without mentioning wheezing. Therefore, it can be concluded that cough is simply another form of wheeze and vice versa. The "Discussion on Yin and Yang" states: "In autumn, one suffers from dampness, leading to cough in winter." Additionally, the "Five Organs Generation" text mentions "coughing and wheezing with difficulty in breathing." The "Essential Diagnosis" concludes that "spring treatment addresses autumn cough, which is cyclical." It also indicates in the "Calm and Composed" section that persistent cough indicates a reversal of kidney energy. The "Plain Questions" exclusively addresses cough in its various sections, and other texts focus on cough without mentioning wheeze, thereby confirming that they refer to the same condition. Some may argue that wheeze is a separate condition, as indicated in writings on exogenous febrile diseases, which describe cough as a sound resembling stairs in the throat; this perspective is unfounded. The "Inner Canon" treats wheeze simply as a cough. The "Discourse on the Flowing Vital Energy" states: "In autumn, one suffers from dampness, leading to an upward reversal and cough."[36p]
The discussion on the correspondence of yin and yang is essentially the same, and the absence of the character for "cough" indicates that a cough is clearly a form of "sore throat." The reason I emphasize this is because Confucius said: "One must indeed rectify names!" Since coughs have historically been attributed to the lungs as a disease, this notion is not easily changed. The "Suwen" states: lung diseases manifest as wheezing and cough. It also says: cough and shortness of breath occur with stagnation in the chest, affecting the hand's taiyin and yangming channels. Among the twelve meridians in the "Lingshu," only the taiyin lung meridian mentions: "The lungs are full and swollen, leading to wheezing and coughing," while the other meridians do not address it. Although the "Suwen" indicates that all five viscera and six bowels can have coughs, the essence lies in the lungs being central. The "Suwen" also says: "The skin and hair are associated with the lungs; they are the first to receive pathogenic qi." The commentary suggests that the pathology refers to cold qi. The text further states: "Pathogenic qi enters through their connection; if cold food and drink enter the stomach and travel up via the spleen meridian to the lungs, the lungs become cold. Cold lungs lead to an internal-external connection with pathogens, which can then result in a lung cough."[37p]
Later generations see these words and wrongly conclude that coughing is due to cold, without comparing them to other texts. How could they know that all six qi can cause coughing? If one were to claim that coughing is due to cold evil, then how do we explain excessive fire in some years, where intense heat leads to lung evil, causing widespread coughing? Similarly, in years where wood is insufficient, the heart qi is delayed, overpowering the lung metal, resulting in coughs and nasal congestion. During periods of transformation, metal may be deficient, leading to sneezing and coughing; in times of hardening, excessive metal causes cough as well. In lesser yang's administration, fire descends while lung metal ascends, resulting in coughs and sneezes. When fire is excessive, it can lead to coughing up blood and restlessness. During lesser yang's control, if the body's defenses are strong, one experiences a full chest and cough; if the atmospheric heat becomes trapped, it can trigger reverse cough and vomiting. When the three qi arrive, heat is present, leading to people suffering from coughing and vomiting. In the final qi, if yang fails to contain itself, one will cough. In the rebound of lesser yang, dryness and excessive heat can cause frightening coughs and blood discharge, and in severe cases, reverse coughing leading to blood loss. In lesser yin's control, heat rises above while clear qi emerges from below, with cold and heat clashing in the middle, making people suffer from coughing and wheezing. When the three qi are active and the heavenly order is set forth, great fire spreads, secondary fire takes hold internally, swelling results in coughing and wheezing, and severe cases may lead to blood stagnation. In lesser yin's control, if external pathogens prevail, sneezing can occur, and in severe cases, coughing and wheezing may ensue. In the rebound of lesser yin, internal heat rises, qi moving left and right can lead to coughing, skin pain can enter the lungs, causing cough and nasal congestion.[38p]
If such conditions arise, they are all born from fire and heat; can one alone attribute them to cold? Is it said that coughing is solely due to heat and fire? When the Liver governs the heavens, if Wind prevails, then one experiences dizziness and tinnitus, which can lead to severe coughing. Such conditions stem from Wind, so how can they be solely attributed to heat and fire? Is it claimed that coughing is caused exclusively by Wind? When the Spleen governs the heavens, if Dampness prevails, coughing and spitting blood occur; with the restoration of the Spleen, Dampness transforms, fluids accumulate within, causing coughing and wheezing. These conditions are born from Dampness, so can they be exclusively attributed to Wind? Is it said that coughing arises solely from Dampness? If illness arises from the metal, people suffer from cough and chest pain; if there is an excess of metal for the year, dry air circulates, the Liver becomes afflicted, and people suffer from severe cough and reverse flow, which may even result in vomiting blood. When the Yangming governs the heavens, if Metal and Fire combine, people suffer from cough and throat obstruction; if Dampness dominates, coughing may occur, accompanied by abdominal noises. When Yangming governs, if the body is clear and retains excess, one may cough blood and have throat obstruction; if excessive heat remains in the heart, such cough does not cease and may expel white blood, leading to death. When Yangming is strong, clarity emerges from within, causing throat obstruction and cough; when Yangming is restored, clear air rises strongly, leading to cough and heart disturbance. If all these conditions arise from dryness, can one solely attribute them to Dampness? Is it claimed that coughing is caused only by dryness? When the Taiyang governs, if pathogenic influences prevail there is discomfort in the chest, leading to a runny nose; upon catching a chill, one coughs.[39p]
If this type arises in the cold, how can it be exclusively due to dryness? Furthermore, the symptoms of lung-related wind include excessive sweating, aversion to wind, a pale complexion, occasional shortness of breath, with improvement during the day and worsening at night; this is also classified as wind-related cough. The laborious wind cough produces yellowish-green phlegm, resembling pus and the size of a pellet; this too is a wind cough. If there is loss or something sought is unattainable, it leads to a sound from the lungs, indicating lung heat and dryness; this is a heat-related cough. Yangming counterflow presents with wheezing, coughing, and body heat; this is also a heat-related cough. A sudden onset of disease can cause slight breath and frequent coughing; this indicates fire-related cough. Wheezing cough results from dampness affecting the Yangming; this is damp-related cough. If wind and water cannot be righted, it leads to coughing; this is also damp-related cough. Kidney energy issues with a distended abdomen and swollen legs, along with heavy wheezing, reflect dampness-related cough. In cases of spleen obstruction, there is lethargy in the limbs and a cough that brings up fluids, leading to great cold; this is a cold-related cough. The six types of cough can indeed be distinguished based on their respective characteristics.[40p]
The cough driven by wind lacks moderation day and night, causing sweating and headaches, with phlegm and saliva not flowing easily; isn’t this a wind cough? The cough driven by heat has rapid breathing and coughing, a flushed face with tidal heat, cold hands and feet, and often involves the breasts; isn’t this a heat cough? The cough driven by fire results in coughing and breathlessness with congestion, nasal discharge and spitting of blood, and in severe cases, blood pours from the seven orifices; isn’t this a fire cough? The cough driven by dryness leads to obstructed breathing, pain throughout the joints, sweating from the head and face, alternating cold and heat, dry and cracked skin, fine sores that itch, constipation and thick, sticky nasal discharge; isn’t this a dry cough? The cough driven by cold may result from exposure to cold, drinking cold beverages, sitting or lying on wet ground in winter, or exposure to cold wind; experiencing cough and rapid breathing in autumn or winter’s water; isn’t this a cold cough? As for treatment, for a wind cough, use Tongsheng San with Banxia and Ren Shen, or Banxia Wan; in severe cases, induce sweating. For a heat cough, use Baihu Tang, Xixin San, or Liangge San with a spoonful of honey mixed in to drink. For a fire cough, use Huanglian Jiedu Tang, Xixin San, or Sanhuang Wan, and in severe cases, add a strong purgative. For a damp cough, use Wuling San, Guiling Ganlu San, or Baizhu Wan, and in severe cases, use Sanhua Shenyuan Wan to purge. For a dry cough, use Mukxiang Tingli San, Dahuang Huanglian Ejiao Wan, and in severe cases, apply a strong cold purgative.[41p]
For a cough caused by cold, it is treated with calming herbal powders for the mind and lungs; if there is cold phlegm in the upper part, one can use the gourd seed powder to dispel it. Although this method is nearly perfect, considerations must be made according to the individual's age, strength, condition, and body type. Illnesses can have different manifestations, and our prescriptions must also adapt accordingly. However, toxic substances like alum, dried ginger, black plums, and poppy husks can cause significant harm. Alas! I have seen many who have coughed since childhood, suffering into old age without recovery, yet they do not die. Conversely, there are many young people, regardless of gender, who perish within months from a cough. Surely, those who took the calming herbal powders for the mind and lungs must have included such afflicted individuals? Those who do not recover and die are not suffering from a cold-induced cough but instead cling to ineffective remedies like winter flowers and Buddha's ears, leading them to death without change. During the Cao-Wei period, a military officer named Li Cheng suffered intensely from coughing, unable to sleep day or night, sometimes coughing up blood and pus. Hua Tuo believed it did not originate from the lungs and administered a bitter concoction, leading to a substantial expulsion of pus and blood, resulting in recovery. Such cases of cough should not be overlooked.[42p]
Wealthy and noble individuals often suffer from coughs due to thick phlegm caused by rich and greasy foods. First, use the unique holy powder to induce vomiting; once that is done, they may take ginseng powder or Tongsheng powder with half-summer for relief. Additionally, take the large ginseng and half-summer pill to resolve phlegm. It is highly advised to avoid sour, salty, oily, greasy, hard, hot foods.

For those who are poor and suffer from coughs, it is often due to internal and external factors such as wind, cold, and dampness. The Inner Canon states: "In autumn, one suffers from dampness; in winter, coughs arise." It is beneficial to take calming formulas or lung soothing powders with ingredients like Atractylodes. The same restrictions apply.

For men who are ill—pale, hot-bodied, and emaciated, with fluctuating chills and fever resembling malaria, compounded by incessant coughing—some may experience facial swelling, body warmth, or spontaneous sweating. The Inner Canon notes this as a case of cold damage accompanied by fatigue. How should it be treated? If the illness is superficial, the higher regions can be addressed using the Fangji powder to induce vomiting. After vomiting, it is essential to take a dose of Tongjie pill, followed by ginseng and astragalus powder, Danggui Decoction, or modified Xiao Chai Hu Decoction, selecting one as appropriate. The Inner Canon states that the treatment methods for both men and women are the same; by following these guidelines, successful outcomes can invariably be achieved.[43p]
Discussion on Coughing Caused by Autumn Dampness

Autumn is characterized by clear and crisp air, which leads to the gathering and descending energies of the body. When harmed by dampness, this is due to the lingering heat of late summer, which does not align with the principles of autumn. When the autumn vibe is insufficient, excess actions prevail, allowing fire to ascend and dominate metal. Since heart fire afflicts the lungs, lung Qi rebels, resulting in coughing. Those who cannot withstand this are disrespected; wood energy ascends, aligning with fire’s nature, causing continuous motion. Those born under this condition suffer illness, resulting in the depletion of kidney water. With prolonged excess of late summer, the energies of the triple burner become vigorous. The Mingmen (Gate of Life) is the convergence of the triple burner. Hence, kidney water is forced upwards and mingles with the damp heat of the spleen, creating phlegm, which leads to coughing with sound and sputum. If coughing does not occur in autumn but manifests in winter, it is due to the extreme of six Yin energies, and the air becomes conducive to harm, thus resulting in coughing in winter instead of autumn. Coughing represents the reversal and ascent of Qi. When Qi rises in rebellion, the face may swell slightly; if it intensifies, the entire body may swell, transforming into water retention. Therefore, it is said that when turbid Qi is present above, it causes distention. Moreover, it is stated that all depressive Qi belongs to lung metal.[44p]
This is what it refers to. Spring is harmed by the wind, summer is harmed by the heat, winter is harmed by the cold; the reasoning for these is smooth and coherent, and the term "time" harms the term "order." Only autumn is harmed by dampness, causing the term "order" to wound the term "time," which readers do not doubt. These four instances have no excess and harm what they accompany. The evil comes later; the main qi of the year each misassigns its share, causing illness, which is a certain principle. If it is said that the term for autumn harms the term for dampness, its wording connects with the previous three sentences, but its reasoning and principles do not connect. Generally speaking, reasoning and principles are coherent and need not be bound by wording. Therefore, those who interpret poetry do not let wording harm meaning, nor let meaning harm intent, and thus they grasp its essence. Hence, it is said: "Spring is harmed by the wind," which implies human capability is harmed by the wind, but that's not the case. If so, one would only suffer headaches from strong winds; how then could it be said that summer brings diarrhea? Now, saying "spring is harmed by the wind" clearly indicates time harms order. The classics state: "The eastern winds bring infantile wind; they harm people externally in the muscles, but internally they reside in the liver." It is also said: "In spring, the damage from Jia and Yi is called liver wind." Using these two sentences for comparison with the earlier text allows the reasoning to connect logically.

Discussion on the harm caused by dampness.[45p]
In the Suwen, the chapter on the transmission of life energy states: In autumn, one is harmed by dampness, which causes an upward reversal leading to cough and results in weakness and numbness. The Great Treatise on Yin and Yang Correspondence states: Being harmed by dampness in autumn leads to coughing in winter. Once autumn dampness prevails and winter moisture increases, the dampness and moisture interact, causing lung energy to weaken, which then manifests as coughing. The resultant weakness and numbness occurs because the internal dampness attacks the organs, resulting in upward coughing, while the external dispersal affects the tendons and leads to weakness. During autumn, the dampness is pervasive; being harmed by dampness during this season is a disruption of the long summer energy and its alignment with autumn. When autumn energy is insufficient, it falters and allows fire to rise and overcome metal. Since heart fire penalizes the lungs, lung energy reverses, leading to cough. What cannot be overcome is insulted, as wood energy ascends, sharing attributes with fire, causing continuous movement. Those affected suffer illness, leading to kidney water deficiency. With the long summer having reached excess, the energy of the Triple Burner is strong. The Mengmen, or life gate, is the convergence of the Triple Burner. Hence, the forced ascent of kidney water combines with the damp heat of the spleen soil to form phlegm, which, in turn, causes coughing with sound and phlegm. Coughing that does not arise in autumn but in winter is due to the extreme of six yin, where the onset of contraction begins to take effect. Thus, being harmed by autumn dampness results in upward coughing, leading to weakness and numbness.[46p]
The root of illness is the same as that of the spring wind, summer heat, and winter cold; however, their influences vary with the seasons. Each of these three corresponds to its own season's characteristics. Dampness is the characteristic of late summer, but what of autumn? Each season—spring, summer, and winter—has its own three months, so their influences operate within their respective periods. However, late summer's influence is primarily concentrated in the month of June. Although autumn also has its three months, the dampness from late summer often extends into autumn, which is why it is said that autumn is harmed by dampness. Regarding the notion that autumn is harmed by dampness, the principles governing its seasonal influence have been discussed previously. In the earlier section, it mentioned conditions such as cough due to counterflow, leading to paralysis and numbness, without specifying a delay in timing, suggesting that these arise immediately. But since it was mentioned alongside wind, heat, and cold, could this be solely interpreted as an immediate reaction?[47p]
However, although there is no clear text, I dare not compare it with the later chapters, and thus I decisively conclude that winter is the season for the onset of disease. Nevertheless, dampness is fundamentally a consequence of late summer, which encroaches upon autumn; even if it arises, it is indeed late in coming. This should only be discussed in relation to the diseases that manifest in autumn. Dampness originates from below, thus causing the lungs to dry, which leads to coughing, referred to as upward rebellion. The lungs are the master of all qi, so if there is already an illness, the qi cannot circulate outward, and dampness stagnates in the meridians, causing the limbs to become weak and powerless, and sometimes even cold and pale. The later chapter's mention of winter cough, already stating that it arrives late, indeed differs significantly from the meaning in the earlier chapter. When dampness lingers and does not disperse, and as winter's cold qi rises prominently, the lungs detest the cold and may be harmed, thus allowing the dampness to invade the lungs and manifest as coughing. Can one glean this intent and discern its significance from the texts?[48p]
Methods of Medicinal Use

The "Nan Jing" states: When the lung is excessively active, external symptoms include a pale face and frequent sneezing, with feelings of sorrow and an inclination to cry. Internally, there are symptoms of wheezing, coughing, and reversal of qi, along with vexation, chest fullness, and heat. At night, there is excessive nasal discharge and frequent sneezing, with nasal blockage. The lung is greatly filled with metal (qi), supporting the mother (lung function). The heart, spleen, and lungs all suffer from cold evil, resulting in sweet saliva; water assaults earth, causing fear. The abdomen is greatly cold, and this condition is called "cold in the middle." White phlegm forms bubbles; when lung qi is weak, it results in extreme cold, thus supporting the mother. One should expel kidney water from the lungs; it can only be resolved with pungent and warm medicine. If the mouth produces sweet saliva, it indicates stomach coldness and disharmony; thus, it should be dealt with using pungent, sweet, and warm remedies. Those who drink alcohol often experience this reverse transformation.

In the "Suwen," regarding eleven types of cough: Liver cough is treated with Xiao Chai Hu Decoction; bile vomiting from the gallbladder is treated with Huang Qin plus Ban Xia and Sheng Jiang Decoction. Heart cough is treated with Jie Geng Decoction; small intestine qi deficiency requires Shao Yao and Gan Cao Decoction. Spleen cough can be treated with Sheng Ma Decoction; stomach expelling long parasites requires Wu Mei Pill. Lung cough is treated with Ma Huang Decoction; large intestine urinary leakage requires Chi Shi Zhi Yu Yu Liang Decoction or Tao Ren Decoction, and if it does not stop, use Zhu Ling Decoction to resolve water. Kidney cough is treated with Fu Zi and Xi Xin Decoction; bladder urinary leakage requires Fu Ling and Gan Cao Decoction.
