He Li Le San treats cough.

For the clove-scented He Li Le, roast thoroughly, remove the core, and grind it into powder. Use two qian of this powder, along with one piece of pork (or swine) belly—remove the fat and split it open. Add the medicine inside, mix with one broken piece of black plum, wrap with banana leaves, and cover with thick rice paper. Roast until fragrant, then remove the paper, leaves, and plum, keeping only the medicine and pork. Chew slowly and take three times a day.

Ping Wei Tang treats phlegmatic cough.

Use three taels of fine pork, cut into three thin slices. Use three inches of soapwort, soak it in water, then wring it out and mix two qian of greasy powder in with the meat. Wrap in wet paper and stew until soft by dawn. Chew it with mild fresh ginger soup or decoction of mulberry bark for relief. In the afternoon, expectoration occurs, which is the root of the illness.[171p]
Prescription for Coughing

To treat coughing:

  • Take 2 jin of Pinellia (Banxia), wash it in river water seven times.
  • Use 1 jin of alum, 4 liang each of cardamom, bulbus of Cimicifuga (Shengma), Amomum fruit (Suanshi), clove bark, and licorice.
  • Add 1 bottle of liquor and 15 slices of ginger.

Method:
Wash the Pinellia to remove its slippery coating. Roast the other ingredients until dry and grind them coarsely. Place the ginger slices and all the herbs with the Pinellia in a large mouth bottle, soaking them in liquor for 7 days in spring and summer, or 1 month in autumn and winter. Afterward, wash and dry the Pinellia, and do not use the other herbs. Take 2 to 3 pieces each time, without regard to timing.

Cough Remedy Song

The song goes: One liang of clear oil, two liang of honey, natural juice of Pinellia and ginger. Add Aster, Ephedra, and apricot kernels, along with dried stem of Xixin, and cook down until it is as black as lacquer. Take three liang before bed, and by morning, the cough will leave without a trace.

Qingzhou White Pills for Coughing

Preparation:

  • Soak a large amount of Pinellia in water seven times.
  • Clean and lightly roast 1 jin of Fuzi, along with Tianma and Chuanwu (slightly roasted and peeled).
  • Wash and lightly roast Nanshan as well as whole scorpions in equal parts.

Grind everything into a fine powder, mix with natural ginger juice, and boil into a dough-like consistency to form pills the size of a wutong seed.

Dosage: Take 10 to 20 pills after meals, with tea or warm water. If experiencing paralysis from wind, take with warm liquor, three doses daily. Regular use ensures freedom from wind phlegm and blockage. For children with convulsions, take 2 pills, dissolved in mint tea.[172p]

    Sheep Lung Soup
    Used for cough with persistent day and night symptoms, feeling of suffocation, and lung damage causing blood in sputum.
    Ingredients:
  • Six taels of calcined oyster, cassia heart, and fresh ginger
  • Five taels each of pinellia, rhizoma zhongru, powdered white quartz, five-flavored fruit, hundred部 root, fritillaria bulb, orange peel, and peeled peach kernel
  • Three taels each of magnolia bark, winter flower, and honey-fried licorice
  • One whole sheep lung, chopped

Preparation:
First, take the sheep lung and use one dou and three sheng of water to boil until it reduces to one dou. Remove the lung and add all the other ingredients, then boil again to reduce to three sheng, divided into four doses, taken three times a day and once at night. Avoid seaweed, mustard greens, sheep meat, and raw scallions.

Cough Clinic

Formula
Sang Bai Pi Decoction
Used for cough lasting for years that does not heal, with breathlessness and blood in sputum due to lung damage.
Ingredients:

  • Five he of mulberry white bark
  • Six taels each of ophiopogon, bitter apricot (blanched), and winter flower
  • Twelve fen each of poria, fritillaria bulb, cimicifuga, and scutellaria
  • Eight fen of peony and one whole white sheep lung, cut
  • One sheng each of honey and fresh rehmannia juice

Preparation:
Chop the ingredients, add one dou of water, and boil to yield three sheng. Strain out the dregs, then add the blanched apricot fat, rehmannia juice, and honey. Simmer on low heat until it boils like fish eyes, stirring continuously. Reduce to two sheng and filter through fine cloth. Take one he after each meal, three to four times a day. Adjust the dosage for the old and young as needed. Avoid raw, cold foods like oil, vinegar, fish, garlic, and wild mustard.[175p]
Lou Tang for Long-lasting Cough Relief:

  • One piece of Lou, remove the pulp, add one spoonful of clam powder, and stir-fry until yellow. Also stir-fry Aristolochia, Stephania, Kudzu root, remove shells from apricot kernels, stir-fry Glycyrrhiza, remove the heart from Fritillaria, and shred Ejiao. Combine with two handfuls of glutinous rice, stir-fry together, then separate the rice. Each ingredient should be two taels. Grind everything into fine powder. Each dose is three qian, with one cup of water, add half a spoon of honey, boil until seven parts are reduced, strain, and take warm at any time, three times a day and once at night.

Apricot Kernel Paste for Cough, Wheezing, and Blood in Saliva:

  • Two taels of apricot kernels soaked in soup, remove the shells and double kernels, stir-fry until slightly yellow, then grind into a paste. Three taels of lard, half a liter of white honey, two taels of Ejiao, crushed and stir-fried until yellow into powder. One cup of fresh ginger juice, two taels of Perilla seeds, stir-fried lightly and ground into paste. Mix these six ingredients in a silver pot, and simmer on low heat until it becomes a paste. Each dose is one spoonful at any time, diluted with warm congee, taken four to five times a day.

Flower Powder: Treats chronic coughs due to cold and heat from lung deficiency. Note: Use winter flowers as needed.[178p]
In a密室 (secret chamber), like burning incense, smoke rises and can be drawn in through a pen tube to swallow it. Or, when burning incense in a sitting or lying position, it is effective even without inhaling. Those who have been ill for several days see improvements, lighter cases recover quickly. For a dry mouth and throat, use tea to wash it down.

Moreover, it is sung: "For years of coughing, hard to treat, avoid foolish doctors, don’t waste your money; finely crush winter flowers into powder, burn the smoke, and inhale it down your throat."

San Qi San treats all types of cough, regardless of duration, for those who wheeze without pause, day and night without respite.

  • Winter flowers: 200 wen
  • Buddha's ear grass: 50 wen
  • Rehmannia root: 2 taels

Dry roast the above, grind it into powder. Use 2 large coins, place a strong fire in a censer to burn it, make a paper tube, one end large and one end small, shaped like a zongzi, and rest it on the censer. Inhale the smoke until it is exhausted, then wash it down with clear tea, producing saliva.

In "Experiential Formulas," Chen's family says: I have a servant who suffered from this ailment for a long time; medical treatments were as ineffective as water on stone. By chance, I acquired a maid from Yuan Prefecture at Qujiang, who newly prepared this medicine; after two doses, he was cured.

Xiao Qinglong Jia Shigao Decoction treats lung congestion, cough with shortness of breath, irritability, and wheezing, with a floating pulse and water in the heart area.

  • Ma Huang (Ephedra) 90 grams
  • Shao Yao (Peony) 90 grams

  • Xi Xin (Asarum) 90 grams
  • Gan Cao (Licorice) 90 grams
  • Gan Jiang (Dried ginger) 90 grams
  • Wu Wei Zi (Schisandra) 60 ml
  • Ban Xia (Pinellia) 60 ml

Preparation:
Combine these nine ingredients with ten dongs of water. First, boil Ma Huang, skim off the foam, then add the other herbs and boil down to three liters. A strong person should take one liter, while a weak person should take less. Take three times a day. For children, take four doses.

Zhi Sou San treats the previous conditions.

Ingredients:

  • 75 grams Ban Xia, rinsed seven times
  • 240 grams of dried white alum

Preparation:
Grind these two ingredients into a powder and mix with ginger to form dough-sized pills. Each dose is three to twenty pills, taken on an empty stomach with warm wine.

San Cai Wan treats cough.[180p]
**Ginseng, Asparagus, and Cooked Dried Rehmannia in equal parts. Prepare as a fine powder, make into pills the size of cherries, and dissolve in the mouth to take.

Qiongyu Paste (From "Medical Genuine Transmission")
For treating deficiency, fatigue, and dry cough:
Twelve ounces of ginseng, fifteen ounces of poria, five pounds of white honey (boil to remove foam), ten pounds of fresh Rehmannia, washed clean, crushed in a stone container to extract natural juice, avoiding iron utensils; five taels each of agarwood and amber.
Grind the ginseng, poria, agarwood, and amber into fine powder. First, mix the Rehmannia juice with white honey, strain it through fine silk to remove residues, then mix in the powdered medicine. Place in a suitable ceramic or silver bottle, cover with several layers of cotton paper, wrapped with reed leaves, seal the bottle mouth, and submerge in a sand pot or copper pot, using steady water to submerge the bottle neck, boil with soft fire for three days and nights. Remove, replace with wax paper several times, seal the bottle mouth, submerge in a well for half a day to remove fire poisons, then bring up, and again boil in the original pot for half a day to expel moisture, then store. Every morning and after noon, take one or two spoonfuls, adjusting with a cup of warm wine. For those who do not drink alcohol, clear broth is also acceptable.**[181p]

Zhongru Qixing San, also known as Xisan, is used to treat cold cough, difficult breathing, chest fullness, and expectoration of pus and blood.

Qixing San is also said to treat cough lasting thirty years.

Ingredients: Winter flower, purple aster fluff, white mulberry root bark, daizhe stone, xixin, and fulong liver, each one tael.

Mix the six ingredients to form seven-star clusters, similar to flat beans. Use a bamboo tube to inhale each cluster directly above the medicine, allowing it to enter the stomach. Take it three times a day before meals. After four days, reform the seven-star clusters using a piece of roasted meat to coat and fully absorb the medicine. Chew it thoroughly while lying on your back to ensure full absorption of the medicinal properties, swallowing the juice carefully. If healing has not occurred, repeat the procedure as initially done. Goat, beef, and deer meat can be used, but pork is not recommended.[195p]

Gypsum Powder: For treating severe coughing and asthma due to heat.

  • One liang of gypsum, half a liang of honey-fried licorice.
    Grind these into a powder. Take three qian each time with fresh spring water, or mix with ginger juice and honey.

Great Baillou Powder: For all kinds of cough due to labor, muscle weakness, difficulty breathing at rest, and inability to eat phlegm.

  • A pair of gecko, honey-fried; one turtle shell, skins removed and honey-fried; honey-fried licorice; ginseng; bupleurum; dried ginger; white poria; white atractylodes; fennel; green tangerine peel; blanched almonds; anemarrhena; fritillaria; dried orange peel; cinnamon; aconite; fresh pinellia; soaked in caustic poria, each one liang; five qian each of sonneratia and gentian.
    Grind these into a powder. Take two qian each time with a cup of water, using three slices of fresh ginger, two dates, and two black plums, boiled together and taken warm on an empty stomach. If sweating occurs, add twenty grains of wheat, avoiding iron utensils.

Minor Baillou Powder: For continuous labor-induced cough and spontaneous sweating.

  • The hulls of imperial rice, roasted without restriction of quantity.
    Grind into a powder. Take two qian with black plum boiled in a cup of water and drink warm after meals. If sweating occurs, add thirty grains of wheat, boiled together and taken warm.

Reed Tube Powder: For all men and women with coughing and rapid breathing.

  • Equal parts of winter flower, spring water stone, goose pipe stone, stalactite stone, cinnamon, licorice, white alum, and Buddha ear herb.
    Grind these into a powder. Take one qian each time, sucking through a bamboo tube, three times a day for immediate effect.[201p]
    Sacred Poppy Powder: Treats men and women with persistent cough that does not stop day or night. Ingredients: One tael of rice husks, honey-fried black plum flesh, ginseng, myrobalan fruit, radish seeds, each five qian; mulberry white bark. Grind these into a fine powder. Take two to three qian for each dose, and mix with boiling soup before bed.

Water-Boiled Golden Pill: Treats cough with wind, phlegm, and heat. Symptoms include a wiry pulse, a pale face, fullness and heaviness in the limbs, urinary issues, and irritability. Ingredients: One tael each of South Star, fresh pinellia tuber; calcined cold water stone; half a tael of Tianma; two qian of realgar; three taels of white flour. Grind into a fine powder, mix with water to form pills. Take fifty to seventy pills, up to a hundred. Boil the medicinal formula in water until it floats, strain, soak in light broth, and take with fresh ginger soup. Alternatively, combine with Banxia and use the prescriptions for Chuanxiong Wan or Fangfeng Wan as needed.

Small Yellow Pill: Treats cough with hot phlegm. Symptoms include a rapid pulse, red face, irritability, heart pain, dry lips and mouth, and excessive laughter. Ingredients: One tael each of South Star and fresh pinellia tuber, and one and a half taels of Scutellaria. Grind into a fine powder, soak in ginger juice, steam into pills about the size of a tung seed. Take fifty to seventy pills after meals, with ginger soup. It is also acceptable to add to Xiaochaihu Decoction with Banxia.[202p]
Bai Zhu Pills treat phlegm and damp coughs, with a slow pulse, yellowish face, heavy limbs, a tendency to sleep, lack of fluid retention, abdominal distension, and indigestion; they are suitable for these symptoms. Ingredients: Nan Xing and Ban Xia, each one liang; Bai Zhu, one and a half liang. Grind to a fine powder, mix into a paste to form pills the size of tung seeds. Take 50 to 70 pills with ginger soup. The Fangji Pills in "Jumai Prescription" can also be used.

Yu Fen Pills treat qi phlegm coughs, with a thin pulse, pale face, shortness of breath, chills, unhappiness, and are suitable for these conditions. Ingredients: Nan Xing, Chen Ju Pi, and Ban Xia, each one liang. Grind to a fine powder, mix into a thin paste to form pills the size of tung seeds. Take 50 to 70 pills with ginger soup after meals. The Fangji Pills in "Jumai Prescription" can also be used. Adjustments for Yu Fen Pills: if there is a feeling of fullness below the heart, add five qian of Zhi Shi; if there is significant body heat, add five qian of Huang Lian; if the body feels heavy, add one liang of Fu Ling; if qi rises abnormally, add five qian of Ku Tsing Li; if shortness of breath occurs, add five qian each of Ren Shen and Jie Geng; for edema, add five qian each of Li Ren and Xing Ren; for constipation, add five qian of Da Huang; for cold phlegm, remove the tangerine peel and add Guo Gui.[203p]
Fangfeng Pill: This treats phlegm cough and unclear Qi in the chest. The Zhizhu Pill is also effective. Ingredients: Fangfeng and Zhike, each with the core removed, stir-fried, both five qian; Baizhu, one liang. Grind these into a fine powder, make into pills with steamed dough, and take 50 to 70 pills each time, washed down with ginger soup.

Wuwu Huangqi Powder (from "Bacui Fang"): This treats cough, excessive phlegm with blood, eye pain, limb fatigue, and weakness in the knees and feet. Ingredients: Maidong and Shudi, each one qian; Zhiqiao and Huangqi, each half qian; Wuweizi, Renshen, Shaoyao, and Gancao, each five fen. Prepare as a single dose, boil with two bowls of water until reduced to one bowl, and take warm after meals.

San Sheng Dan (from "Zheng Chuan"): This is extremely effective for chronic cough. Ingredients: Tian Nansheng, baked and cracked, one liang; Dabanxia, soaked in decoction seven times, two liang; Gancao, five qian. First, grind Tian Nansheng and Dabanxia into a fine powder, mix with the natural juice of fresh ginger, shape into pieces and leave for seven days in spring and autumn, ten days in winter, and five days in summer. Then grind again with Gancao into a fine powder. Take one bowl of thin bamboo juice, mix the earlier powder with bamboo juice, shape into cakes, and dry them. Additionally, wet with bamboo juice and dry again. Repeat this wetting and drying process ten times until no bamboo juice remains, then grind into fine powder. Use white sand honey, taking one spoonful before bed, letting it dissolve in the mouth, and rinse with bamboo juice before swallowing.[204p]

Xingren Decoction
Treats all coughs.
Half a pound of apricot kernels, remove the skin and tip. Soak in the right child's urine, changing it once a day; in summer, change it three times a day. Soak for half a month, rinse, dry, and grind into a very fine powder. Take a dose the size of a jujube, mix with mint tea sweetened with honey, take after meals; several doses will cure completely.

Shuang Yu Powder (from "Yi Lao")
Treats phlegm-heat with cough, wheezing, and phlegm.

Here is the translated text:

The above is a fine powder; take three qian each time, decoct with ginseng and drink it after meals when going to bed.

Great Restoration Decoction: This treats serious conditions in men and women due to severe blood and qi deficiency, loss of spirit, dangerous coughing, etc.
Ginseng, a little as two or three qian, or more as one or two liang.
Goji berries, two or three qian.
Cooked rehmannia, a little as two or three qian, or more as two or three liang.
Honey-fried licorice, one or two qian.
Angelica, two or three qian (do not use in cases of diarrhea).
Cornelian cherry, one qian (avoid if sensitive to acidity).
Eucommia and processed Chinese yam, each two qian.
Add two sheng of water, decoct to seven parts, and take warm after meals.

Left Return Decoction: This is a tonic for water. For those with weakened Yin of the Mingmen and excess Yang who cough, this formula with adjustments is suitable.
Cooked rehmannia, two or three qian, or increased to one or two liang.
Honey-fried licorice, one qian.
Cornelian cherry, one or two qian (reduce if sensitive to acidity).
Poria, one and a half qian.
Chinese yam and goji berries, each two qian.
Add two sheng of water, decoct to seven parts, and take warm away from meals.

Right Return Decoction: This is a tonic for fire. For those with weakened Yang of the Mingmen and excess Yin who cough, this formula with adjustments is suitable.
Cooked rehmannia as before, with processed Chinese yam, eucommia prepared with ginger, and goji berries, each two qian.
Cornelian cherry flesh, one qian.
Honey-fried licorice and cinnamon, each one or two qian.
Processed Aconite, one to three qian.
Add two sheng of water, decoct to seven parts, and take warm away from meals.[213p]
Zuǒ Guī Wán treats insufficiency of true yin and kidney water, which cannot nourish the defensive and nutrient aspects, gradually leading to weakness and coughing. It is advisable to strengthen the governing water to nurture the primordial yin of the left kidney, thereby replenishing essence and blood. This formula is appropriate for that purpose.

Ingredients:

  • 8 taels of cooked rehmannia
  • 4 taels each of stir-fried yam, goji berries, mountain blackthorn fruit, processed dodder seed, and fried deer horn gelatin pearls
  • 3 taels of good-quality ox knee, washed and steamed with liquor, avoiding excessive fine texture
  • 4 taels of turtle shell gelatin, cut into small pieces and fried into pearls, avoiding those without fire.

Method: Steam the cooked rehmannia until softened and pound it into a paste. Mix and form into pills the size of a tung seed with refined honey, taking 100 pills before meals with boiling soup or light salt soup. If there is heat affecting the lungs, add 3 taels of lily.

Yòu Guī Wán treats insufficient primal qi, whether due to congenital weakness or excessive labor injury, leading to a decline of the fire at the life gate, which cannot generate earth, resulting in spleen and stomach deficiency with coldness, fatigue, anxiety, or symptoms such as palpitations, unretracted limbs, seeing evil spirits, declining vitality with infertility, coughing, etc. It is essential to quickly enhance the source of fire to nourish the primordial yang of the right kidney, thus strengthening the vitality and spirit. This formula is suitable for such conditions.

Ingredients:

  • 8 taels of cooked rehmannia
  • 2 taels of processed aconite, gradually increasing to 5-6 taels
  • 2 taels of cinnamon, gradually increasing to 4 taels
  • Do not use processed angelica in excess
  • 3 taels each of stir-fried mountain blackthorn fruit, stir-fried yam, lightly stir-fried goji berries, processed dodder seed, fried deer antler gelatin pearls, and stir-fried eucommia with ginger juice.

Method: The method for preparing pills is as before, or form into size of small pellets. Chew and take 2-3 pills with boiling white soup for quicker effect.[214p]
Wufu Decoction
For those with deficiency of the five organs, who suffer from cough due to loss, this can treat them.

Yin Decoction
This treats water deficiency and excessive fire, hence the name "One Yin." For cases where the kidney's true Yin is deficient, leading to abundant Yang signs, heat from empty fire, and symptoms like cough with phlegm due to Yin deficiency, this should be used with appropriate adjustments.

  • Two qian each of raw Rehmannia, Peony, Ophiopogon, and Salvia
  • One qian of Licorice
  • Three to five qian of cooked Rehmannia
  • One and a half qian of Achyranthes

Jin Shui Liu Jun Decoction: This treats lung and kidney deficiency cold, with water accumulating as phlegm, or elderly patients with Yin deficiency and insufficient blood and qi, externally attacked by wind-cold, presenting symptoms of cough, nausea, excessive phlegm, and acute wheezing. Liu'an Pills treat coughs caused by wind-cold, as well as initial symptoms of wind invasion, phlegm stagnation, and reversed qi.

Ingredients:

  • Half a qian of dried citrus peel
  • Two to three qian of pinellia
  • One qian of apricot kernels
  • One qian of licorice
  • Five to seven fen of white mustard seed (not to be used by the old and weak)
  • Two qian of poria
  • One and a half zhōng of water, adding three to five or seven slices of fresh ginger, and decocting for seven parts. Take on an empty stomach.

For coughs caused by external wind with significant cold, it is often difficult to disperse; add seven to eight fen or one qian of northern xixin. If the cough persists due to wind and is accompanied by lung and stomach fire, add one to two qian of scutellaria. In severe cases, add Zhimu and gypsum, using only one slice of fresh ginger. For coughs with cold evil and ineffective phlegm, add two to three qian of angelica, especially suitable for the elderly. If there is a deficiency of qi and blood, it is advisable to use Jinsuijun decoction alongside this.

Baimu Pills clear phlegm, alleviate heat, moisten the lungs, and stop coughing.

Ingredients:

  • One liang of fritillaria

Grind the above into powder, mix with sand sugar or honey, and form pills the size of longan, which may be dissolved in the mouth or chewed. If one wishes to stop a lingering cough, for every liang of fritillaria, it is advisable to add one qian each of Baoyaosuan, selaginella, and turmeric, which is particularly effective. If Baoyaosuan is unavailable, one qian of vinegar-fried clams can also be used, or corn husks may be used as needed.[217p]
Chai Chen Jian: Treats symptoms of wind-cold, cough with fever, feelings of fullness with phlegm, etc.

Ingredients:

  • Chai Hu (Bupleurum) 2-3 qian

  • Fu Ling (Poria) 2 qian

Liu Wei Hui Yang Yin: According to the "Complete Book of Jingyue," this formula should contain processed Fu Zi. It treats symptoms of impending collapse of yin and yang, cough, and wheezing.

Ingredients:

  • Ren Shen (Ginseng) 1-2 liang or several qian
  • Shu Di Huang (Cooked Rehmannia) 5 qian or 1 liang
  • Pao Gan Jiang (Processed Dried Ginger) 2-3 qian
  • Dang Gui Shen (Angelica Root) 3 qian, for diarrhea or blood motion, substitute with Dong Zhong (Winter Worm)
  • Zhi Gan Cao (Prepared Licorice) 1 qian

Prepare with 2 sheng of water, and boil over medium heat to reduce to 7 portions; take warm.

Cough Section

Single Prescription

For sudden violent cough: Use 1 liang of white clay powder and alum, grind to powder, mix with ginger juice to form pills the size of a tree nut, and take twenty pills with ginger soup before bed.

For chronic cough: For those with dust from old thatched roofs and smoke exposure, mix Shi Huang (Yellow Ochre), Dong Hua (Winter Flower), and women's menstrual sashes to a powder, water them to apply to the thatched roof, let dry, then burn in a bamboo tube and inhale the smoke—there will be no illness that cannot be cured.[218p]
Sudden cough: Grind lead filings, cassia heart, and soap pods into a fine powder, mix with honey to form balls the size of a phoenix nut. Take fifteen balls with each meter of drink. Avoid green onions.

For cough lasting thirty years: Grind yellow incense, wood fragrance, and datura seeds into a fine powder, apply sheep fat onto blue paper, spread the powder on it, and roll it into a cylinder to inhale the smoke.

Cough treatment method: One ounce of yellow incense, rolled into ten tubes with wax paper to burn and inhale the smoke, take once a day. Only eat plain porridge, and after seven days, supplement with sheep meat soup.

For water retention and cough with abdominal swelling: One ounce of yellow incense, two parts winter flower, one part moxa, spread moxa with wax paper, place two powders of wine on top, roll it into a tube of reed, burn and inhale the smoke for thirty days to recover. Use one dose within three days, and abstain from salt and vinegar for a hundred days.

Persistent cough: Each morning, take winter flower about the size of a chicken egg, mix with a little honey to moisten, put it in an iron pot, and use a ceramic basin drilled with a small hole to set a small straw inside, sealing it with flour paste, to avoid cold air leakage. There are many remedies for cough, but I have a very simple one: take a preserved citron, remove the seeds, and slice into thin pieces. Place in a sand jar with some wine, boil until soft, and from dusk to dawn, use honey to mix well. Awaken the person from sleep and have them take it with a spoon; it is very effective.

In addition, a certain scholar from Yuet Province reported: In childhood I suffered from a severe cough that no medicines could cure. Someone advised using a bundle of soft mulberry branches facing south, breaking each branch into one-inch pieces, placing them in a pot with about five bowls of water, and simmering until reduced to one bowl. Drink during hot weather when thirsty; continue this for a month and it will be cured.

Acupuncture

The "Suwen" states: Lung illnesses involve coughing, wheezing, shortness of breath, pain in shoulders and back, sweating, and pain in the lower body including buttocks, thighs, knees, and feet. Kidney illnesses involve abdominal distension, swelling of the shins, wheezing, coughing, heaviness of the body, night sweating, and aversion to wind. In lung heat illness, heat leads to coughing and wheezing, chest pain, inability to sigh deeply, severe headaches, and sweating with chills. In severe cases, excessive sweating can be fatal. If qi reverses, it can lead to death. Needle the hand taiyin and yangming points until blood flows like large beans, then stop immediately.

If an evil is lodged in the foot shaoyang channel, it can cause pain in the ribs, inability to breathe, cough with sweating; needle each side of the toenail of the little and next toes, and pain will cease immediately, and sweating will stop. For coughs, wear warm clothing and manage diet; after one day, if symptoms persist, needle the opposite side, and continue needling until the illness resolves.

Needling through the lung can lead to death within three days if excessive motion occurs, resulting in coughing.[244p]

  • The puncture in the chest cavity allows the flow of qi to escape, causing shortness of breath and coughing.

  • Puncturing the area below the ribs leads to coughing.

  • The "Spiritual Pivot" states: if the pathogenic factor is in the lungs, one experiences skin pain, chills and fever, shortness of breath, sweating, and cough that affects the shoulders and back. Treat it by pressing the points outside the chest, along the back’s three segments beside the five organs, applying quick pressure with the hand until relief is felt, then puncturing in the chest cavity for further effect.

Guidance:
Movement: There are three types of this condition: either due to wind-cold causing coughing, or due to heart fire erratically moving and inflaming the lung passages. The method of returning to the origin and concentrating the spirit should be used to seal and secure; fire should not rise, the lung passages should not itch, and the coughing will naturally cease. For cold cough, especially practice a slight closing method. For fire cough, just stop and seal, seeking tranquility; then draw water from the kidneys to irrigate the lung fire, circulating it, and the lungs will receive moisture, causing the cough to naturally stop. Open the chest to clear the lung meridian, washing down through the lung meridian to the large intestine's nine curves, guiding it toward the valley path.

For cough caused by wind-cold and dampness, the external method involves making a fist and applying it at the shoulder’s edge, rubbing it down to the back and the kidney locations; self-warmth can dispel it.

Cough due to food accumulation requires an external method of rubbing the navel region, allowing food to gradually descend. It is necessary to be relaxed and have the diaphragm flat, allowing Qi to go down, which will lead to recovery.

For cough arising from deficient heat movements, one must swallow saliva, draw it down to the lower dantian, speak less, and avoid anger; this will lead to recovery.

Cough caused by shouting after drinking is difficult to treat and may lead to consumptive illness.[255p]
The "Secret Instructions of the Stone Chamber" states: The lungs, representing the metal element, are delicate organs that cannot contain foreign substances; however, they can still contain air. If a person has a persistent cough that does not improve despite taking various lung-nourishing medicines, unless air enters through the throat, the lungs will remain difficult to heal quickly. The method involves using the breath of a thirteen-year-old girl, who exhales her breath into the patient's mouth. Every day at the fifth watch (around 3-5 AM), the girl should mouth-feed the patient, fully sending her lower abdominal energy into the patient’s mouth. The patient should swallow a mouthful each day, limited to just one, which should be as effective as taking medicine. However, during the exhalation, one must strictly avoid any feelings of desire; any such motion will be not only useless but also harmful. The patient may only have one or two mouthfuls, in consideration of the girl’s health.

The "Essentials of Life Preservation" states: The method for guiding a cough involves sitting down with feet extended. Use the double child-rearing method, applying force to lift up, lower the head, and gradually bend down, using both hands to pull the toes three times. With strength, follow the original method to lift up, and then swallow saliva downwards into the lower abdomen. This bending method should be done twenty-four times, maintaining tranquility and benefiting from the practice.[256p]
Medical Case Studies

The "Rumen Shiqin" states: A man in his twenties had been suffering from a cough for several years, his voice caught but unable to come out. The physician asked: "Have you ever taken medicine?" The man replied: "My family is poor, I have never taken medicine." The physician said: "In youth, those who do not recklessly take medicine are easier to treat." First, he administered a bitter decoction to induce vomiting; next, he used methods akin to transportation and dredged the rivers to promote significant bowel movement, and afterwards, he used a heavy formula, and the patient was indeed cured.

One farmer had a cough, and after an induced discharge and a purge, he was already over half better. He then took a ginseng lung tonic before bed and additionally consumed betel nut pills to stimulate his appetite.

Gao Sanlang from the East Gate had been coughing for a year and a half, with ringing in his ears and coughing up pus and blood for three months. His face was covered in dark spots, his body was hot, and he could not produce sound in his throat. The physician said: "The source of the cough lies in the excess heart fire. It is damaged by dampness in autumn, leading to cough in winter. When winter's water is abundant, it combines with dampness, obstructing the heart, causing the fire not to descend but to rise, scorching the lung’s metal; after prolonged suffering, it results in a cough, and the metal cannot produce sound. Treating with tonics for the lungs and kidneys is not appropriate. I recommend preparing watermelon, ice, and snow materials, using methods to induce discharge, and also taking medicines to eliminate dampness; the illness will improve day by day."[257p]
Yang Shou's wife had been suffering from a cough for more than ten years, with persistent coughing for a day without relief. To stop it, musk soup was administered, yet even at midnight, the coughing persisted. After another dose, she felt somewhat nauseous the following morning, so ginseng soup was given, and after two days, she felt slightly better. After administering medicine on three occasions, the physician advised Luan Jingxian that a long-standing cough has already restrained the illness, and naturally, recovery would be slow. After several days of adjustment, the cough finally ceased. It is often said that after the cough eases, there are those who recover suddenly, and those who recover gradually. There are also cases of internal discomfort where the illness is not yet fully resolved, and cases of returning heat that must be treated without delay. Generally, after three days, a sense of relief is to be expected.

Zhao Junyu's wife had been ill with a cough for ten months. The physician used dried orange peel, angelica, licorice, white atractylodes, bitter orange, and platycodon root. Junyu suspected these were not suitable cough medications. The physician laughed and asked if he was surprised by the absence of black plum or poppy capsules. He explained that a winter cough is caused by the dampness of the autumn, where damp earth reverses and causes coughing. This formula scatters qi, eliminates dampness, relieves urgency, and harmonizes the meridians. After three doses, efficacy was indeed observed.[258p]
In Yan City, Dong Degou suffered from a chronic cough due to labor. A physician advised him that upon recovery, he should refrain from sexual activities. After he recovered, he became complacent and violated the prohibition, leading to his death. After his death, his wife gave birth to a son, which coincided with the day of his recovery. Initially, Dong was quite firm about keeping it a secret; only then did it become known.

A man, aged forty, suffered from a chronic cough, with phlegm that was thick and foul-smelling, unbearable to the nostrils. In autumn and winter, his condition was somewhat relieved, but worsened in spring and summer, characterized by alternating chills and fever, with symptoms manifesting in the afternoons, resembling those of malaria. He sweated excessively while sleeping, like water. He frequently took ephedra root and dried mulberry leaves, yet continued to sweat profusely. He also took calming and lung-soothing powders to no avail. Initially, the physician used a specific powder to induce vomiting, which brought forth phlegm resembling chicken fat, leading him to be unconscious for three days, occasionally given cool water to drink, gradually regaining consciousness and appetite. Afterward, he prescribed a mixture of ginseng and pinellia pills along with a sweet osmanthus remedy, and after a few doses, he was cured.

In Zhang Ban Village, a child named Lu Zichun, around seven or eight years old, suffered from a cough in the summer, becoming very weak. The physician wanted to induce vomiting, but Zichun feared for the child's frail condition and was hesitant. One day, after drinking wine, the family offered him more, and he vomited extensively, after which the cough ceased. It was likely that the bitterness of the wine acted as an effective remedy, and Zichun then fully understood the physician's advice.[259p]
The "Danxi Heart Method" states:

There was a man over fifty years old who suffered from coughing, aversion to wind and cold, dry mouth, slight heart pain, floating tight pulses in both hands, fullness and distension in the chest and sides, and a rapid pulse, with the left hand significantly larger than the right, indicating general excess in defense and deficiency internally. Upon questioning, he revealed that he usually enjoyed a diet rich in wine and meat, and had a history of food accumulation. Due to exertion in a sweat room and subsequent exposure to cold water, as well as braving light rain and enduring hunger before returning to overeat with wine and meat, he became ill. Initially, he was given four qian of ginseng and one and a half qian of ephedra root, along with two to three doses, which alleviated the cough and eliminated the aversion to wind and cold. Later, the prescription was changed to include magnolia bark, bitter orange, dried tangerine peel, green tangerine peel, (wild) vine seeds, and pinellia prepared into pills, with which over twenty doses were administered, taken with ginseng decoction, and the fullness and distension resolved.

Another man, aged fifty, had developed malaria after laboring in cold water during the hot months, followed by phlegm cough. By the end of summer the following year, his pulse was string-like and the left hand was weak. When struck, he would sweat slightly and produce phlegm, with constant fever and thick yellow phlegm. He was given one tael of pinellia, seven qian of white atractylodes, six qian of poria, half a tael each of scutellaria, dried tangerine peel, balloon flower root, bitter orange peel, and gypsum, along with two and a half qian of fried silkworm and one and a half qian of schisandra, prepared into pills with a paste of fermented flour, and taken with ginger decoction, thirty pills at a time. He was initially given a decoction of three herbs with added scutellaria and white atractylodes, and at night ten small stomach pills to stir his phlegm. Additionally, moxibustion was administered at five points: Dazhui, Fengmen, and Feishu, resulting in his recovery.[260p]
The "Bencao Gangmu" states: In the "Lei Bian," it is recorded that during the time of Huizong, Li Fangyu served as an inner court physician. At that time, a favored concubine fell ill with phlegm cough, unable to sleep all night, her face swollen like a plate. Huizong called for Li to present a diagnosis, decreeing that if there was no improvement within three days, he would face execution. Li, anxious and at a loss, bid farewell to his wife in tears. Suddenly, he heard an outside vendor selling cough medicine, promising that for a small coin per dose, one would be able to sleep immediately. Li purchased a dose and examined it; its color was light green, and fearing the drug might be harsh, he decided to try two doses himself. Having found no adverse effects, he combined three doses into one and administered it to the concubine. That evening, her cough stopped, and by morning, her face had returned to normal. An inner servant rushed to report this, and the emperor was greatly pleased, bestowing a reward of gold and silk worth ten thousand strings. Fearing that the formula might be demanded, Li sought out the previous vendor, treated him to drinks, and offered a high price for the formula. The vendor revealed that he had learned it from a commander during his early military days, having obtained it as a spoils of war for the rest of his life. The formula consisted of genuine clam powder, fried red on new tiles, with a small amount of indigo, and mixed with diluted salt water and a few drops of sesame oil, adjusted to a dosage of two qian.[261p]
Zhao Xun's "Notes on Nurturing Illness" states: A young scholar from Zhao Prefecture suffered from a persistent cough, and none of the hundred medicines worked. Someone suggested using a bundle of soft mulberry branches facing south, cutting each branch into one-inch pieces to boil in a pot with five bowls of water until only one bowl remained. He was to drink this when thirsty, and after a month of this treatment, he recovered. This is also a modified method of boiling mulberry branches.

The "Medical Guidelines" mentions: A middle-aged woman with a dry cough had a pulse that was smooth and bean-like in shape, with the rest being scattered and large without being floating, and the left pulse was stronger than the right. Every morning at the fifth watch, she felt heat in her heart and sweat, but her anger was even worse, and there was no benefit from the herbs like platycodon. Thus, gypsum and cyperus were used as the main ingredients, along with gentian, coptis, indigo, asparagus, perilla fruit, dried tangerine peel, fried licorice, angelica, and platycodon as the assistants. In total, more than twenty prescriptions were given, and she began to feel better. A decoction of fresh ginger boiled with honey, and a decoction of dried tangerine peel were both effective for treating those without phlegm but still coughing, as the spicy-sweet ingredients moistened the lungs. If using only green tangerine peel, all the herbs should remove the white parts.

The "Compendium of Materia Medica" states: Dried tangerine peel is spicy, regulates the qi, and removes phlegm and stagnation; green tangerine peel is bitter and regulates the lower qi. Both flavors work together to disperse the qi of the three jiao (body regions). Therefore, the "Sacred Beneficial Treatise" states: Dried tangerine peel removes obstructive elements; without removing obstruction, phlegm will form; ephedra induces sweating; if the obstruction is not removed, sweating will stop.[262p]
A man over fifty years old was suffering from a serious cold accompanied by a cough, with a hoarse voice. After taking a dose of Ginseng Decoction, his snoring gradually improved, and after two or three patches of treatment, the coughing also subsided. After taking two or three pounds of medicine, he was fully recovered.

"The Essential Readings of Medicine" states: The esteemed scholar Jin Bohan had a cough with difficulty in breathing. He had used nearly all remedies for clearing heat, moistening the lungs, transforming phlegm, and regulating the qi, but his illness showed no improvement. Upon examining his kidney pulse, it was large and soft, indicating a deficiency of qi with excessive fire. I prescribed three qian of ginseng decoction to accompany five qian of the Eight Flavors Pill, and after one dose, there was improvement. Later, I added one qian of cinnamon and eight fen of aconite to the Back to Qi Decoction. After a total of fifty doses and two pounds of the Eight Flavors Pill, he was cured.

The history scholar Ming Lin had been coughing for years and sought treatment from dozens of doctors, trying countless remedies, but his condition worsened. He believed he was bound to suffer from exhaustion. I said: "Not so." His pulse was not rapid and weak but had a large, slippery quality on the right side, indicating unresolved wind-phlegm. He must have consumed too many sour astringents, which exacerbated his condition over time. I prescribed five doses of Ma Huang, Xing Ren, Ban Xia, Qian Hu, Jie Geng, Gan Cao, Ju Hong, and Su Zi, and after knowing the effects, he improved after ten doses.[263p]
Zhang Yuangong had a chronic cough for three years, and medication proved ineffective, so he resigned himself to his fate. One day, he visited me regarding another matter and expressed that he thought he could not be cured, but he requested a diagnosis. I asked him if he felt pain in his chest when hungry, and he said it was very painful. I noticed over ten white spots on his upper lip, which indicated that a worm was gnawing at his lungs. I prescribed a remedy made from hundred parts cream, along with black plum and betel nut. Within ten days, the pain subsided and the cough ceased. I instructed his family to search in a clean bucket, and they found more than forty small white worms. From then on, he never experienced a relapse.

Minister Feng Wuyue's daughter had been suffering from fever and cough for over six months. In October, she coughed up a significant amount of fresh blood. In one day, she could only consume a bowl of porridge, her large meat was consumed, her stools were watery, and she was bedridden, with a pulse rate of seven. I said: "The method is not to save; this is well-known to everyone. If you can only heed my guidance and not be distracted by others, there is hope to save one out of ten." I prescribed three doses daily, each containing five qian of ginseng, three qian of astragalus, two qian of peony, and one qian of dried tangerine peel. After taking seventy doses and three pounds of a strengthening pill, she was able to get up and within three months was able to eat and drink as before. If one were to stick to conventional methods and abandon this, it would lead to hidden and lingering suffering.[264p]
"The Medical Case Studies of Xue Ji" states: A woman, unable to bear children, suffered from coughing, chest obstruction, and a lack of taste in her food. This indicated damage to both the spleen and lungs, with phlegm accumulating internally. The initial treatment was Gui Pi Decoction, supplemented with fresh gardenia fruit, Angelica, Fritillaria, and Platycodon, leading to gradual improvement of her symptoms.

A man experienced fatigue and coughed during winter. He took a dispersing remedy, thinking it beneficial. I said: This is due to weak lung qi and loose pores, making him susceptible to external pathogens. Immediate reinforcement of the spleen is essential for fundamental healing. He didn't believe me, took Six Gentlemen Decoction, removed ginseng and atractylodes, but added herbs like perilla and trifoliate orange, resulting in further depletion of his original qi, leading to lung abscess and his demise.

Doctor Li Beichuan, when overworked, would cough. I treated him with the Baizhong Yiqi Decoction, and he recovered. One day he relapsed and self-medicated with Ginseng and Perilla drink, worsening his condition; he then took Ginseng Dispersing Evils Powder, resulting in stiff neck, locked jaw, and tense back. I stated: He mistakenly lost sweat and body fluids, causing a transformation into a convulsion illness. Continuing with the previous decoction, I added a coin of aconite, and he recovered after four doses. If a cold leads to excessive sweating, difficulty in breathing, and continuous phlegm production, it may definitely result in abscess formation.

Master Tan Xizeng coughed and expectorated phlegm, with cold hands and feet. I diagnosed him with spleen and lung deficiency with cold, treated with Baizhong Yiqi, adding roasted ginger, and he was cured."[265p]
Mr. Ruan, who was sent as an envoy, showed signs of coughing with a pale face and a runny nose; this indicated weakness in the spleen and lungs combined with an external pathogen. I treated him with a formula to tonify the middle and benefit the qi, adding Poria, Pinellia, and Schisandra, which led to recovery. I also later used the Six Gentlemen Decoction, along with Chuanxiong and Angelica, to ensure stability.

Director Chen Guohua had pre-existing yin deficiency and was suffering from a cough. He believed he understood medicine and used diaphoretic and phlegm-transforming medicines, which proved ineffective and worsened his condition. I stated that this was due to weakness in the spleen and lungs, but he did not believe me. Instead, he took Niu Huang Qing Xin Pill, resulting in further abdominal bloating, diminished appetite, and all signs of the three yin deficiencies became apparent. In the morning, he used Six Gentlemen Decoction, Platycodon, Cimicifuga, and the Five Flavors, to tonify the spleen and generate lung qi. In the evening, he took Eight Flavor Pill to reinforce the fire of the Mingmen, supporting the spleen. Over time, the various symptoms improved. The classic states: if one cannot treat the emptiness, how can one ask about the rest? The weakness of the spleen does not allow it to generate lung qi, and using previous medicines only exacerbates the fire; I could not understand that.

Zhongshu Bao Xifu, who also suffered from yin deficiency and a cough, took Qing Qi Hua Tan Pill, along with Er Chen, Scutellaria, and Coptis types, and his phlegm increased. He then used Si Wu, Coptis, Anemarrhena, and Scrophularia; he experienced abdominal bloating and hoarseness, with a floating and wiry pulse on the right and a vigorous pulse on the left. I suggested that since the spleen cannot generate lung qi and the yin fire is counteracting it, it should nourish the source of digestion. In the morning, he took a combination to tonify the middle, adding Cornus, Ophiopogon, and the Five Flavors, and in the evening, he took Six Flavor Rehmannia with Schisandra. After more than three months, he was delighted to find his condition had improved significantly.[266p]
Regarding the patient Shi Zhan, every spring he would cough. I prescribed a decoction of Ginseng and Suye, adding Scutellaria, Lian, Sang, and Xing, and he recovered. In the spring of the Year of Yisi, his condition worsened; he developed a hoarse voice and a weak pulse on the left wrist. I concluded this was related to the kidney meridian's yin fire, affecting the lung's metal; thus, I aimed to nourish the source of transformation. I prescribed Liuwei Dihuang Wan, supplemented with Mai Men Dong, Wu Wei Zi, and fried Gardenia, along with the Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang, leading to his recovery.

The Confucian scholar Zhang Keming experienced coughing, treated with Er Chen, Scutellaria, Lian, Zhiqiao; he felt fullness in the chest, wheezing, and coughed up phlegm early in the morning. I added Suzi and Xingren, which led to the discharge of phlegm and a sensation of dryness and thirst. I diagnosed his early morning phlegm as due to spleen weakness leading to an inability to digest; the chest fullness was also due to spleen weakness failing to nourish the lung's metal; the excessive saliva was from spleen weakness failing to contain it; the thirst and dryness resulted from the spleen's inability to generate fluids. I then used Liu Jun Zi Tang with fried ginger and dried fruit to warmly nourish the spleen and stomach, and also incorporated Ba Wei Wan to replenish the earth element, resulting in his recovery.

One man experienced phlegm and coughing in summer, which did not respond to medicines for stomach fire. I diagnosed this as the fire invading the lung's metal and treated him with Mai Men Dong Tang, leading to recovery. Later, after overexertion, he coughed again; I used Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang, adding Jie Geng, Shan Zhi, Pian Qin, Mai Men, and Wu Wei to assist in his recovery. However, he exhibited dryness of the mouth and fatigue, with dark and scanty urination. I employed Sheng Mai San daily to help him recover. If the cough was due to stomach fire with phlegm, I recommended Zhu Ye Shi Gao Tang. For stomach qi deficiency, I suggested Bu Zhong Yi Qi Tang with Beimu and Jie Geng. If yin fire was surging upwards, I would use Sheng Mai San with Di Huang Wan to protect the lung qi and nourish kidney water. This is a true organ issue, not simply a matter of nourishing the source of transformation, and cannot be resolved by simple methods.[267p]
A woman suffered from a cough, side pain, and fever, which worsened in the afternoons. She was treated with a modified Xiao Yao San plus熟地 and recovered. After a year, due to anger and labor, her previous symptoms returned, accompanied by sun headaches and alternating cold and heat, as well as coughing and frequent urination. These were attributed to liver fire and blood deficiency. Using the previous formula along with Di Huang Wan for over a month, she recovered.

A cousin's wife experienced a cough with fever, vomiting phlegm, producing about five or six bowls of sputum day and night, with wheezing and constant coughing, chest constriction, thirst, and loss of appetite, culminating in a severe menstrual flow. This indicated a deficiency of the kidney's fire and coldness of the spleen, so she was treated with Ba Wei Wan and Fu Zi Li Zhong Tang with modifications, resulting in recovery.

Another woman had a cough, with excessive phlegm in the morning and severe wheezing at night preventing sleep. I noted that the morning phlegm was due to a deficiency in the spleen that led to phlegm formation from food, while the nightly wheezing was due to pulmonary deficiency and excess yin fire. Hence, I prescribed Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction with added Mai Men Dong and Wu Wei, leading to her recovery.

Chen Dao Fu's eldest son suffered from deficiency in the kidney essence and had a chronic cough that worsened in the afternoons. I suggested that he should tonify the spleen, nourish the source of digestion, enabling the metal (lung) and water (kidney) to mutually support each other. During early spring, he was skeptical and instead took Huang Lian and Zhi Mu. By summer, he was coughing up phlegm, felt thirsty, urinated frequently, and had a flushed face. I prescribed a formula of Bai Zhu, Dang Gui, Fu Ling, Chen Pi, Mai Dong, Wu Wei, Dan Pi, and Ze Xie in four doses, which I then combined with Ren Shen, Huang Qi, 熟地, and Shan Yao into pills for him to take. All symptoms quickly subsided. Upon further consultation, I sensed his belief had strengthened, so I continued the previous medication as usual. However, he remained unwilling to take it, ultimately leading to his decline.[268p]
The "Ancient and Modern Medical Treatise" states: A woman suffered from prolonged coughing due to lung heat, her body felt as if it were burned, and her muscles were thin, approaching exhaustion. Using equal parts of loquat leaves, akebia, winter flower, purple aster, apricot kernels, and mulberry white skin, with half the amount of rhubarb powdered finely, forming pills the size of cherries to be taken before bed during winter, she was cured before finishing one dose.

The "Meaning of Herbs" states: A patient presented with cough due to a cold, without any fever, felt extremely anxious as if near death, struggling to breathe. Upon examination, I found his head and face red, restless and unable to calm, and his pulse was large and empty. I remarked that this case was quite unusual, resembling a cold with excess heat; why would a cold also present symptoms this way? It was essential to use ginseng, aconite, and other warming herbs to support the lower source and recover the vital energy. Otherwise, he would profusely sweat at the shi and chou hours and could die from loss of yang. He did not heed my words. As night fell, without needing to exert himself, he grew even more frantic, which led him to urgently take the previous medicine. After taking it, he felt somewhat calmer for a while. I then suggested having someone sleep beside him to help bring out his sweat like rain. After using one more dose, his sweating stopped, and his body felt stable; he no longer coughed. When I inquired about what had happened, he mentioned having taken four doses of ephedra, which made him restless and feel like dying. Thus, I realized that even a cold could present an excess heat pattern, just like in cases of true cold. This was mainly due to his underlying deficiency, which made the true yang more prone to overflowing.[269p]
Lu Lingyi's respected elder was usually on a vegetarian diet, and his stomach and intestines had withered. After the end of his period, the menstrual blood still did not stop, suggesting a possibility of excessive bleeding. Seeing the deleterious effects of anguish upon the intestines, I hurried to treat him, and he had been well for some time. This autumn, however, the dry metal has been excessive, causing coughs and illnesses for everyone. Yet, the elder's body, already weak with deficiency and dryness, was particularly harmed. He experienced tightness and swelling in his chest and ribs, shortness of breath, restless sleep, and severe pain when coughing, with phlegm that was bloody and foul. Eating was difficult, speaking was hard, alternating chills and fever, and during the hours of Shen and You (the latter part of the night and early morning), the dryness intensified, causing all his ailments to worsen. His pulse was sometimes strong, sometimes weak, occasionally firm, sometimes tense and wiry. Taking medicine to clear the lungs was like pouring water onto a fire, yielding no relief. The disciples were at a loss, knowing the situation was critical.[270p]
I was also informed that my lung abscess was becoming serious, and due to my old age, I could not bear it. Therefore, I used a decoction of Qingli and jujube to clear the lung. First, I opened the obstruction of the lung's qi, and then I felt some relief in my breathing, was able to eat a little, and could expel phlegm more easily. My body could also tilt slightly, indicating a significant chance of recovery. But I said: Not yet. I see that the situation is coming on too urgently, and if I am forced to seek immediate relief, ultimately, a temporary opening can easily lead to a reclosure. When it closes again, the previous method cannot be used again. Now, while it is temporarily open, I will explore multiple methods to remedy it, ensuring recovery by the winter solstice in sixty days. The dryness within the body and the dryness of the season are intertwined and difficult to resolve. We must wait for the dry metal to withdraw its qi, allowing the lung metal to attain tranquility. I urge diligent treatment for the condition during this period of sixty days, as there will be frequent crises and recoveries. Generally, all methods used should be active adjustments because supplementing is not appropriate for lung diseases.[271p]
