Therefore, one should first lightly disperse and then gradually contract, so the lungs do not become weak, and the evil does not become stagnant, thus stopping the wheezing and cough on its own.

This concludes the six guidelines.[115p]

　　凡治咳不分外感内伤，虚实新久，袭用清凉药，少加疏散者，因仍苟且，贻患实深，良医所不为也。　　凡治咳遇阴虚火盛干燥少痰，及痰咯难出者，妄用二陈汤，转劫其阴而生大患者，医之罪也。　　凡咳而且利，上下交征而不顾，其人中气者十无一起，如此死者，医杀之也。此有肺热肾寒两证，水火不同，毋论用凉用温，总以回护中气为主。　　凡邪盛咳频，断不可用劫濇药。咳久邪衰，其势不锐，方可濇之。误则伤肺，必至咳无休止，坐以待毙，医之罪也。　　凡属肺痿肺痈之咳，误作虚劳，妄补阴血，转滞其痰，因致其人不救者，医之罪也。　　凡咳而渐致气高汗渍，宜不俟喘急痰鸣，急补其下。若仍治标亡本，必致气脱卒亡，医之罪也。[116p]

In treating coughs, one must distinguish between external causes and internal injuries, as well as differentiate between deficiency and excess, new and chronic conditions. Using cooling medicines with only a slight dispersing effect may seem negligent and lead to severe complications; this is something a good physician should avoid.

When treating a cough resulting from yin deficiency with excessive fire and dryness coupled with little phlegm, using Er Chen Decoction indiscriminately may injure the yin and lead to a serious condition—this is the physician's fault.

In cases where cough and diarrhea occur simultaneously, if one does not pay attention, those with weakened middle qi often have a high mortality rate; thus, should such individuals die, it is the physician’s responsibility.

This condition may involve both lung heat and kidney cold, as water and fire differ; regardless of whether to use cooling or warming treatments, the primary focus must be on protecting the middle qi.

When the evil is strong and cough is frequent, one must never use strong purgatives. If a cough persists while the evil weakens, only then can mild treatments be applied. Mismanagement may harm the lungs and lead to uncontrollable coughing, resulting in a passive waiting for death; this is the responsibility of the physician.

In cases of cough associated with pulmonary atrophy or abscess, mistakenly diagnosing it as deficiency and improperly nourishing yin and blood can hinder phlegm clearance, leading to a fatal outcome—this is the physician’s fault.

For coughs that progress to elevated qi and sweating, one should not wait for urgent symptoms like wheezing or phlegm sounds but must promptly address the underlying issue. If one continues to treat superficial symptoms without addressing the root cause, it will inevitably lead to a collapse of qi and sudden death; this is the physician’s fault.[116p]

　　　　景岳全书 【明　张介宾】

　　　　　论证

　　咳嗽一证，窃见诸家立论太繁，皆不得其要，多致后人临证，莫知所从，所以治难得效。以余观之，则咳嗽之要，止惟二证。何为二证？一曰外感，一曰内伤，而尽之矣。夫外感之咳，必由皮毛而入，盖皮毛为肺之合，而凡外邪袭之则必先入于肺，久而不愈则必自肺而传于五脏也。内伤之嗽，必起于阴分，盖肺属燥金，为水之母，阴损于下则阳孤于上，水涸金枯，肺苦于燥，肺燥则痒，痒则咳不能已也。总之咳证虽多，无非肺病，而肺之为病，亦无非此二者而已。但于二者之中，当辨阴阳，当分虚实耳。盖外感之咳，阳邪也，阳邪自外而入，故治宜辛温，邪得温而自散也。内伤之咳，阴病也，阴气受伤于内，故治宜甘平养阴，阴气复而咳自愈也。然外感之邪多有余，若实中有虚，则宜兼补以散之。[117p]

Discussion on Coughing

Coughing is a symptom that I have observed various scholars complicate with excessive arguments, leading to confusion for future generations in diagnosing and treating it. From my perspective, the essence of coughing can be distilled into two main categories: external causes and internal injuries.

What are these two categories? First, there is external aggression; second, there is internal deficiency, and that is all there is to it. Coughing due to external causes must originate from the skin and hair, as these are connected to the lungs. When external pathogens invade, they must first enter through the lungs. If the condition persists and does not improve, it will eventually affect the five internal organs.

Coughing due to internal injury arises primarily from the deficiency of the yin. The lungs are associated with dryness (metal) and are the source of water. When the yin is depleted from below, the yang is left isolated above; this results in dryness affecting the lungs. When the lungs are dry, they become itchy, leading to persistent coughing.

In summary, although there are many types of coughs, they ultimately stem from lung issues, which can be categorized into these two types. However, it is essential to differentiate between yin and yang and to discern between deficiency and excess. External coughing is attributed to yang pathogens, which enter from the outside; therefore, treatment should involve warming and dispersing, allowing the pathogens to scatter. Conversely, internal coughing is due to yin deficiency, where the yin energy is impaired from within; in this case, treatment should focus on sweet and neutral substances that nourish the yin, enabling the cough to resolve.

Nonetheless, if there is an excess of external pathogens involved, even within an internal deficiency, treatment should involve a combination of nourishment and dispersion.[117p]

内伤之病多不足，若虚中挟实，亦当兼清以润之。大都咳嗽之因，无出于此，于此求之，自得其本，则治之无不应手，又何有巢氏之十咳证，陈氏之三因证，徒致乱人心目而不得有济也。留心者，其熟味此意。　　经云：肺之令人欬。又曰：五脏六腑，皆令人咳，非独肺也。又曰：皮毛先受邪气，邪气以从其合也。又曰：五脏各以其时受病，非其时各传以与之。然则五脏之咳，由肺所传，则肺为主脏而五脏其兼者也。故五脏六腑，各有其证，正以辨其兼证耳。既有兼证，则亦当有兼治。虽有兼治，无非以肺为主也，是固然矣。然愚则犹有说焉。则谓外感之咳，与内伤之咳，其所本不同，而所治亦异。盖外感之咳，其来在肺，故必由肺以及他脏，此肺为本而他脏为标也。内伤之咳，先因伤他脏，故必由他脏以及肺，此他脏为本而肺为标也。[118p]

In the case of internal injuries, many ailments are insufficient; if there's a deficiency that includes a fullness, it should also be addressed with clarity and moisture. Generally, the causes of coughing stem from this; by seeking it here, one obtains the root, making treatment responsive. How can there be confusion like the ten cough syndromes of the Chao family or the three causes of cough of the Chen family, which only serve to confuse people's minds and provide no relief? Those who pay attention will understand this meaning well.

The classics say: the lungs cause coughing. They also state: the five organs and six bowels can all cause coughing; it is not only the lungs. Furthermore, it is said: the skin and hair first receive the pathogenic energy, which combines with the harmony. It is also mentioned that each of the five organs suffers illnesses at their appointed times, and not all can transfer their conditions to each other simultaneously. Therefore, when coughing arises from the five organs, it is transmitted through the lungs, making the lungs the primary organ while the others are supplementary. Thus, the five organs and six bowels each have their signs, distinguished by their accompanying symptoms.

When there are accompanying symptoms, there should also be combined treatments. Even with combined treatments, the emphasis remains on the lungs, which is self-evident. However, there still remains a viewpoint. It suggests that coughing due to external pathogens and coughing due to internal injuries have different origins and require different treatments. In external coughs, the onset is in the lungs, thus it must arise from the lungs to the other organs, making the lungs the source and the other organs the signs. In internal coughs, the initial cause is the injury to the other organs; therefore, it must arise from the other organs to affect the lungs, with the other organs as the source and the lungs as the sign.[118p]

凡治内伤者，使不知治他脏而单治肺，则真阴何由以复？阴不复则咳终不愈。治外感者，使不知治阳而妄治阴，则邪气何由以解？邪不解则嗽终不宁。经曰：治病必求其本。何今人之不能察也！　　劳风证，《内经》评热病论曰：劳风法在肺下，其为病使人强上冥视，唾出若涕，恶风而振寒，此为劳风之病。巨阳引精者三日，中年者五日，不精者七日。咳出青黄涕，其状如脓，大如弹丸，从口中若鼻中出，不出则伤肺，伤肺则死矣。按劳风证，即劳力伤风证也。盖人之劳者，必毛窍开而汗液泄，所以风邪易入。凡今人之患伤风者，多有此证。故轻者惟三四日，重者五七日，必咳出浊痰如涕而愈者，此即劳风之属也。但以外感之法治之，自无不愈。[119p]

To treat internal injuries, one must not only focus on the lungs without understanding how to treat other organs; otherwise, how can the true yin be restored? Without the restoration of yin, the cough will never heal. When treating external conditions, one must not neglect the yang and mistakenly treat the yin; otherwise, how can the evil qi be resolved? If the evil is not dispelled, the cough will remain unrelieved. The classics state: to treat illness, one must seek its root. Why is it that modern people cannot discern this?

Regarding the labor wind syndrome, the "Inner Canon" states that the treatment for heat-related illness requires attention to the lungs. This condition causes people to feel weak, with cloudy vision, and phlegm that resembles mucus, alongside an aversion to wind and chills; this is the disease of labor wind. Those who are robust recover in three days, middle-aged individuals in five days, and the weak in seven days. Coughing up green and yellow phlegm that appears like pus and is as large as a pellet, emerging from the mouth as if from the nose; if it does not come out, it harms the lungs, and lung damage will lead to death.

Labor wind syndrome refers to the effects of overexertion leading to wind exposure. People who exert themselves will have their pores open and sweat to flow, making it easy for wind evil to invade. Many modern cases of wind-injury present this syndrome. Thus, those with mild cases recover in three to four days, while severe cases take five to seven days, ultimately expelling turbid phlegm like mucus before healing, which indeed belongs to the category of labor wind. However, if treated according to the methods for external conditions, recovery is assured.[119p]

其有劳之甚者，或内摇其精，或外劳其形，劳伤既甚，精血必亏，故邪不能散而痰不能出，此即劳损干嗽之类也，所以多不可治。　　外感有嗽，内伤亦有嗽，此一实一虚，治当有辨也。盖外感之嗽，必因偶受风寒，故或为寒热，或为气急，或为鼻塞声重，头痛吐痰。邪轻者脉亦和缓，邪甚者脉或弦洪微数。但其素无积劳虚损等证，而陡病咳嗽者，即外感证也。　　若内伤之嗽，则其病来有渐，或因酒色，或因劳伤，必先有微嗽而日渐以甚。[120p]

Those who are greatly fatigued may either exhaust their essence internally or strain their form externally. When the fatigue becomes severe, both essence and blood will inevitably deplete, which prevents the evil from dispersing and phlegm from being expelled; this is akin to the cough caused by excessive labor, thus often proving difficult to treat.

Coughing can arise from external pathogens as well as from internal injuries; one condition is real, the other is虚 (deficient), so treatment must be discerning. Cough due to external pathogens is usually caused by an exposure to wind and cold, leading to symptoms that may include chills and fever, or breathlessness, nasal congestion with a heavy sound, headaches, and phlegm. If the evil is light, the pulse will be harmonious and gentle, while if it is severe, the pulse may become wiry, rapid, or weak. However, if there are no prior signs of chronic fatigue or depletion, and an acute cough arises suddenly, it indicates an external pathogen.

In contrast, cough resulting from internal injury tends to develop gradually, possibly due to indulgence in alcohol and sensual pleasures or due to fatigue; it generally starts with a slight cough that becomes increasingly severe over time.[120p]

其证则或为夜热潮热，或为形容瘦减，或两颧常赤，或气短喉干，其脉轻者亦必微数，重者必细数弦紧。盖外感之嗽其来暴，内伤之嗽其来徐。外感之嗽因于寒邪，内伤之嗽因于阴虚。外感之嗽，可温可散，其治易；内伤之嗽，宜补宜和，其治难。此固其辨也。然或脉证素弱而忽病外感者有之，或形体素强而病致内伤者亦有之。此中疑似，但于病因脉色中，细加权察，自有声应可证。若或认之不真，而互谬其治，则吉凶攸系不浅也，最宜慎之！
　　　　　外感证治

　　外感咳嗽，无论四时，必皆因于寒邪。盖寒随时气，入客肺中，所以治嗽，但治以辛温，其邪自散，惟六安煎加生姜为最妙。凡属外感，悉宜先以此汤加减主之。若肺脘燥濇，痰气不利，或年老血衰，咳嗽费力者，于本方加当归二三钱。若寒气太盛，或中寒肺气不温，邪不能解者，于此方加北细辛七八分或一钱。若冬月寒盛气闭，邪不易散者，即麻黄、桂枝，俱可加用，或用小青龙汤。[121p]

The symptoms may include night fevers and heat sensations, weight loss, persistent redness in both cheeks, shortness of breath, dry throat, and a pulse that is either light and rapid or thin and tight. Coughs due to external factors appear suddenly, while those from internal deficiencies develop gradually. Coughs caused by external factors are due to cold evils, whereas those from internal injuries arise from Yin deficiency. External coughs may be treated with warming or dispersing methods, making them easier to manage; internal coughs require tonification and harmonization, which complicates their treatment. This is the distinction to be made. However, there are cases where individuals with weak pulses suddenly contract external illnesses, and strong individuals may suffer from internal injuries. In these ambiguous situations, one should closely observe the cause of illness and pulse characteristics to discern the appropriate responses. If one misdiagnoses the condition and treats it incorrectly, it could lead to serious consequences, so caution is advised.

Treatment for External Cough Symptoms

External coughs occur at any time and are fundamentally caused by cold evils. Cold follows the seasonal climate and invades the lungs, so the treatment for coughs is to use warm excitants to disperse the evils, with Liugan Decoction plus fresh ginger being the most effective. For all cases of external afflictions, it is essential to use this decoction, adjusted as necessary. If there is dryness in the lung area with phlegm and air not flowing well, or if the patient is elderly or blood is deficient causing difficulty in coughing, add two to three qian of angelica root to this formula. If cold evils are too intense or if the lung qi is not warm enough to dispel the evils, add seven to eight fen or one qian of northern fine herb to this formula. If in winter when the cold is severe and qi is blocked, making it hard to disperse the evils, add ephedra and cinnamon twig or use Xiao Qing Long Decoction.[121p]

若伤风见寒，或伤寒见风，而往来寒热，咳嗽不止者，宜柴陈煎主之。若寒邪不甚，痰气不多者，但以二陈汤加减主之，则无有不愈。　　外感之嗽，凡属阴虚少血，或脾肺虚寒之辈，则最易感邪。但察其脉体稍弱，胸膈无滞，或肾气不足，水泛为痰，或心(食曹)呕恶，饥不欲食，或年及中衰，血气渐弱，而咳嗽不能愈者，悉宜金水六君煎加减主之，足称神剂。若兼阳分气虚，而脉微神困，懒言多汗者，必加人参勿疑也。若但以脾胃土虚，不能生金，而邪不能解，宜六君子汤以补脾肺。[122p]

If one suffers from a wind injury with cold, or a cold injury with wind, accompanied by alternating chills and fever, and a persistent cough, it is advisable to use a decoction of Chai Chen as the primary treatment. If the cold pathogen is not severe and the phlegm and qi are not abundant, simply adjusting the Er Chen Tang will suffice for treatment, and there will be no lack of cures.

Coughs caused by external factors, particularly in those with yin deficiency and little blood, or those with spleen and lung cold deficiency, are most susceptible to pathogens. However, if one observes that the pulse is slightly weak, there is no obstruction in the chest, or if kidney qi is insufficient leading to fluid accumulation as phlegm, or heart conditions manifesting as nausea and lack of appetite, or if one is middle-aged and experiencing gradual weakness of blood and qi, resulting in a cough that cannot be cured, it is advised to use the Jin Shui Liu Jun Decoction with adjustments. This is highly effective.

If there is also a deficiency in yang qi, accompanied by a weak pulse and spirit fatigue, excessive sweating, one must certainly add ginseng without doubt. If the issue is merely due to spleen and stomach deficiency, unable to generate metal, leading to failure in expelling the pathogen, Liu Jun Zi Decoction should be used to tonify the spleen and lungs.[122p]

或脾虚不能制水，泛而为痰，宜理中汤或理阴煎、八味丸之类以补土母，皆良法也。　　外感咳嗽而兼火者，必有内热、喜冷、脉滑等证，亦但以二陈六安等汤，酌加凉药佐之。热微者，可加黄芩一二钱；热甚者，再加知母、栀子之属。若火在阳明而兼头痛热渴者，惟加石膏为宜。　　外感之证，春多升浮之气，治宜兼降，如泽泻、前胡、海石、(艹舌)蒌之属是也。夏多炎热之气，治宜兼凉，如芩、连、知、蘗之属是也。[123p]

If there is a deficiency of the spleen that cannot control water, leading to phlegm, it is advisable to use formulas such as Lizhong Decoction or Liyin Decoction, or Eight Flavor Pills to nourish the Earth Mother; these are all good methods.

For cough due to external pathogens accompanied by heat, there will definitely be signs of internal heat, preference for coolness, and a slippery pulse. In this case, one should use formulas like Erchen Decoction or Liu'an Decoction, with appropriate cooling herbs added. If the heat is mild, add one or two qian of Huangqin; if the heat is severe, further add Zhimud, Gheda. If the heat is in the Yangming and there are symptoms of headache and thirst, adding gypsum is the right choice.

In cases of external attacks, in spring there is often an excessive rising and floating energy, so treatment should also focus on descending, using herbs such as Zexie, Qianhu, Haishi, and others of that nature. In summer, there is often a hot and fiery energy, so treatment should incorporate cooling herbs, such as Qinchun, Lian, Zhi, and Baike, among others.[123p]

秋多阴湿之气，治宜兼燥，如苍朮、白朮、干姜、细辛之属是也。冬多风寒之气，治宜兼散，如防风、紫苏、桂枝、麻黄之属是也。经言岁气天和，即此之类。然时气固不可不知，而病气尤不可不察。若当其时非其病，及时证有不相合者，又当舍时从证也。至于各脏之气证有兼见者，又当随其兼治，故不可任胶柱之见。　　咳嗽凡遇秋冬即发者，此寒包热也，但解其寒而热自散。宜六安煎、二陈汤、金水六君煎三方，察其虚实壮老用之。如果热甚者，不妨佐以黄芩、知母之类。[124p]

In autumn, there is much damp and humid atmosphere, so treatment should also include drying agents, such as Atractylodes macrocephala, white Atractylodes, dried ginger, and the like. In winter, there is much wind and cold, so treatment should also include dispersing agents, such as Fangfeng, Perilla, Cinnamon twig, and Ma Huang. The classics say that the seasonal energies harmonize with the heavens; this refers to such matters. However, it is essential to be aware of the seasonal influences, and even more so to observe the pathogenic influences. If the season is not aligned with a certain illness, and there are clear signs of incompatibility, one must prioritize the evidence over the season. Furthermore, when there are symptoms in various organs that occur together, treatment should be adjusted accordingly, thus one must not simply adhere to rigid criteria.

Coughing that arises during autumn and winter is due to cold constraining heat; thus, relieving the cold will naturally dispel the heat. The appropriate remedies include Liu An decoction, Er Chen decoction, and Jin Shui Liu Jun decoction—these should be administered according to the patient's condition and constitution. If the heat is particularly intense, it may be beneficial to add ingredients like Huang Qin and Zhi Mu.[124p]

　　　　　内伤证治

　　凡内伤之嗽，必皆本于阴分。何为阴分？五脏之精气是也。然五脏皆有精气，而又惟肾为元精之本，肺为元气之主。故五脏之气分受伤，则病必自上而下，由肺由脾，以极于肾；五脏之精分受伤，则病必自下而上，由肾由脾，以极于肺；肺肾俱病，则他脏不免矣。所以劳损之嗽，最为难治，正以其病在根本，而不易为力也。病在根本，尚堪治不求本乎？故欲治上者，不在乎上而在乎下；欲治下者，不在乎下而在乎上。知气中有精，肺属金，为清虚之脏，凡金被火刑则为嗽，金寒水冷亦为嗽，此咳嗽所当治肺也。然内伤之嗽，则不独在肺。盖五脏之精皆藏于肾，而少阴肾脉，从肾上贯肝膈，入肺中，循喉咙，挟舌本。所以肺金之虚，多由肾水之涸，正以子令母虚也。故凡治劳损咳嗽，必当以壮水滋阴为主，庶肺气得充，嗽可渐愈。[125p]

Treatment of Internal Injury Cough

All coughs resulting from internal injuries must originate from the Yin portion. What is the Yin portion? It is the essence and energy of the five organs. Although all five organs possess essence and energy, the kidney is the source of primordial essence, and the lung is the master of primordial energy. Therefore, when the energy of the five organs is harmed, the disease will manifest itself from above downward, starting from the lung and spleen, ultimately reaching the kidney; when the essence of the five organs is harmed, the disease will rise from below upward, starting from the kidney and spleen, ultimately reaching the lung. If both the lung and kidney are afflicted, the other organs will not be spared. Hence, cough resulting from overexertion is the most difficult to treat, precisely because its root cause is deep-seated and not easily influenced.

When the disease is rooted, can it not be treated by simply addressing the symptoms? Therefore, to treat what is above, one must not focus on the symptoms above but on those below; to treat what is below, one must not focus on the symptoms below but on those above. Understand that within Qi lies essence; the lung, belonging to the metal element, is a light and empty organ. When metal is subjected to the fire's burning, it results in cough; likewise, when metal is cold and water is icy, it also leads to cough; thus, coughs must be treated in the lung. However, coughs stemming from internal injury are not solely present in the lung. The essence of all five organs is stored in the kidney, and the lesser Yin kidney channel extends from the kidney, penetrating through the liver diaphragm and entering the lung, tracing up the throat and surrounding the base of the tongue. Hence, the weakness of lung metal is often due to the depletion of kidney water, with the child (lung) weakening the mother (kidney).

Therefore, in treating cough due to overexertion, it is essential to prioritize strengthening water and nourishing Yin, so that the lung's energy can be replenished, allowing the cough to gradually improve.[125p]

宜一阴煎、左归丸、六味地黄丸之类，择而用之。其有元阳下亏，生气不布，以致脾困于中，肺困于上，而为喘促、为痞满、为痰涎呕恶、为泄泻畏寒。凡脉见细弱，证见虚寒，而咳嗽不已者，此等证候，皆不必治嗽，但补其阳而嗽自止。如右归饮、右归丸、八味地黄丸、大补元煎、六味回阳饮、理中汤、劫劳散之类，皆当随宜速用，不得因循以致侵深无及也。　　内伤咳嗽，凡水亏于下，火炎于上，以致火烁肺金而为干咳，烦热喉痛，口疮潮热，便结喜冷，尺寸滑数等证，则不得不兼清火以存其水，宜四阴煎，或加减一阴煎、人参固本丸主之。此当与咳血证参酌，其治详见血证门。　　咳嗽声哑者，以肺本属金，盖金实则不鸣，金破亦不鸣。金实者，以肺中有邪，非寒邪即火邪也。金破者，以真阴受损，非气虚即精虚也。寒邪者，宜辛宜温；火邪者，宜甘宜清。[126p]

One should appropriately use formulas like Yiyin Decoction, Zuo Gui Pill, and Liu Wei Di Huang Pill. If there is a deficiency in the original yang, leading to a lack of vitality causing the spleen to be constrained below and the lungs to be burdened above, resulting in symptoms like wheezing, fullness, phlegm, nausea, and diarrhea with aversion to cold, then if the pulse is fine and weak, and signs of deficiency and cold are present, and the cough persists, it is not necessary to treat the cough directly; instead, one should tonify the yang, and the cough will cease on its own. Medicines such as You Gui Decoction, You Gui Pill, Ba Wei Di Huang Pill, Da Bu Yuan Decoction, Liu Wei Hui Yang Decoction, Li Zhong Decoction, and Jie Lao Powder should be used promptly based on necessity, and should not be delayed to prevent deeper complications.

For cough caused by internal injury, if there is a deficiency of water below and fire excess above, leading to fire damaging the lung metal and resulting in a dry cough, heat and pain in the throat, mouth sores with tidal fever, constipation with a preference for cold, and a rapid, slippery pulse, it is essential to also clear the heat to preserve the water; thus, Si Yin Decoction or a modified Yiyin Decoction, or Ren Shen Gu Ben Pill should be employed. This should be considered alongside cases of coughing blood, with detailed treatment methods referenced in the section on blood conditions.

For a hoarse cough, since the lung is associated with metal, when metal is strong it does not resonate, and when it is damaged it also does not resonate. A strong metal signifies that there is evil in the lung, either cold evil or fire evil. A damaged metal suggests that the true yin is compromised, which may be due to either qi deficiency or essence deficiency. For cold evil, warming and spicy remedies should be used; for fire evil, sweet and clarifying remedies should be indicated.[126p]

气虚者宜补阳，精虚者宜补阴。大都此证邪实者其来暴，其治亦易；虚损者其来徐，其治亦难。治损之法，当与后干咳证参酌用之。　　内伤虚损之嗽，多不宜用燥药及辛香动气等剂，如六安、二陈之类皆不可轻用，惟甘润养阴，如乳酥、蜂蜜、百合、地黄、阿胶、麦冬、去皮核桃肉之类，皆所宜也。外邪证多误认为劳损，而遂成真劳者，此必其人气体柔弱，而医家望之已有成心，故见其发热遂认为火，见其咳嗽遂认为劳，不明表里，率用滋阴降火等剂。不知寒邪既已在表，凉药不宜妄投。若外既有寒，而内又得寒，则表里合邪，必致邪留不解，延绵日甚。俗云：伤风不愈变成劳。夫伤风岂能变劳？特以庸医误治，而日加侵削，则柔弱之人，能堪几多清理，久而不愈，不至成劳不已也，此实医之所误耳。[127p]

Those with Qi deficiency should tonify Yang, while those with Jing deficiency should tonify Yin. Generally, if the condition is due to an external evil and is acute, treatment is easier. If it stems from deficiency, the onset is gradual, and treatment is more difficult.

For treating deficiency, methods should be combined with those for post-cough conditions. Cough from internal injury due to deficiency should not use drying medicines or aromatic stimulating agents like Liu'an or Erchen, which should be used sparingly. Instead, one should use sweet and moistening substances to nourish Yin, such as cream, honey, lily, rehmannia, donkey-hide gelatin, ophiopogon, and peeled walnuts.

External evil conditions are often mistakenly thought to be caused by overexertion, leading to genuine exhaustion. This is particularly true for those whose Qi is weak and soft, where physicians might misinterpret symptoms of fever as heat and coughing as exhaustion, not distinguishing between exterior and interior issues, thus improperly using Yin-nourishing and fire-reducing medicinals.

It is unknown that if cold evil is already present externally, cooling medicines should not be recklessly prescribed. If there is both external cold and internal cold, it will result in a combined evil, which will cause the condition to persist and worsen.

Common sayings indicate that a cold or wind attack that doesn’t resolve can turn into exhaustion. However, how can a cold truly transform into exhaustion? It is merely due to the mismanagement of inept doctors that leads to daily deterioration. A frail person cannot withstand continual purging; if it remains unresolved for a long time, it can potentially become exhaustion. This indeed is a grave error of medicine.[127p]

故医于此证，最当详察在表在里及新邪久病等因，脉色形气等辨，辨得其真，则但以六安煎、金水六君煎或柴陈煎之类，不数剂而可愈矣。医之不精，此其一也。　　干咳嗽证，在丹溪云：火郁之甚。乃痰郁火，邪在肺中，用苦梗以开之，下用补阴降火，不已则成劳，须用倒仓法，此证多是不得志者有之。愚谓丹溪此说殊不然。夫既云不得志，则其忧思内伤岂痰火病也，又岂苦梗、倒仓所宜攻也？盖干咳嗽者，以肺中津液不足枯涸而然，此明系内伤亏损，肺肾不交，气不生津，精不化气，所以干濇如此。但其有火无火，亦当辨治。若脏平无火者，止因肺虚，故必先补气自能生精，宜五福饮之类主之。若脏气微寒者，非辛不润，故补阳则阴生，宜理阴煎或六君子汤之类。若兼内热有火者，须保真阴，故必先壮水，自能制火，宜一阴煎，或加减一阴煎，兼贝母丸之类。若以此证而但知消痰开郁，将见气愈耗，水愈亏，未免为涸辙之鲋矣。[128p]

Therefore, when diagnosing this condition, one must closely examine both superficial and internal factors, as well as the distinctions between new pathogens and chronic illnesses, along with pulse, complexion, and bodily signs. If the true nature is determined, a few doses of Six An Decoction, Jin Shui Liu Jun Decoction, or similar formulations can cure it. The inaccuracy of a physician is one of the reasons for failure.

In the case of a dry cough, Danxi states: the fire is severely constrained. This indicates phlegm and fire stagnation in the lungs. One should use bitter herbs to open it up and utilize tonifying methods to lower the fire. If this does not relieve the condition, it may progress to consumptive illness, necessitating the use of the reversing method. This symptom commonly affects those who feel unfulfilled. However, I believe Danxi's interpretation is quite different. If it is said that one feels unfulfilled, then their worries and thoughts may lead to internal injury, which is not merely phlegm and fire illness, nor should it be treated with bitter herbs or the reversing method.

A dry cough arises from insufficient fluids in the lungs, indicating internal deficiency. When the lung and kidney are not in harmony, qi cannot produce fluids, and essence cannot transform into qi, resulting in this dryness. It is essential to distinguish whether there is excess fire or not. If there is no fire in the organs, it is simply due to lung deficiency, thus one must first tonify qi to generate essence, suitable for prescriptions like Five Blessings Decoction. If the organ's qi is slightly cold, it cannot be moistened without pungent herbs, so supplementing yang will generate yin; therefore, yin-regulating decoctions or Liu Jun Zi Decoction are appropriate.

If there are internal heat and fire, it is essential to preserve the true yin; thus, one must first strengthen water to control fire, recommending Yi Yin Decoction or a modified version, potentially combined with a pill containing Fritillaria. If one only focuses on resolving phlegm and relieving stagnation in this condition, they will see the qi deplete further and water become more deficient, ending up like a fish stranded in a dry rut.[128p]

　　　　　论河间治口　敕先治痰说[129p]

Discussion on the Governance of Hejian: An Edict on Proper Treatment of Phlegm[129p]

　　愚观河间谓治嗽当先治痰，因以南星、半夏之属为主，似得治嗽之法矣。此其意谓嗽必因痰，故胜其痰而嗽自愈，则理有不然也。盖外感之嗽，必因风寒，风寒在肺则肺气不清，所以动嗽，动嗽然后动痰。此风邪痰嗽之本，本于外感，非外感本于痰也。又如内伤之嗽，必因阴虚，阴虚则水涸金枯，所以动嗽，脾虚肾败，所以化痰。此阴虚痰嗽之本，本于内伤，非内伤本于痰也。今曰治嗽当先治痰，岂求本之道乎？然治外感之嗽，惟二陈之属为最效。何也？盖南星、半夏、生姜、陈皮、枳壳之类，其味皆辛，辛能入肺，辛能散寒，寒邪散则痰嗽自愈，此正所以治本而实非以治痰也。若内伤阴虚之嗽则大忌辛燥，此辈岂堪轻用哉！经曰：肺欲辛，以辛泻之。此肺实者之宜辛也。又曰：辛走气，气病无多食辛。此肺虚者之忌辛也。气味宜否之理，《内经》妙用如此。河间何以不察，而谓南星、半夏之属，但能治痰。岂果治痰之标，便能治嗽之本乎？[130p]

The foolish observer Hejian believes that in treating cough, one should first address phlegm, hence using Nanning and Banxia as the main remedies, thinking he has found a method to treat cough. His reasoning implies that cough must originate from phlegm; thus, overcoming phlegm will naturally resolve the cough. However, this logic is flawed.

Coughs caused by external pathogens must arise from wind and cold; when wind and cold are present in the lungs, lung qi becomes obstructed, leading to cough, which in turn stirs up phlegm. Therefore, the root of cough from wind is based on external factors, not the other way around. Similarly, coughs caused by internal injury are always due to yin deficiency; with yin deficiency, fluids become depleted, and organs become exhausted, which leads to cough, while spleen deficiency and kidney weakness result in phlegm formation. Hence, the source of cough from yin deficiency originates in internal injuries, not from phlegm itself.

Thus, to say that cough should first be treated by addressing phlegm is surely not seeking the root cause! When treating cough from external factors, the most effective remedies are those belonging to the Erchen category. Why is that? It is because remedies like Nanning, Banxia, ginger, aged tangerine peel, and bitter orange are all spicy in flavor. Spiciness can penetrate the lungs and disperse cold; when cold is dispelled, phlegm cough resolves itself—this is truly a treatment that addresses the root cause, not merely treating phlegm. However, for coughs due to internal injuries involving yin deficiency, spicy and drying remedies are strictly contraindicated. Can such remedies be casually employed?

The classic states: the lungs require spiciness, which should be used to purge them. This applies to those with excess lung conditions needing spice. It also states: spiciness promotes qi; if there is a qi illness, one should not consume too much spice. This warns those with deficient lung conditions against spiciness. Thus, the principles regarding flavors and medicinal properties are expertly elaborated in the Inner Canon. Why does Hejian fail to comprehend this and claim that Nanning, Banxia, and similar remedies can solely treat phlegm? Can it truly be that addressing the surface symptoms of phlegm can resolve the fundamental issues of cough?[130p]

　　　　石室秘箓 【清　陈士铎】

　　　　　欬嗽治法

　　肺嗽之证，本是肺虚，肺虚必宜补肺明矣。奈何兼治肾也？盖肺金之气，夜卧必归诸肾之中，譬如母子之间，母虽外游，夜间必返子家以安其身。肺金为心火所伤，必求救于己子以御火侮。傥其子贫寒，何以号多人以报母雠哉！今有一方治之，用熟地、麦冬各一两，山茱萸四钱，元参五钱，苏子、天门冬、甘草、牛膝各一钱，沙参三钱，紫菀五分，水煎服。此方之妙，全在峻补肾水而少清肺金，则子盛于母，而母雠可报。[131p]

Secret Code of the Stone Chamber - Treatment Method for Cough

The symptoms of lung cough stem from lung deficiency, which must be treated by nourishing the lungs. However, it is also necessary to treat the kidneys. This is because the essence of the lung, as metal, returns to the kidneys at night, analogous to the bond between mother and child; although the mother may wander outside, she must return to her child's home at night for rest. If the lung metal is injured by heart fire, it must seek help from its child to defend against this fire attack. If the child is impoverished, how can they repay their mother’s efforts?

There is a prescription for this: use one tael each of cooked rehmannia and ophiopogon, four qian of shan zhu yu, five qian of yuanshen, one qian each of perilla, asparagine, licorice, and achyranthes, three qian of adenophora, and five fen of purple aster, decocted in water and taken as a remedy. The effectiveness of this prescription lies in the strong nourishment of kidney water while minimally clearing lung metal; thus, the child thrives while the mother can repay her efforts.[131p]

又有祛邪之品，用之得宜，全不耗散肺金。譬如子率友朋，尽是同心之助，声言攻击，全不费老母之资，则子之雠虽在未复，而外侮闻风退舍，不敢重犯于母家，此又肺肾同治之妙法也。　　燥证咳嗽，已伤肺矣，复加吐血吐脓，乌得不死？而必欲生之迂矣！不知燥证以致咳嗽，原是外感，非比内伤，虽吐脓血，亦因咳嗽之伤而来，救咳嗽而肺金有养，嗽止而脓血亦消也。方用养肺救燥丹，麦冬、金银花、元参各三两，甘草、天门冬、桔梗各三钱，水煎服。[132p]

There are also remedies to dispel evils; when used appropriately, they do not deplete the lung’s vitality at all. For example, when a child gathers friends, all of whom offer heartfelt support, any verbal attacks do not burden the resources of the mother. Thus, though the child's adversary may still exist, external hostility retreats at the mere mention of it, and they dare not repeatedly invade the mother’s home. This is also a subtle method of treating both the lungs and kidneys together.

In cases of dry cough, if the lungs have already been harmed, further complications like coughing up blood and pus will surely lead to death! Yet the desire to live can cloud judgment! It is not recognized that dry conditions causing a cough originate from external factors, not internal injuries. Even the expectoration of pus and blood arises from lung damage through coughing. To save the cough while nourishing the lung's essence, when the cough ceases, the pus and blood will also dissipate.

The prescription to nourish the lungs and relieve dryness consists of: three liang each of Ophiopogon, honeysuckle, and Scrophularia, and three qian each of licorice, asparagus, and Platycodon, boiled in water for consumption.[132p]

此方单入肺金以润津液，兼消浮火而止脓血，内气既润，外感又除，何愁死证之难治哉！　　咳嗽法，当用轻清之药品，少少散之，无不立效，如小柴胡汤是也。然而小柴胡汤，世人不知轻重之法，予再酌定之，可永为式。方用柴胡、黄芩、半夏、甘草各一钱，陈皮五分，此小柴胡汤。予更加人参五分，茯苓二钱，更为奇妙。盖气足则邪易出而汗易发，世人见用人参，便觉失色，匪独医者不敢用，即病者亦不敢服，相沿而不可救药者，滔滔皆是，安得布告天下医人，详察其病源而善用之也。[133p]

This formula enters the lungs to moisten the fluids, alleviating floating heat and stopping pus and blood. With the internal Qi nourished and external pathogens cleared, how can one fear the difficulty of treating critical conditions?

For cough treatment, one should use light and clear medicines, taking them in small doses, which will show immediate effects, such as Xiao Chai Hu Decoction. However, many do not understand the principles of light and heavy, which I will further refine for lasting use. The formula includes Chai Hu, Huang Qin, Ban Xia, and Gan Cao, each a qian, and Chen Pi five fen; this is the Xiao Chai Hu Decoction. I add five fen of Ren Shen and two qian of Fu Ling for even greater efficacy. When the Qi is sufficient, the pathogens easily disperse and sweating becomes easier.

People see the use of Ren Shen and feel uneasy—not only do doctors shy away from it, but patients also hesitate to take it. This cycle of fear leads to a situation where countless individuals remain beyond help. How can we spread the word to doctors everywhere to examine the sources of illness and use this knowledge wisely?[133p]

　　人病久嗽不已，无不以为邪之聚也。日日用发散之剂而不效者何？气散故耳。气散矣，而仍用散药，无怪乎经月而不效也。法当用收敛之药一二剂，便见成功。方用人参、白芥子、北五味子、苏子各一钱，白芍三钱，酸枣仁二钱，麦冬五钱，益智仁五分，水煎服，一剂轻，二剂全愈。后服六味地黄丸，加麦冬三两、北五味子一两，服之不再发，否则不能保其不发也。盖久服散药，耗尽真阴，虽暂用收敛之药，一时奏功，而真阴既亏，腠理不密，一经风邪，最易感入，此必然之势也。服地黄丸水足而肺金有养，腠理密，又何患重感风邪哉！

For treating cough with a floating pulse:

  • Five liang of magnolia bark
  • Four liang of ephedra
  • One piece of gypsum the size of a chicken egg
  • Half sheng of apricot kernels
  • Half sheng of pinellia

  • Two liang each of dried ginger and asarum
  • One sheng of wheat

Yijian Apricot Soup
Treats cough, regardless of external wind-cold, internal injury from cold, and weakness leading to blood sputum, as well as phlegm stagnation.
Equal parts of:
Ginseng,
Pinellia (processed),
White poria,
Licorice,

Peony.
The following in half:
Asarum,
Dried ginger,
Cinnamon twig.

Baimu San: Treats sudden cough that has not improved for many days.

Ingredients: 2 qian of Baimu, peeled and pointed apricot kernel; 2 qian of mulberry root; 1 qian each of five-flavor fruit, Zhimu, and licorice; and 1.5 qian of (wild) winter flower.

Preparation: Prepare one dose, using two sheng of water, with three slices of fresh ginger. Boil until one sheng remains, and take it after meals. (Note: The recipe in Qixiao Liangfang omits the wild winter flower.)

Cough Relief Formula: Treats various coughs that have persisted without healing.

Ingredients: 2 qian each of Buddha’s ear grass, licorice, ginseng, (wild) winter flower, and powdered alum.

Preparation: Grind finely and make one dose, using two cups of water, with three slices of fresh ginger, one jujube, and half a dried plum. Boil until reduced to seven tenths, and take it after meals.

Cough Nourishing Formula:

Ingredients: One set of beef bones (marrow), 8 liang of white sand honey, peeled and ground apricot kernels; peeled and finely ground yam; and 4 liang each of peeled walnuts.

Preparation: Boil the beef marrow and honey in a clay pot until boiling, filter with silk cloth to remove dregs, and store in a ceramic bottle. Add the yam, apricot kernels, and walnuts to the bottle, seal the opening tightly with paper, and cook in a double boiler for a day and night. Each morning, dissolve one spoonful in warm water and take.[142p]

　　雌黄丸　治暴嗽久嗽劳嗽。
　　叶子雌黄一两研细，纸筋泥固济，令干，勿令泥厚。将药入盒子内，水调赤石脂封，盒子口更以泥封之，候干，坐盒子于地上，上面以未入窑瓦坯子，拥盒子令作一尖子，上用炭十斤，簇定顶上，着火一熨斗笼起，令火从上渐炽，候火销三分去一，看瓦坯通红，则去火候冷，开盒子取药当如镜面光明红色　　右入乳钵内细研，汤浸蒸饼，和丸如粟米大。每服三丸、五丸，食后用甘草汤下，服后睡良久，妙。
　　紫金散　治一切痰嗽，日夜不得眠卧。　　南星去皮脐　白矾　甘草各半两　乌梅肉二两　　右为粗散，用慢火于银石器内，炒令紫色，放冷，研为细末。每服二钱，临卧时，身入被内，用虀汁七分，温汤三分暖令稍热，调前药末服之咽下，便仰卧低枕，想药入于肺中，须臾得睡，其嗽立止。[143p]

Cihuang Pill: Treats violent cough, chronic cough, and cough due to exhaustion.

Take one tael of cihuang leaves and grind them finely. Use paper paste to firmly seal the mixture, allowing it to dry without making the paste too thick. Place the medicine inside a box, mix with water and red lead, sealing the box mouth with paste as well. Wait for it to dry, then place the box on the ground and cover it with unburned clay tiles, packing the box to form a peak on top. Put ten pounds of charcoal on top, ignite it, and let the fire gradually heat from above. After the fire burns down a third, check to see if the clay tile glows red; if so, extinguish the fire and allow it to cool. Open the box to retrieve the medicine, which should be like a shiny, bright red mirror surface.

Next, put it into a mortar and grind finely. Steep a steamed cake in soup, mix well, and form pills the size of a grain of millet. Take three to five pills after meals using honey licorice soup; after taking, sleep for a long while—it's marvelous.

Zijin Powder: Treats all kinds of phlegm cough, preventing sleep day and night.

Prepare the following in equal amounts: peeled nanchang, white alum, and licorice, each half a tael, along with two taels of black plum flesh.

This becomes a coarse powder, cooked over slow heat in a silver container until it turns purple. Allow it to cool and grind it into a fine powder. Take two qian before sleeping. Wrap the body in blankets, mix seven parts of the juice with three parts of warm soup to make it slightly warm, and take this mixed powder down with it. Then lie on your back with a low pillow, imagining the medicine enters the lungs. In a moment, one will fall asleep, and the cough will stop immediately.[143p]

　　苏子煎　治上气咳嗽。
　　苏子　生姜汁　生地汁　白蜜　杏仁各一升　　右捣苏子，以地黄汁、姜汁浇之，以绢绞取汁更捣，以汁浇之，绞令味尽去滓熬，令杏仁微黄黑如脂，又以汁浇之，绢绞往来六七度，令味尽去滓，内蜜合和，置铜器中于汤上煎之，令如饴，每服方寸匕，日三夜一。一方无地黄汁。
　　蜜酥煎　治肺感于寒，成咳嗽上气，及多涕唾，面目浮肿。　　杏仁三升，去皮尖双仁，研　白蜜一升　牛酥二升　　右将杏仁于磁盆中，用水研取汁五升，净磨铜铛，勿令脂腻，先倾三升汁于铛中，刻木记其探浅，又倾汁二升，火煎减至于所记处，即内蜜酥等煎，还至本记处，药乃成，贮不津磁器中。每日三度以暖酒服一大匙。不能饮酒，和粥服亦得。服至一七日，唾色变白，二七日唾稀，三七日咳断。[144p]

Suzi Decoction - Treats upper respiratory coughing.
Take one sheng each of Suzi, ginger juice, raw rehmannia juice, white honey, and almond. Crush the Suzi and moisten it with the rehmannia and ginger juices. Use silk to strain the mixture, then crush again, pouring the juice over it, straining thoroughly to remove residues until the almonds turn slightly yellow-black like grease. Use the juice to moisten again, straining back and forth six or seven times to extract all flavor, mix in the honey, and place in a copper vessel over boiling water until it reaches a syrupy consistency. Take a mouthful the size of a fingertip, three times a day and once at night. If without rehmannia juice.

Honey and Butter Decoction - Treats lung ailments due to cold, resulting in coughing and upper respiratory distress, with excessive nasal discharge and facial swelling.
Use three sheng of almonds, remove the skins and tips, and grind them. Take one sheng of white honey and two sheng of beef butter. In a ceramic bowl, grind the almonds with water to extract five sheng of juice. Cleanse a copper pot, ensuring it is not greasy, pour three sheng of juice into it, marking the depth with a wooden stick, then add two more sheng of juice. Reduce over heat to the marked level, then add the honey and butter mixture and return to the original mark; the medicine is then complete, stored in a dry ceramic vessel. Take one large spoonful mixed with warm wine three times daily, or with congee if unable to consume alcohol. Continue for one week until phlegm turns white, two weeks leads to watery sputum, and three weeks resolves the cough.[144p]

　　百合汤　治肺气壅滞，咳嗽喘闷，膈脘不利，气否多渴，腰膝浮肿，小便淋濇。　　百合　赤茯苓　陈皮去白　紫苏茎叶　人参　大腹皮　猪苓　桑皮　枳壳麸炒　麦冬去心　甘草炙，各一两　马兜铃七枚，和皮　　右粗捣筛，每服四钱，水一盏半，入生姜一枣大，同煎至八分，去滓，不拘时温服。
　　葶苈散　治咳嗽面目浮肿，不得安卧，涕唾稠粘。　　甜葶苈隔纸炒　(木郁)李仁炒　桑白皮各一两　大腹皮去土，七钱半　紫菀　旋覆花　槟榔　木通各半钱　　右为散，每服三钱，水一中盏，生姜半分，煎至六分，去滓，不拘时温服。[145p]

Lily Soup
Treats lung qi obstruction, coughing, shortness of breath, uncomfortable feeling in the chest, troublesome digestion, excessive thirst, swelling in the waist and knees, and painful urination.
Ingredients:
Lily, red poria, peeled tangerine peel, stems and leaves of purple perilla, ginseng, orange peel, pig poria, mulberry bark, stir-fried bitter orange kernel, dried lily bulb (heart removed), and honey-fried licorice, each one tael. Seven pieces of Aristolochia, with skin removed.
Preparation: Coarsely crush and sift the above ingredients. For each dose, take four qian, add one and a half cups of water, and include a piece of fresh ginger the size of a jujube. Cook until reduced by a third, strain, and take warm at any time.

Tingli Powder
Treats coughing, facial swelling, inability to lie peacefully, and thick, sticky phlegm.
Ingredients:
Sweet tingli fried between paper, fried apricot kernel, white mulberry bark each one tael; orange peel (cleaned of soil) seven and a half qian; purple aster, inverted flower, areca nut, and clerodendrum each half qian.
Preparation: Make into powder. For each dose, take three qian, add one middle cup of water, and half a fen of fresh ginger, boil down to six tenths, strain, and take warm at any time.[145p]

　　清咽宁肺汤 【《统旨》】 　治欬嗽。　　桔梗二钱　山栀炒　黄芩　桑皮　甘草　前胡　知母　贝母各一钱　　水二锺，煎八分，食后服。

Qingyan Ningfei Decoction [from "Tongzhi"]
For treating cough.
2 qian of Platycodon,
1 qian each of fried Gardenia, Huangqin, mulberry leaf, licorice, Qianhu, Zhimu, Fritillaria.
2 zhong of water, decoct to 8 parts, take after meals.

Ge Jia Decoction
For treating cough with purulent blood and lung atrophy with emaciation, as well as thick and sticky phlegm.
Ge Jia, soaked, roasted, Zhimu roasted, Fritillaria roasted, mulberry root roasted, deer antler glue roasted until dry, loquat leaves with hairs and tips removed, Kudzu root, ginseng, roasted licorice, almond soaked in apricot kernel soup, skin and tips removed, stir-fried, each 1 liang.
Take 3 qian, in 1.5 bowls of water, decoct to 8 parts, strain, and can be taken warm at any time.

Baohe Decoction
For chronic cough due to exhaustion, leading to lung dryness and atrophy; it is very effective when taken.
1 qian each of Zhimu, Fritillaria, Tiansong, Mai Dong, Tianhua Fen, and stir-fried Coix seed; 0.5 qian each of peeled bitter almond; 12 grains of Schisandra; 6 fen each of Aster, Aristolochia, Platycodon, lily, and Ejiao mixed with Ge powder; 6 fen of Angelica and 6 fen of rhizome of hundred parts; 4 fen each of powdered licorice, perilla, and mint.
2 zhong of water, 3 slices of ginger, decoct to 7 parts, add a spoonful of honey, take after meals. For blood or phlegm with blood, add stir-fried Mugwort, raw Rehmannia, and small thistle. For excessive phlegm, add orange peel, Poria, and (stir-fried) loquat seeds. For wheezing, remove perilla and mint, adding sesame seeds, mulberry bark, and dried tangerine peel.[146p]

　　五味子汤　治咳嗽皮肤干燥，唾中有血，胸膈疼痛。　　赤小豆一撮　五味子　桔梗　紫菀　甘草炒　续断各五分　竹茹一钱　生地　桑皮炒，各二钱　　右，水煎服。

　　本事鳖甲丸　治劳嗽虚证，及鼻流清涕，耳作蝉鸣，眼见黑花，一切虚证，丈夫女人皆可服。　　五味子二钱　鳖甲　地骨皮各三两
　　右为末，炼蜜丸如梧子大。空心食前，温酒或盐汤任意服三五十丸。妇人酢汤下。此方乃曲江人家秘方，服效者众，且处方有理。
　　三拗汤 【《和剂》】 　治寒燠不常，暴嗽喘急，鼻塞痰壅。　　麻黄不去节　杏仁不去尖　甘草不炙，各等分　　每服五钱，水一锺，生姜五片，煎服，有汗即愈。一本甘草减半。[147p]

Wuweizi Decoction: Treats cough, dry skin, blood in saliva, and chest pain.
A pinch of red beans, Wuweizi, Platycodon, Aster tataricus, stir-fried licorice, and Xu-duan, each 5 fen; bamboo shavings 1 qian; raw rehmannia and stir-fried mulberry bark, each 2 qian.
Take the above ingredients and decoct in water.

Ben Shi Bie Jia Wan: Treats cough due to deficiency, clear nasal discharge, ringing in the ears, seeing black spots, and all symptoms of deficiency, suitable for both men and women.
Wuweizi 2 qian; Bie Jia and Di Guo Pi, each 3 liang.
Grind them into powder, mix with honey, and form pills the size of a walnut. Take 30-50 pills before meals with warm wine or salty soup, as preferred. Women can take them with vinegar soup. This formula is a secret recipe from a family in Qujiang, with many effective cases, and is based on sound principles.

San Niao Decoction [from "He Ji"]: Treats inconsistent cold and heat, sudden cough with wheezing, nasal congestion, and phlegm retention.
Mahuang (without removing the nodes), apricot kernels (without removing the tips), and licorice (not roasted), all in equal parts.
Take 5 qian of the mixture, add 1 zhong of water and 5 slices of ginger, and decoct. If sweating occurs, it will cure. In one version, the amount of licorice is halved.[147p]

　　青金丸 【《三因》】 　治肺虚风壅，咳嗽喘满，咯痰血。　　杏仁去皮尖，二两，用牡蛎煅成粉与杏仁同炒黄色，去牡蛎粉不用　青黛一两　　右为末研匀，用黄蜡一两，镕化搜和，丸如弹子大，压扁如饼。每用梨三个，或用软柿饼一个，去核入药在内，湿纸裹煨，约药镕方取出，去火毒，细嚼，糯米饮下。
　　天门冬丸　治肺脏壅热，咳嗽，痰唾稠粘。　　天冬一两半，焙　百合　前胡　贝母煨　桑皮　半夏　桔梗　防己　紫菀　赤茯苓　生地黄　杏仁汤洗，去皮尖双仁，麸炒黄，研如膏，各七钱半　　右为细末，炼蜜和捣二三百杵，丸如桐子大。每服二十丸，不拘时，生姜汤送下，日三服。
　　前胡散　治欬嗽涕唾稠黏，心胷不利，时有烦热。　　前胡　桑皮　贝母煨，各一两　麦门冬一两半　甘草炙，二钱半　杏仁半两，汤浸去皮尖双仁，炒　　右为散，每服四钱，以水一中盏，入姜半分，煎至六分，去滓温服，无时。[148p]

Qingjin Wan [From "Three Causes"]
Treats lung deficiency, wind obstruction, coughing, wheezing, and phlegm with blood.
Prepare two taels of peeled bitter almonds, and pan-fry with powdered calcined oyster until yellow; discard the oyster powder. Use one tael of indigo. Grind the above into a fine powder, mix with one tael of yellow wax, melt and combine. Form into small round balls the size of a bullet, and press flat like a cake. Use three pears or one soft persimmon (seed removed), and insert the medicine inside, wrap in damp paper and steam. Take out once melted, remove heat toxins, chew thoroughly, and swallow with glutinous rice drink.

Tianmendong Wan
Treats lung congestion and heat, coughing, and thick, sticky phlegm.
Prepare one and a half taels of roasted Tianmendong, along with half a tael each of lily, Qianhu, Fritillaria, mulberry bark, Pinellia, Platycodon, Stephania, Aster, red Poria, raw rehmannia, and bitter almonds soaked in broth (remove skin and tips). Roast and grind into a paste of seven and a half qian each. Mix into a fine powder, refine with honey, and pound with two to three hundred strokes, forming balls the size of a tung seed. Take twenty balls each time, without restrictions on timing, swallowed with ginger decoction, three times daily.

Qianhu San
Treats coughing with thick, sticky phlegm, chest discomfort, and frequent heat sensations.
One tael each of Qianhu, mulberry bark, and Fritillaria; one and a half taels of Ophiopogon; two and a half qian of roasted licorice; and half a tael of bitter almonds soaked in broth (remove skin and tips, roast). Grind into powder, take four qian at a time, infuse in a medium cup of water with half a slice of ginger, decoct until reduced by two-thirds, strain and drink warm, without restriction on timing.[148p]

　　枳壳汤 【洁古，下同】 　治久嗽胸膈不利者，多上焦发热。　　枳壳炒，四两　桔梗二两　黄芩一两半　　右为细末，每早取二两半，水三锺，煎至一锺，日作三服，午时、中时、卧时各一服。三日七两半，服尽，又服半夏汤，用半夏姜制切片，每三钱半，水盏半，姜五片，煎至一盏，食后，日二三服。二三日服了，再服枳壳丸，尽其痰为度。
　　款气丸　治久嗽痰喘，肺气浮肿。
　　青皮　陈皮　槟榔　木香　杏仁　马兜铃炮　茯苓　(木郁)李仁　当归　莪朮　葶苈各三钱　人参　防己各四钱　牵牛头末，二两半　　右为细末，姜汁面糊丸桐子大。每服二十丸，加至七十丸，食后姜汤送下。一方无莪朮，有猪苓、泽泻。[149p]

Zhike Decoction: This treatment is for chronic cough and chest oppression with heat primarily in the upper body.

Ingredients:

  • Stir-fried Zhike: 4 taels
  • Platycodon: 2 taels
  • Huangqin (Scutellaria): 1.5 taels

Grind the above into a fine powder. Each morning, take 2.5 taels with 3 pints of water and simmer until reduced to 1 pint. Divide into three doses throughout the day to be taken at noon, mid-afternoon, and bedtime. After three days, consume a total of 7.5 taels. Once finished, take Banxia Decoction, which consists of sliced Banxia and ginger—3.5 qian (a weight unit) of each with half a cup of water and 5 slices of ginger; simmer until reduced to half a cup. This should be taken 2 or 3 times per day after meals for two to three days. Follow this with Zhike Pills to eliminate phlegm.

Kuanqi Pills: This treatment is for chronic cough with phlegm and wheezing due to pulmonary edema.

Ingredients:

  • Qingpi (Green Tangerine Peel)
  • Chenpi (Aged Tangerine Peel)
  • Betel Nut
  • Wood Scent
  • Apricot Kernel
  • Prepared Aristolochia
  • Poria
  • (Wood-fragrant) Li Ren (Plum Kernel)
  • Angelica
  • Curcuma
  • Lepidium sativum (Pungent mustard)

Each of these measures 3 qian; Ginseng and Fangji (Stephania) each measure 4 qian. Use 2.5 taels of powdered Qian Niu Tou (Morning Glory Seed). Mix all into a fine powder, form into pill-sized balls about the size of a tung seed with ginger juice and flour. Take 20 pills per dose, increasing to 70 pills after meals with ginger soup. If E Zhu is not available, substitute with Zhu Ling and Ze Xie.[149p]

　　贝母汤 【《本事方》】 　治诸嗽久不瘥。　　贝母一两，去心，姜制　黄芩半两　干姜生　五味子　陈皮各一两　桑白皮半两　半夏　柴胡　桂心各一两　木香　甘草各二钱半　　右为粗未，每服五钱，水一盏半，加杏仁七粒去皮尖，生姜七片，煎去滓温服。有蒋氏之妻，积年嗽，制此方授之，一服瘥。以治诸般嗽悉愈。此方有寒有热，有收有散，诸嗽通用也。一方有杏仁。[150p]

Ma Dou Ling Wan: This treats chronic coughs that persist for many years and possesses great efficacy.

Ingredients:

  • Ma Dou Ling
  • Ban Xia
  • Almonds (peeled and tip removed), roasted in bran, each weighing 1 tael
  • 21 grains of Ba Dou, peeled and ground

Except for Ba Dou and almonds, grind the remaining ingredients into a fine powder. Use soapberry paste to form pills the size of a wutong nut, coated with realgar. Take ten pills at bedtime, boiled in a decoction of black plum for ease of use.

Bai Mu Tang (from "Ben Shi Fang"): This treats various coughs that do not heal for a long time.

Ingredients:

  • Bai Mu (1 tael, heart removed, processed with ginger)
  • Huang Qin (half a tael)
  • Gan Jiang (1 tael)
  • Wu Wei Zi (1 tael)
  • Chen Pi (1 tael)
  • Sang Bai Pi (half a tael)
  • Ban Xia (1 tael)
  • Chai Hu (1 tael)
  • Gui Xin (1 tael)
  • Mu Xiang (2.5 qian)
  • Gan Cao (2.5 qian)

Grind the right-side ingredients into a coarse powder. For each dose, take 5 qian, mix with 1.5 cups of water, add 7 peeled almond grains and 7 slices of fresh ginger, then decoct and consume warm after straining.

There was a wife of the Jiang family who had a chronic cough for years; this recipe was prescribed to her, and one dose cured her. This remedy cured all types of coughs. It balances cold and heat, and both consolidates and disperses; thus, it is suitable for various coughs. One variant includes almonds.[150p]

Ginseng Powder
Treats various coughs and wheezing, where speech cannot flow. Those with chronic conditions will see significant effects with prolonged use.
Ingredients: Ginseng, Anemarrhena, Fritillaria, Aristolochia, Ephedra (dried at joints), Bitter Apricot Kernels (raw), Pinellia (each 1.5 qian), Tianxian vine (1 qian).
Preparation: Combine and boil with two sheng of water, one black plum, and one spoon of honey until reduced to one sheng; take before bedtime.

Ginseng Lung Decoction
Treats deficiency-cold of the lung and stomach, cough and wheezing, restless sleep, as well as chronic cough with bloody and foul sputum.
Ingredients: Rehmannia root, Ginseng, Honey-fried Licorice, Fried Angelica, Black Plum flesh, Bitter Apricot Kernels (peeled and toasted), Mulberry root (outer skin removed), Anemarrhena, Poppy shell (stems removed and honey-fried), all in equal parts.
Preparation: Prepare with three qian of the mixture, half a sheng of water, one black plum, and one date; decoct to one sheng and drink warm before sleep.

Ginseng and Millet Decoction
Treats chronic cough.
Ingredients: Ginseng, (wild) winter flower, Poppy shell (soaked and fried), all in equal parts.
Preparation: Use four qian of the mixture, one sheng of water, one qian of Angelica, and one black plum; boil down to seven portions and drink warm before sleep.

Chronic Cough Pill (Danxi)
Finely ground sea clam powder with:
Main ingredient: Gallbladder star;
Supporting ingredients: Bitter Apricot Kernels, Chebulic Myrobalan, Blue Indigo, Soap Pod.
Preparation: Mix into a powder and form pills the size of a tung seed, to be taken with ginger soup.[151p]

　　香蚕散　凡久嗽，乃积痰久留肺脘，粘滞如胶，气不能升降，或挟湿与酒而作。　　香附子童便浸　僵蚕炒　海蛤粉　(艹舌)蒌仁　蜂房　杏仁　姜汁　竹沥　神曲各等分　　右为末，炼蜜丸噙化。

　　祛痰丸　一男子五十岁，旧年因暑月入冷水作劳患疟，后得痰嗽，次年夏末得弦脉而左手虚，叩之必汗少而有痰，身时时发热，痰如稠黄胶，与下项方药，仍灸大椎、风门、肺俞五处。　　半夏一两　白朮七钱　茯苓六钱　黄芩　陈皮留白　桔梗　枳壳　石膏煅，各半两　僵蚕炒二钱半　五味子一钱半　　右用神曲糊丸，姜汤下三十丸。先与三拗汤加黄芩、白朮，二贴。夜与小胃丹十丸，以搅其痰。[152p]

Fragrant Silkworm Powder: Generally, prolonged coughing leads to phlegm accumulation in the lungs, which becomes sticky like glue, hindering the upward and downward flow of qi, or it may be combined with dampness and wine. For the formula, use equal parts of: Fragrant Cyperus, immature silkworms (stir-fried), sea clam powder, Chuan lian seeds, bee honeycomb, apricot kernels, ginger juice, bamboo juice, and fermented grain.

Make this into a fine powder and form into honey pills to dissolve in the mouth.

Ban Su Pills: For physical exhaustion, summer season without sweating, leading to prolonged cough and phlegm-heat. Use half-sha (Pinellia) and ginger, both one tael; mix these two herbs with powdered reed root, clam shell, and fermented grain, then combine with both halves of Chuan lian cores and peach kernels to form pills. First take three doses of San Jiao Decoction before taking these pills.

Phlegm-Expelling Pills: A fifty-year-old man suffered from a labor-related heat illness after entering cold water in summer, resulting in a persistent cough with subsequent summer heat. By the next summer, he showed weak left pulses and upon tapping was prone to sweating with phlegm, accompanied by occasional fever, with phlegm thick and yellow like glue. Use the following formula: one tael of half-sha, seven qian of white atractylodes, six qian of poria, half-tael each of scutellaria, dried tangerine peel, platycodon, bitter orange peel, and calcined gypsum, two and a half qian of stir-fried silkworms, and one and a half qian of schisandra.

This mixture should be formed into pills with fermented grain, and take thirty pills with ginger decoction. First, use San Jiao Decoction with added scutellaria and white atractylodes for two doses. At night, take ten pills of Xiao Wei Dan to disperse the phlegm.[152p]

　　大菟丝子丸 【《和剂》】 　治肾气虚损，五劳七伤，脚膝酸痛，面色黧黑，目眩耳鸣，心忡气短，时有盗汗，小便滑数。　　菟丝子净洗酒浸　泽泻　鹿茸去毛酥炙　石龙芮去土　肉桂去粗皮　附子炮去皮，各一两　石斛　山茱萸肉　熟干地黄　白茯苓　续断　牛膝酒浸一宿，焙干　防风　肉苁蓉酒浸切焙　杜仲去粗皮炒去丝　沉香　补骨脂去毛酒炒　荜澄茄　巴戟去心　茴香炒，各三两　五味子　桑螵蛸酒浸炒　覆盆子去枝叶萼　芎藭各半两　　右为细末，酒煮面糊丸如梧子大。每服二十丸，空心温酒盐汤任下。[153p]

Great Cuscuta Seed Pills
Treats kidney qi deficiency and damage, conditions of five labors and seven injuries, soreness and pain in the legs and knees, dark complexion, dizziness and tinnitus, palpitations and shortness of breath, occasional night sweats, and frequent slippery urination.

Ingredients:

  • Cuscuta seeds (washed and soaked in wine)
  • Alisma
  • Deer antler (hair removed and gently roasted)
  • Stone orchid (soil removed)
  • Cinnamon (coarse bark removed)
  • Prepared aconite (skin removed), each 1 liang
  • Dendrobium
  • Corneous Cornelian cherry flesh
  • Cooked dry Rehmannia
  • White Poria
  • Dipsacus
  • Cowherb (soaked in wine overnight and dried)
  • Siler
  • Flesh of Ephedra (soaked in wine, cut and roasted)
  • Eucommia (coarse bark removed and stir-fried)
  • Sandalwood
  • Psoralea (hair removed and wine-fried)
  • Pepper
  • Morinda root (heart removed)
  • Fennel (stir-fried), each 3 liang
  • Schisandra
  • Silk cocoon (soaked in wine and roasted)
  • Raspberry (branches and leaves removed)
  • Ligusticum, each half a liang

Grind the ingredients into a fine powder, mix with wine to form a dough, and roll into pills the size of a jujube. Take 20 pills each time, with warm wine or salty soup on an empty stomach.[153p]

　　甘桔汤　仲景云：少阴咽痛药也。孙真人治肺痈，吐脓血，用生甘草。加减二十余条。　　桔梗三两　甘草一两
　　右，水煎服。咳逆气者，加陈皮；咳嗽者，加贝母、知母；咳发渴者，加五味子；吐脓血者，加紫菀；肺痿者，加阿胶；面目肿者，加茯苓；呕者，加生姜、半夏；少气者，加人参、麦门冬；肤痛者，加黄芪；目赤者，加栀子、黄连；咽痛者，加鼠黏子、竹茹；声不出者，加半夏、桂枝；痰毒头肿者，加鼠粘子、大黄、芒硝；胸痛膈不利者，加枳壳；心胸痞者，加枳实；不得眠者，加栀子；发狂者，加防风、荆芥；加葛根、陈皮。[154p]

Sweet Tangerine Soup

Zhongjing states: A remedy for sore throat due to Lesser Yin. Sun Zhenren treated lung abscess, expelling pus and blood, using raw licorice. Over two dozen modifications can be made.

Ingredients:

  • 3 taels of Platycodon
  • 1 tael of licorice

Preparation: Boil in water and take as a decoction.

For different conditions:

  • For cough with reversed qi, add dried tangerine peel;
  • For cough, add fritillaria and anemarrhena;
  • For cough with thirst, add schisandra;
  • For expelling pus and blood, add purple aster;
  • For pulmonary atrophy, add ejiao;
  • For facial swelling, add poria;
  • For vomiting, add fresh ginger and pinellia;
  • For shortness of breath, add ginseng and ophiopogon;
  • For skin pain, add astragalus;
  • For red eyes, add gardenia and coptis;
  • For sore throat, add mouse glue and bamboo leaf;
  • For loss of voice, add pinellia and cinnamon twig;
  • For phlegm toxicity with head swelling, add mouse glue, rhubarb, and natron;
  • For chest pain with blocked diaphragm, add bitter orange peel;
  • For heart and chest tightness, add bitter orange;
  • For insomnia, add gardenia;
  • For mania, add siler and schizonepeta;
  • Also add kudzu and dried tangerine peel.[154p]

　　射干麻黄汤 【《仲景》】 　治喉中有声。　　射干　细辛　紫菀　(艹款)冬花各三两　麻黄　生姜各四两　五味子　半夏各半升　大枣七枚　　水一斗二升，先煮麻黄两沸，去上沫，纳诸药，煮取三升，分温三服。
　　白前汤 【《千金方》】 　治咳逆上气，身体浮肿，短气肿满，旦夕倚壁不得卧，喉中水鸡声。　　白前　紫菀　半夏　大戟各三两
　　水一斗，浸一宿，明日煮取三升，分三服。
　　清金汤　治丈夫女人远年咳嗽，上气喘急，喉中涎声，胸满气逆，坐卧不宁，饮食不下。　　陈皮去白　薏苡仁　五味子　阿胶炒　紫苏　茯苓去皮　桑白皮　杏仁去皮尖，炒　(艹款)冬花　贝母去心　半夏曲　百合各一钱　粟壳蜜炒　人参　甘草炙，各半钱　　右作一服，水二锺，生姜三片，枣二枚，乌梅一枚，煎一锺，食后服。[155p]

Shooting Rush and Ephedra Decoction
For the treatment of sounds in the throat.
Shooting rush, fine bitter herb, purple aster, and winter flower, each three taels;
Ephedra and fresh ginger, each four taels;
Schisandra and half-suma, each half sheng;
Seven large dates.
Water, one dou and two sheng; first boil the ephedra until it bubbles twice, remove the froth, add the other herbs, and boil down to three sheng, dividing into three warm doses.

White Before Decoction
For the treatment of cough with reversed qi, body swelling, shortness of breath with fullness, unable to lie down leaning against the wall day and night, and the sound of water fowl in the throat.
White before, purple aster, half-suma, and great Ginseng, each three taels.
Water, one dou, soak overnight, boil down to three sheng the next day, dividing into three doses.

Clear Gold Decoction
For the treatment of persistent cough in both men and women, acute shortness of breath, sound of phlegm in the throat, fullness in the chest with reversed qi, restlessness in sitting or lying, and inability to eat.
Dried tangerine peel (white part removed), coix seed, schisandra, and stir-fried donkey-hide gelatin, purple perilla, peeled poria, mulberry bark, peeled bitter almond (top removed), stir-fried winter flower, mother-of-pearl (heart removed), half-suma, and lily bulbs, each one qian;
Cereal husk stir-fried with honey, ginseng, and honey-fried licorice, each half qian.
Prepare one recipe with two zhong of water, three slices of fresh ginger, two dates, and one black plum, and simmer down to one zhong. Take after meals.[155p]

　　杏仁煎　治欬嗽失音不出。
　　杏仁去皮尖，三两，研　紫菀　五味子各一两　生姜汁　白蜜　饧糖各一两半　桑皮　贝母　木通各一两二钱半　　右銼碎，用水三升，熬至半升，去滓，入前杏仁等四味，再熬成膏。每服一匕，含化。一方加(艹款)冬花、知母各一两。

　　小陷胸汤 【仲景】 　治热痰咳嗽。　　黄连一两　半夏半升，洗　(艹舌)蒌实大者一枚　　右以水六升，先煮(艹舌)蒌，取三升，去滓，内诸药，煮取二升，去滓，分温三服。[156p]

Almond Decoction: Treats cough, loss of voice, and inability to speak. Take three taels of peeled almonds, grind them; one tael each of Aster root and Schisandra; one and a half taels each of fresh ginger juice, white honey, and syrup; and two taels and five qian each of mulberry bark, Fritillaria, and Akebia. Crush the above ingredients, use three sheng of water, boil down to half a sheng, strain, add the almonds and the other four ingredients, and continue to boil into a paste. Take one spoonful at a time, and let it dissolve in your mouth. An alternative recipe adds one tael each of winter flower and Anemarrhena.

Voice-Opening Decoction: Treats cough, shortness of breath, fullness and oppression in the chest, and inability to speak. Take one sheng of almonds, roast the peeled almonds, and grind them into a paste; three taels each of Schisandra, Akebia, ginseng, and cassia, with a little skin removed; three taels each of Asarum, winter flower, Acorus, and bamboo shavings; and two sheng of jujube flesh; one sheng each of white honey and fresh ginger juice. Crush the first eight ingredients to the size of mung beans, use five sheng of water, and simmer on low heat until just boiling five to seven times. Strain out the residue, add the ginger juice, honey, and jujube flesh, and boil again until the desired consistency is reached. Take one spoonful with a small cup of warm wine to wash it down. Another version suggests using ash-free wine to hold and swallow.

Small Chest-Closure Decoction (Zhongjing): Treats heat phlegm cough. Take one tael of Huanglian, half a sheng of Banxia (washed), and one large fruit of Trichosanthes. Use six sheng of water, first boil the Trichosanthes, remove three sheng of liquid, strain, add the other medicines, and boil down to two sheng, then strain and divide into three warm doses.[156p]

Three Life Pill: for treating cough.

Ingredients:

  • Walnut kernels
  • Fresh ginger, peeled and finely chopped
  • Almonds, each one tael.
    Combine these three ingredients, grind them into a paste, and form pills. You can make about thirteen to fourteen pills. Chew one pill before bed. Take for several doses, then stop.

Phlegm-Cough Dissolving Pill:

Ingredients:

  • White mustard seeds and talc, each half a tael.
  • Fritillaria and Nanking star anise, each one tael.
  • Wind-washed nitrate, two and a half qian.
  • Huangqin (Scutellaria), soaked in wine, one and a half taels.
    Grind these into a powder, soak in soup, and form into pills.

Ginseng and Pinellia Pill (from Hygienic Treasure):

Dissolves phlegm, stops cough and wheezing, treats wind phlegm and food phlegm, and all types of phlegm-related nausea and headaches. Also for wind headaches, whether on the side or in the front, or for symptoms like dizziness, tinnitus, nasal congestion, dry throat, and poor chest circulation.

Ingredients:

  • Ginseng, Poria, Nanking star anise, and mint, each half a tael.
  • Cold-water stone, native alum, Pinellia, and shredded ginger, each one tael.
  • Pulverized clam powder, two taels.
  • Patchouli, two and a half qian.

Grind these into powder, mix with water to form pills the size of a tung seed. Take thirty pills each time, with ginger soup after meals, three times a day. White soup can also be used. One variation adds half a tael of Huanglian (Coptis) and two taels of Huangbai (Phellodendron) for better effect. Additionally, it treats hangovers and harmonizes internal organs, showing remarkable efficacy.[157p]

　　温肺汤 【《良方》，下同】 　治肺虚感冷咳嗽，呕吐痰沫。　　干姜　半夏汤泡去滑，各一钱　杏仁　陈皮　甘草各钱半　细辛　阿胶炒，各半钱　　右作一服，用水二锺，生姜五片，红枣一　，煎至一锺，去滓，不拘时服。[162p]

Shen Zhu San
Treats wind-cold with symptoms of headache, nasal congestion, and cough.
Ingredients: Cang Zhu (Atractylodes) 2 qian, Qiang Huo 1 qian, Chuan Xiong 1 qian, Bai Zhi 1 qian, Xi Xin 1 qian, Gan Cao 1 qian.
Grind together, make into a paste. Add 3 slices of ginger and 1 inch of green onion, boil and take.

Jin Fei Cao San
Treats lung cold with heavy cough and thick yellow phlegm.
Ingredients: Jing Jie 2 qian, Xuan Fu Hua 1.5 qian, Qian Hu 1.5 qian, Chi Fu Ling 1 qian, Ma Huang 1 qian, Ban Xia 7.5 fen, Xi Xin 3 fen, Gan Cao 3 fen.
Grind together, make into a paste. Add 3 slices of ginger, 2 jujubes, and 1 dried plum, boil in water, strain out the dregs, and take.

Yu Fen Wan
Treats cough due to qi and phlegm.
Ingredients: Nan Xing (Rhizoma Arisaematis) 1 liang, Ban Xia (Pinellia) 1 liang, Chen Ju Pi ( dried tangerine peel) 1 liang.
Grind into powder, mix with natural ginger juice to form pills the size of a walnut. Take 40 pills with ginger decoction. For cold phlegm with tangerine peel, add Gui Zhi (cinnamon).

Wen Fei Tang
Treats lung deficiency with cold-induced cough and vomiting of phlegm.
Ingredients: Gan Jiang (dried ginger) 1 qian, Ban Xia (Pinellia) soaked and prepared, both 1 qian; Xing Ren (apricot kernel) 0.5 qian, Chen Pi (dried tangerine peel) 0.5 qian, Gan Cao 0.5 qian, Xi Xin 0.5 qian, A Jiao (donkey hide gel) toasted, 0.5 qian.
Prepare as a single dose with 2 zhong of water, 5 slices of fresh ginger, and 1 red date, boil down to 1 zhong, strain out the dregs, and take at any time.[162p]

Ginseng and Purple Aster Decoction: Treats lung qi disorders, cough, and wheezing that do not improve. Ingredients: Ginseng, Purple Aster fungus, Cinnamon Twig, Schisandra, peeled and trimmed Apricot Kernel, Licorice, each 10 grams; Squeeze Sand, Poppy Husk (processed with ginger), each 20 grams. Prepare as one dose using two cups of water, five slices of fresh ginger, and two black plums, simmer down to one cup, and take before meals.

Five Awkward Decoction: Treats cold-induced cough and wheezing. Ingredients: Ephedra (with joints intact), Apricot Kernel (with skin), raw Licorice, Schizonepeta, Platycodon, each 20 grams. Prepare as one dose using two cups of water, three slices of fresh ginger, and simmer down to one cup, and take before meals. If there’s a sore throat, add a small amount of Niter after cooking. Another variation omits Schizonepeta and Platycodon and uses Bitter Orange and Pinellia instead.

Jade Mushroom Pill: Treats wind-phlegm obstruction, dizziness, heavy cough, and difficulty in throat passage. Ingredients: Ginseng, peeled White Poria, burned Alum, Tian Nansheng (Processed with rice wash water), Peppermint, each 300 grams; Pinellia (raw), 600 grams. Grind into fine powder, cook with ginger juice to form a dough, and roll into pills the size of a walnut. Take 30 pills with ginger soup after meals. If phlegm is excessive and hot, use peppermint soup instead.[163p]

Zhongru Pulmonary Nourishing Decoction: Used for insufficient lung qi leading to long-term cough, causing the skin to dry and wither, spitting blood with a foul smell, and persistent breathlessness. Ingredients: Zhongru (pounded to rice-like powder) 2 qian, mulberry root 2 qian, cinnamon (with rough skin removed), white quartz (crushed to powder), Schisandra berries, Donghua flower (hardened parts removed), purple aster (washed), Ophiopogon (heart removed), ginseng 1 qian each. Prepare by mixing the powdered Zhongru and white quartz separately. Use all ingredients as one dose, with 2 zhong of water, 5 slices of fresh ginger, 1 jujube, and 30 grains of japonica rice. Boil until reduced to 1 zhong, and take after meals.

Ginseng Lung Moistening Pill: Used for insufficient lung qi, coughing, and wheezing that do not improve over many years, gradually leading to exhaustion, as well as for treating phlegm blockage and symptoms like dizziness, dry mouth, and thick nasal discharge. Ingredients: Ginseng, Donghua flower, Asarum (leaves removed), roasted apricot kernels (peeled), honey-fried licorice, each 4 liang; cinnamon (skin removed), balloon flower, each 5 liang; Anemarrhena 6 liang. Grind into fine powder, mix with honey to form pills the size of a chicken head. Take one pill after meals with light ginger tea.

Eight Flavor Flower Powder: Used for irregular cold and heat in the lung meridian with persistent phlegm. Ingredients: Donghua flower, purple aster fuzz, Schisandra berries, honey-fried licorice, each 1.5 qian; roasted mulberry bark, Ephedra (nodes removed), apricot kernels (soaked, peeled, and pointed ends removed), each 1 qian. Prepare as one dose, with 2 zhong of water, boil down to 1 zhong, and add yellow wax (the size of a soap nut) to take after meals.[164p]

Ren Shen Wan: Treats persistent cough for many years, ineffective against various medicines.
Ingredients:

  • Ginseng, Platycodon, Licorice (each 1 tael)
  • Northern Schisandra, Ejiao, clam powder (each 0.5 tael)
  • Cinnamon, Almond (peeled and roasted) (2.5 qian each)
  • Prepare finely powdered, mix with honey to form pills, each 2 taels makes 15 pills. Take one pill, wrap it in new silk, moisten it in soup, dissolve and swallow.

Da Jiang Qi Tang: Treats excess upper and deficiency lower, phlegm obstruction in the diaphragm, wheezing, dry throat.
Ingredients:

  • Slightly roasted Perilla seeds, Chuanxiong, Asarum, baked Angelica, White Poria, Platycodon, Magnolia bark (processed with ginger), Chenpi (white part removed), fried Banxia (half-baked), Qianhu, Cinnamon (rough skin removed), Licorice (each 1 qian).
    Prepare into one dose with two jars of water, five slices of ginger, five leaves of Perilla, decoct until one jar remains, strain, take after meals. One variant without cinnamon.

Ping Fei Tang: Treats lung qi obstruction, wheezing, phlegm accumulation, alternating chills and fever, dry throat and mouth.
Ingredients:

  • Chenpi (1.5 qian)
  • Banxia (soaked in soup and washed seven times), roasted bitter herb, mint, Perilla, pitless hawthorn fruit, Aster, roasted Almond, Schisandra, mulberry bark (mixed with honey), poppy husk, Licorice (each 1 qian).
    Prepare into one dose with two jars of water, five slices of ginger, decoct until one jar remains, take after meals.[165p]

Ren Shen Jing Jie San
Treats lung disorders caused by wind, phlegm obstruction, unclear head and eyes, inability to speak, dry throat, stiff neck, and nasal discharge.

Ginseng, peeled and pointed almonds, fried platycodon, fine xian, aged tangerine peel, ma huang without root and nodes, each one qian;
Banxia soaked and washed, one and a half qian;
Jingjie spikes, Tongcao, roasted licorice each half qian.

Almond Decoction
Treats elderly individuals suffering from chronic coughing and wheezing, unable to sleep. Effects are immediate.
Ingredients:
Peeled and pointed almonds and walnut meat in equal parts.
Preparation: Grind together into a paste, add a little refined honey, mix well to the right consistency, and form into pills the size of marbles. Take one pill after meals, chewed well with fresh ginger soup.

Phlegm Expelling Pills
Treats wheezing and coughing caused by wind phlegm.
Ingredients:
Ginseng, aged tangerine peel without white part, green tangerine peel, poria, stir-fried white atractylodes, wooden incense, and tianma, each one liang;
Sophora flower buds, Banxia soaked and washed seven times, each seven and a half qian;
Pig’s tooth soap pods, peeled and roasted, five qian.
Preparation: Grind into a fine powder, boil with ginger juice to make a paste, form into pills the size of phoenix seeds. Take fifty to seventy pills after meals with warm wine, ginger soup is also acceptable.[166p]

Perilla and Pinellia Decoction: Used to treat cough, phlegm, and sputum.

  • Ingredients: Perilla, Pinellia (soaked seven times), Aster root, dried tangerine peel (white parts removed), Schisandra, almonds (skin and tip removed, roasted), fried mulberry root, each two qian.
  • Directions: Prepare one dose with two sheng of water, add three slices of ginger, boil until reduced to one sheng, and take three times a day.

Lung Nourishing Decoction: Used to treat lung deficiency with chronic cough.

  • Ingredients: E.jiao, fried clam powder, Perilla seeds, Platycodon, Pinellia (soaked seven times), roasted licorice, each one qian. (Additional ingredients: Winter flower, cardamom, Aster root, Asarum, almonds (roasted and peeled), Schisandra, amomum, dried tangerine peel, roasted mulberry root, Acorus calamus, green tangerine peel), each half qian.
  • Directions: Prepare one dose with two sheng of water, add four slices of ginger, five leaves of Perilla, boil down to one sheng, and take after meals.

Ginseng Drink: Used for cough, phlegm, and general use.

  • Ingredients: Ginseng, Platycodon, fermented Pinellia, Schisandra, Asarum, bitter orange peel, red Poria (peeled), almonds, each one and a half qian; roasted licorice, half a qian.
  • Directions: Prepare one dose with two sheng of water, add three slices of ginger, ten wu mei (black plums), boil until reduced to one sheng, and take after meals. If almonds are not used, omit the black plums from the preparation. For phlegmy cough, add Aster root and increase the licorice.[167p]

Ren Shen Run Fei San: Treats cough, shortness of breath, phlegm congestion, and nasal blockage.
Ingredients:

  • 2 Qian of ginseng
  • 1.5 Qian each of: peeled and sectioned ephedra, peeled and roasted apricot kernels, and peeled heart of fritillaria
  • 0.5 Qian of tangerine peel
  • 1 Qian each of: stir-fried donkey-hide gelatin, platycodon root (without the fibrous roots), and roasted licorice
    Combine these as one dose, using 2 Zhong of water, and 3 to 5 leaves of perilla. Boil until reduced to 1 Zhong, and take it away from meals.

Ren Shen Hua San: Treats lingering cough.
Ingredients:

  • 1 Qian each of: ginseng (without the fibrous roots), (Caulophyllum) winter flower, and toasted millet husk
  • 1.5 Qian each of: anemarrhena, fritillaria, and pinellia
    Combine these as one dose, using 2 Zhong of water and one black plum, and boil until reduced to 1 Zhong. Take before bed.

Xing Xiang Wan: Treats various types of coughs producing phlegm.
Ingredients:

  • 1.5 Qian each of: south star, pinellia, and 1 Liang of alum, ground and soaked overnight
  • 3 Liang each of: sweet-scented osmanthus, soapberry soaked for a week, and tangerine peel soaked and washed
    Combine these four ingredients, avoiding fire, making a fine powder. Use fresh ginger juice to mix into a paste and form pills the size of jujube seeds. Take 50 pills after meals, using light ginger soup to swallow.

Jia Jian Xie Bai San: Treats conditions where yin is low and yang is high, causing cough, vomiting, phlegm, and wheezing.
Ingredients:

  • 2 Qian each of: mulberry white bark and the root of earth bones
  • 1 Qian each of: white tangerine peel (washed), ginseng, and fresh licorice
  • 1.5 Qian each of: white poria and green skin
  • 0.5 Qian of Schisandra berry
    Combine these as one dose, adding 100 grains of polished rice, using 2 Zhong of water, boil to 1 Zhong, and take before sleep.[168p]

Ginseng Lung Tonic
For the treatment of persistent cough after a long duration.
Ginseng and dried tangerine peel, each 2 qian; grain husk and black plum flesh, each 1.5 qian; mulberry bark and licorice, each 1 qian. Prepare as one dose, using 2 sheng of water, boil down to 1 sheng, add a spoon of honey, and take before sleep.

Perilla Decoction
For treating spleen and lung deficiency cold, phlegm, and cough.
Perilla leaves, schisandra, and green tangerine peel (white parts discarded), apricot kernels, mulberry bark, ephedra (without joints), dried tangerine peel, pinellia, ginseng, and licorice, each 1 qian and 2 fen. Prepare as one dose, using 2 sheng of water and 3 slices of ginger, boil down to 1 sheng, and take after meals.

Ginseng Moistening Lung Tonic
For insufficient lung qi, ongoing wheezing and coughing; also treats cold damage with high fever, headache, and body pain.
Dried ginger, 7.5 fen; ginseng, balloon flower, white atractylodes, ephedra (without joints), dried kudzu, and white atractylodes, each 1.5 qian; licorice, 1 qian. Prepare as one dose, using 2 sheng of water, 3 slices of ginger, 3 stalks of green onion, boil down to 1 sheng, and take at any time.

Tingli Powder
For treating lung qi asthenia, phlegm cough, and restless sleep.
Roasted bitter tingli and clam powder, each 1 qian; mulberry bark, gardenia, ginseng, red poria, peeled apricot kernels (roasted), ginger mint, peppermint, dried tangerine peel, fried balloon flower, and roasted licorice, each 1 qian and 3 fen. Prepare as two doses, each with 2 sheng of water and 3 slices of ginger, boil down to 7 fen, and take at any time.[169p]

(Kaun flower) disperses excess heat and treats cold and heat intertwined, alleviating lung qi obstruction, coughing, shortness of breath, excessive phlegm, and throat discomfort. It is suitable for consumption.

(Kaun flower) 7.5 qian each of mulberry root white bark, pinellia, anemarrhena, and 3 qian each of ephedra, fried bitter almond (peeled tip removed), and honey-fried licorice.

Make two doses; for each dose, use 2 jings of water and 3 slices of fresh ginger, decoct to 7 parts, and take at any time.

Almond Decoction treats loss of voice due to coughing.

3 liang of peeled bitter almond, ground; 1.5 liang each of fresh ginger juice and sugar; 1.1 liang each of mulberry bark and fried fritillaria without heart; as well as 1 liang each of purple aster and five-flavor fruit.

Crush these ingredients, use 3 sheng of water, boil down to half a sheng, strain out the dregs, add the previous four ingredients again, and boil into a paste, taking one spoon to dissolve in the mouth. An additional formula includes 1 liang each of (Kaun flower) and anemarrhena.

Cough Remedy:

1.5 qian each of pinellia, bitter almond, fried fritillaria, alum, south star, white ginger, mint, and agastache.

Crush these ingredients to make one dose; use 2 jings of water, 3 slices of ginger, and 1 date, decocting together to 7 parts, to be taken after meals.[170p]

Hanhua Zhǐsòu Wán treats discordance of lung qi and cough, nourishing the heart and lungs when taken regularly; it is effective for both adults and children with all types of coughs.

Ingredients:

  • 1 tael of roasted winter flowers
  • 1 tael of blanched almonds (skin and tip removed)
  • 1 tael of fritillaria bulb (heart removed)
  • 1.5 taels of white peony
  • 1.5 taels of prepared licorice

He Li Le San treats cough.

For the clove-scented He Li Le, roast thoroughly, remove the core, and grind it into powder. Use two qian of this powder, along with one piece of pork (or swine) belly—remove the fat and split it open. Add the medicine inside, mix with one broken piece of black plum, wrap with banana leaves, and cover with thick rice paper. Roast until fragrant, then remove the paper, leaves, and plum, keeping only the medicine and pork. Chew slowly and take three times a day.

Ping Wei Tang treats phlegmatic cough.

Use three taels of fine pork, cut into three thin slices. Use three inches of soapwort, soak it in water, then wring it out and mix two qian of greasy powder in with the meat. Wrap in wet paper and stew until soft by dawn. Chew it with mild fresh ginger soup or decoction of mulberry bark for relief. In the afternoon, expectoration occurs, which is the root of the illness.[171p]
